revision.text:
{{Infobox officeholder | image name = BurtonKWheeler.jpg | jr/sr1 = United States Senator | state1 = [[Montana]] | term_start1 = March 4, 1923 | term_end1 = January 3, 1947 | predecessor1 = [[Henry L. Myers]] | successor1 = [[Zales Ecton]] | office2 = Member of the [[Montana House of Representatives]] | term_start2 = 1910 | term_end2 = 1912 | birth_name = Burton Kendall Wheeler | birth_date = {{birth date|1882|2|27|mf=yes}} | birth_place = [[Hudson, Massachusetts|Hudson]], [[Massachusetts]], U.S. | death_date = {{death date and age|1975|1|6|1882|2|27|mf=yes}} | death_place = [[Washington, D.C.]], U.S. | nationality = American | alma_mater = [[University of Michigan]] | party = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] | otherparty = [[Progressive Party (United States, 1924–34)|Progressive]] (1924) | spouse = Lulu M. White (1883–1962) | children = 3 sons: John, Edward, and John
3 daughters: Elizabeth, Frances (died 1957), and Marion }} '''Burton Kendall Wheeler''' (February 27, 1882{{spaced ndash}}January 6, 1975) was an attorney and an [[Americans|American]] politician of the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]] in [[Montana]]; he served as a [[United States Senate|United States Senator]] from 1923 until 1947. He returned to his law practice and lived in Washington, D.C. for his remaining years. Wheeler was an independent Democrat who initially represented the [[Left-wing politics|left wing]] of the party, receiving support from Montana's [[Trade union|labor unions]]. He ran for [[Vice President of the United States|vice president]] in [[United States presidential election, 1924|1924]] on the [[Progressive Party (United States, 1924)|Progressive Party]] ticket headed by Wisconsin [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] [[Robert La Follette, Sr.]]. An ardent [[New Deal]] liberal until 1937, he broke with [[President of the United States|President]] [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]] on the issue of [[Judicial Procedures Reform Bill of 1937|packing]] the [[Supreme Court of the United States|United States Supreme Court]]. In foreign policy from 1938–41 he became a leader of the non-interventionist wing of the party, fighting against entry into [[World War II]] until the attack on Pearl Harbor. ==Early life and education== Wheeler was born in [[Hudson, Massachusetts]], to Mary Elizabeth Rice (née Tyler) and Asa Leonard Wheeler.[https://archive.org/stream/tankeefromthewes000420mbp/tankeefromthewes000420mbp_djvu.txt Burton K. Wheeler (with Paul F. Healy), ''Yankee From The West: The Candid, Turbulent Life Story of the Yankee-born U.S. Senator from Montana''], Garden City, NY: Doubleday, 1962, full text online at Internet Archive website, accessed December 12, 2012 He grew up in Massachusetts, attending the public schools. He first worked as a stenographer in [[Boston, Massachusetts]]. He traveled west to attend [[University of Michigan Law School]], where he graduated in 1905. He initially intended to settle in [[Seattle]], but after getting off the train in [[Butte, Montana]], he lost his belongings in a [[poker]] game. The new attorney settled there and began practicing law.{{cite book|last=Gunther|first=John|authorlink=John Gunther|title=Inside U.S.A|page=176|location=[[New York City|New York]], [[London]]|publisher=[[Harper & Brothers]]|year=1947|title-link=Inside U.S.A. (book)}}{{cite web|title=125 Montana Newsmakers: Burton K. Wheeler|url=http://www.greatfallstribune.com/multimedia/125newsmakers4/wheeler.html|website=Great Falls Tribune|author=Tribune Staff|accessdate=August 27, 2011}} ==Marriage and family== Wheeler married Lulu M. White. They had six children: John, Elizabeth, Edward, Frances, Richard and Marion. Frances helped her father with his research for his autobiography, ''Yankee from the West: The Candid, Turbulent Life Story of the Yankee-born U. S. Senator from Montana'', which he published in 1962 and dedicated to her and his wife.''Yankee from the West: The Candid, Turbulent Life Story of the Yankee-born U. S. Senator from Montana'', by Burton K. Wheeler and Paul F. Healy, Garden City, NY: Doubleday & Co., Inc., 1962, full text online at Internet Archive Website ==Political career== Wheeler was elected as a [[Montana Legislature|Montana state legislator]] in 1910, and in that position, he gained a reputation as a champion of labor against the [[Anaconda Copper Mining Company]], which dominated the state's economy and politics. He was appointed as a [[United States Attorney]]. During his tenure, he was notable for not issuing a single [[sedition]] indictment during [[World War I]], especially significant as Montana was a large stronghold of the [[Industrial Workers of the World]]. In other parts of the country, IWW membership was suppressed under the new sedition law. {{citation needed|date=September 2013}} ==1920s== In [[Montana gubernatorial election, 1920|1920]], Wheeler ran for [[Governor of Montana]], easily winning the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] primary, and he won the support of the [[Non-Partisan League]] in the general election. The ticket included a multi-racial set of candidates, unusual for 1920, including an [[African American]] and a [[Blackfoot Confederacy|Blackfoot Indian]].''Current Biography 1940,'' p. 858 Wheeler was defeated by [[History of the Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] former U.S. Senator [[Joseph M. Dixon]]. Wheeler ran as a Democrat for the Senate in [[United States Senate election in Montana, 1922|1922]], and was elected over Congressman [[Carl W. Riddick]], the Republican nominee, with 55% of the vote. He broke with the Democratic Party in [[United States presidential election, 1924|1924]] to run for [[Vice President of the United States]] on the [[Progressive Party 1924 (United States)|Progressive Party]] ticket led by La Follette. They carried one state—La Follette's Wisconsin—and ran well in union areas and railroad towns. He returned to the Democratic Party after the election, which Republican [[Calvin Coolidge]] won in an Electoral College landslide. He served a total of four terms and was re-elected in [[United States Senate election in Montana, 1928|1928]], [[United States Senate election in Montana, 1934|1934]], and [[United States Senate election in Montana, 1940|1940]]. [[File:Senator Burton Kendall Wheeler.jpg|thumb|left|Burton K. Wheeler]] ==1930s== In 1930, Wheeler gained national attention when he successfully campaigned for the reelection to the U.S. Senate of his friend and Democratic colleague [[Thomas Gore]], the colorful "Blind Cowboy" of [[Oklahoma]]. Wheeler supported President [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]]'s election, and many of his [[New Deal]] policies. He broke with Roosevelt over his opposition to the [[Judicial Procedures Reform Bill of 1937]], and also opposed much of Roosevelt's foreign policy before [[World War II]]. In the [[U.S. presidential election, 1940|1940 presidential election]], there was a large movement to "Draft Wheeler" into the presidential race, possibly as a [[Third party (politics)|third party]] candidate, led primarily by [[John L. Lewis]]. {{citation needed|date=September 2013}} In 1938, Wheeler introduced Senate Resolution 294, a "sense of the senate" statement that, in order to insure fair competition, AM radio stations in the United States should be limited to a transmitter power of 50,000 watts.[https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=mdp.39015087659424;view=1up;seq=511 "Limitation of Power of Radio Broadcast Stations"] (Senate Resolution 294), ''Journal of the Senate of the United States of America'' (Seventy-Fifth Congress, Third Session), June 9, 1938, page 507. Now commonly known as the [[Wheeler resolution]], it was approved on June 13, 1938[https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=mdp.39015087659424;view=1up;seq=543 "Radio Stations Broadcasting in Standard Band"], ''Journal of the Senate of the United States of America'' (Seventy-Fifth Congress, Third Session), June 13, 1938, page 539. and the next year the [[Federal Communications Commission]] implemented a 50,000 watt cap, which still remains in force.[https://archive.org/stream/broadcasting16unse#page/n184/mode/1up/ "Proposed New FCC Rules Well Received"], ''Broadcasting'', February 1, 1939, pages 16-17, 70-73. ==Opposition to World War II intervention== Wheeler, an outspoken [[non-interventionist]], opposed the U.S. entry into [[World War II]].{{cite web|url=http://pastdaily.com/2017/05/04/may-4-1941-burton-k-wheeler/|title=May 4, 1941 - Burton K. Wheeler Makes The Case Against Intervention|last=gordonskene|date=4 May 2017|website=pastdaily.com|accessdate=17 April 2018}} As tensions mounted in Europe, he supported the anti-war [[America First Committee]]. As chair of the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee, Wheeler announced in August 1941 he would investigate “interventionists” in the motion picture industry. He questioned why so many foreign-born men were allowed to shape American opinion. "Critics charged that the Committee was motivated by animus to Jewish studio heads."David Gordon.[http://bobrowen.com/nymas/americafirst.html ''America First: the Anti-War Movement, Charles Lindbergh and the Second World War, 1940-1941''] Representing the studios was 1940 Republican Presidential candidate [[Wendell Willkie]] who charged that Wheeler and other critics sought to impose the same kind of censorship that [[Nazi Germany]] was enacting all over Europe. Wheeler also led the attack on Roosevelt's [[Lend-Lease|Lend Lease Bill]] charging that if passed "it would plow under every fourth American boy".''Inside U.S.A.'' (Gunther), p. 175. Roosevelt in response charged that Wheeler's statement was "the damnedest thing said in a generation". After the start of World War II in Europe, Wheeler opposed aid to Britain or the other [[Allies (World War II)|Allies]], already fighting in the war. On October 17, 1941, Wheeler said: "I can't conceive of [[Japan]] being crazy enough to want to go to war with us." One month later, he added: "If we go to war with Japan, the only reason will be to help England." The United States Army secret [[Victory Program]] was leaked on 4 December 1941 to Wheeler, who passed this information on to three newspapers.[http://www.ibiblio.org/hyperwar/USA/USA-Victory/USA-Victory-4.html Charles E. Kirkpatrick, ''Writing the Victory Plan of 1941,'' Ch. 4, "Detailed Planning"], [[United States Army Center of Military History]], CMH Pub 93-10. Following Japan's [[attack on Pearl Harbor]], Wheeler supported a declaration of war saying, "The only thing now is to do our best to lick hell out of them."{{cite book|author=Susan Dunn|title=1940: FDR, Willkie, Lindbergh, Hitler-the Election Amid the Storm|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nluuyZI68YIC&pg=PA310|year=2013|publisher=Yale UP|page=310|isbn=9780300190861}} ==Later life== Wheeler sought renomination in 1946 but was defeated in the Democratic primary by [[Leif Erickson (politician)|Leif Erickson]], who attacked Wheeler as insufficiently liberal and for his "pre-war isolationist" views. Erickson in turn was defeated by Republican state representative [[Zales Ecton]]. On September 15, 1950, Wheeler served as counsel to fellow Democrat from Minnesota [[Max Lowenthal]] during the latter's testimony before the [[House Un-American Activities Committee]]. {{Cite book | url = https://archive.org/stream/hearingsregardin195002unit/hearingsregardin195002unit_djvu.txt | title = Hearings regarding Communist espionage in the United States Government | date = 28 August 1950 | pages = 2959–2986 | accessdate = 21 October 2017}} Wheeler did not return to politics, nor full-time to Montana, but took up his law practice in [[Washington, D.C.]] Aided by research by his daughter, Frances (died 1957), Wheeler wrote his autobiography, with Paul F. Healy, ''Yankee from the West'', published in 1962 by Doubleday & Company. He dedicated the book to his wife and daughter. He died in Washington, D.C., aged 92, and is interred in the District of Columbia's [[Rock Creek Cemetery]].[http://politicalgraveyard.com/bio/wheeler.html#R9M0JH46X Burton K. Wheeler profile], Political Graveyard website [[Burton K. Wheeler House|His Butte home]] is a [[National Historic Landmark]] in recognition of his national political role.{{Cite journal|title=National Register of Historic Places Inventory-Nomination: Burton K. Wheeler House|url={{NHLS url|id=76001129}} |format=pdf|date=February 1976 |author=George R. Adams and Ralph Christian |publisher=National Park Service}} and {{NHLS url|id=76001129|title=Accompanying 2 photos, exterior, from 1975.|photos=y}} (681 KB) In 2004, journalist [[Bill Kauffman]] described Wheeler as having been notable as an "anti-[[conscription|draft]], anti-war, anti-[[big business]] defender of [[civil liberties]]".[http://www.amconmag.com/2004/2004_09_27/review.html Bill Kauffman, "Heil to the Chief"], ''The American Conservative'', September 27, 2004. ==In popular culture== *During the 1946 campaign, David George Kin wrote and published ''The Plot Against America: Senator Wheeler and the Forces Behind Him'', a political pamphlet against Wheeler by supporters of the [[Communist Party USA]]. It accused Wheeler and [[Harry S. Truman]] of being part of a [[fascism|fascist]] conspiracy.[http://www.antiwar.com/justin/j090501.html "Wheeler's Progress: The Evolution of a Progressive"], antiwar.com, May 1, 2009. * In [[Philip Roth]]'s [[alternate history]] novel, ''[[The Plot Against America]]'' (2004), Wheeler serves as [[Vice President of the United States|Vice President]] during the [[fictional Presidents of the United States|fictional Presidency]] of [[Charles Lindbergh]]. Roth depicted [[Acting President of the United States|Acting President]] Wheeler as a political opportunist who imposes [[martial law]] in Lindbergh's absence. (However, Wheeler had historically been known as a leading opponent of the martial law imposed by the [[Governor of Montana]] during [[World War I]].) * In an earlier, lesser-known alternate history novel, ''[[The Divide (novel)|The Divide]]'' (1980) by author and cartoonist [[William Overgard]], Wheeler becomes President in 1940, campaigning on a platform of isolationism despite huge victories by the Axis in that year (far larger than those which actually occurred). As a result, when the U.S. belatedly finally enters the war, it is defeated in 1946 and partitioned as spoils between Nazi Germany and Imperial Japan; Wheeler along with most of the government and military are ultimately executed as [[war criminal]]s. ==See also== * [[List of United States Senators expelled or censured]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==Further reading== {{lacking ISBN|section|date=September 2013}} * Anderson, John Thomas. ”Senator Burton K. Wheeler and United States Foreign Relations” PhD dissertation, University of Virginia, 1982 * Johnson, Marc C., “Franklin D. Roosevelt, Burton K. Wheeler, and the Great Debate: A Montana Senator's Crusade for Non-intervention before World War II”, ''Montana: The Magazine of Western History'' (Winter 2012) 62#1 pp 3–22 * Morrison, John, and Catherine Wright Morrison, ''Mavericks: The Lives and Battles of Montana's Political Legends'' (2003), pp 161–96 * Ruetten, Richard T. ''Burton K. Wheeler, 1905-1925, An Independent Liberal under Fire'' (1957); vol 1 of standard biography * Ruetten, R. ''Burton K. Wheeler of Montana: A Progressive between the Wars'' (1961); vol. 2 of standard biography ===Primary sources=== * [https://archive.org/stream/tankeefromthewes000420mbp/tankeefromthewes000420mbp_djvu.txt Wheeler, Burton K., with Paul F. Healy, ''Yankee from the West: The Candid, Turbulent Life Story of the Yankee-born U. S. Senator from Montana''], Garden City, NY: Doubleday & Co., Inc., 1962, full text online at Internet Archive Website ==External links== {{wikiquote}} *{{Commons cat inline|Burton K. revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = David Bird | honorific_suffix = | image = David Bird.jpg | image_size = 200 | alt = A man with a white beard, mustache and sunglasses, wearing a hooded red jacket with yellow zipper, and blue jeans, photographed in winter with snow and bare trees behind him | caption = Bird in February 2013, wearing the jacket he had on when he disappeared 11 months later | birth_name = David Christopher Bird | birth_date = <!-- {{birth date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} for living people supply only the year unless the exact date is already widely published, as per [[WP:DOB]] --> | birth_place = [[Trenton, New Jersey]], U.S. | baptised = <!-- will not display if birth_date is entered --> | disappeared_date = January 11, 2014 (aged 55) | disappeared_place = [[Millington, New Jersey]], U.S. | disappeared_status = | death_date = Presumed to be same as disappearance date | death_place = Millington, New Jersey, U.S. | death_cause = Accidental drowning | body_discovered = March 18, 2015, [[Passaic River]] | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline}} --> | burial_place = <!-- may be used instead of resting_place and resting_place_coordinates - displays "Burial place" as label --> | burial_coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline}} --> | monuments = | residence = | nationality = | ethnicity = <!-- Ethnicity should be supported with a citation from a reliable source --> | citizenship = United States | education = [[Notre Dame High School (New Jersey)|Notre Dame High School]] | alma_mater = [[Rider University]] | occupation = | employer = ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' | organization = | known_for = Reporting on [[energy markets]] | height = 6 ft 1 inch | weight = 200 lb | religion = <!-- Religion should be supported with a citation from a reliable source --> | denomination = <!-- Denomination should be supported with a citation from a reliable source --> | spouse = <!-- Use article title or common name --> | children = | parents = }}
'''David Christopher Bird''' (c. 1959–2014) was an American journalist who covered [[energy market]]s for ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' and was deputy [[managing editor]] for [[Dow Jones & Company|Dow Jones]] Energy Service. He was known for his ability to detect emerging market trends, particularly the [[Price of oil#2014–2015 global oversupply|decline in oil prices]] that began in 2014, before they otherwise became apparent, through close analysis of data. Before working at the ''Journal'' he had worked for Dow Jones overseas, based in its London office.<ref name="West">Melanie Grayce West, [https://www.wsj.com/articles/body-of-missing-reporter-found-in-new-jersey-1426789646 Body of Missing Wall Street Journal Reporter Found in New Jersey: David Bird disappeared after going for a walk near his home in 2014], ''Wall Street Journal'' (March 19, 2015).</ref>
In early 2014 he left his [[Millington, New Jersey]], home for a short walk and never returned. Local search efforts, hampered by [[Early 2014 North American cold wave|that year's severe winter weather]], failed to find any trace of him. [[Conspiracy theory|Conspiracy theories]] surfaced, especially after an erroneous report that his credit card had been used overseas, suggesting his disappearance was part of a pattern of suspicious deaths in the financial sector. However, when his body was finally found in a nearby river 14 months later, the coroner ruled his death an accidental drowning and said there were no signs of foul play.
A native of the [[Trenton, New Jersey|Trenton]] area, Bird was a graduate of [[Rider University]]. In addition to his journalistic work he was an outdoor enthusiast who led [[Boy Scouts of America|Boy Scout]] hiking trips and ran marathons. He did the latter to raise awareness for [[organ donation]], since his life had been saved by a [[liver transplant]] following a [[hepatitis]] infection he suffered in the early 2000s.
==Early life and education== Bird was born in [[Trenton, New Jersey]], and was the youngest of six children.<ref name="West"/> After attending a [[Catholic school|Catholic]] [[elementary school]] in [[Hamilton Township, Mercer County, New Jersey|Hamilton Township]], south of Trenton, where the family lived, he went to [[Notre Dame High School (New Jersey)|Notre Dame High School]] in nearby [[Lawrenceville, New Jersey|Lawrenceville]]. He graduated from [[Rider College]] in 1980.<ref name="West"/><ref name="Website obituary">{{cite web|title=Funeral Announcement and Obituary|url=http://www.finddavidbird.info/Jan2014/obituary/|publisher=finddavidbird.info|date=March 18, 2015|accessdate=January 4, 2016}}</ref>
==Career== Bird worked at the ''[[The News-Press|News-Press]]'' of [[Fort Myers, Florida]] before joining Dow Jones Newswires, and subsequently transferring to Dow Jones's London office.<ref name="West"/> Five years into his career, Bird traveled extensively through Europe and the [[Middle East]], returning to the U.S. in 1988.<ref name="West"/>
Bird worked for [[Dow Jones & Company]] (the publisher of the ''Wall Street Journal''), for more than twenty years, rising to become deputy managing editor of the Dow Jones Energy Service.<ref name="West"/> He was a key reporter on energy markets.<ref name="West"/>
After his death, ''Journal'' editor-in-chief [[Gerard Baker]] praised Bird's reportorial zeal. "His ability to navigate the vast troves of public oil data was unmatched," Baker wrote in a memo to staff. "At 10:30 a.m. on Wednesdays, he could often be seen hunched over his computer, sifting through spreadsheets and crunching numbers just released by the [[Energy Information Administration]]. He was often the first to gain insight into important energy-market trends."<ref name="Baker memo at Romenesko">{{cite web|last=Baker|first=Gerard|authorlink=Gerard Baker|title=''Wall Street Journal'' editor on David Bird: 'Devoted to his beat and generous with his colleagues'|url=http://jimromenesko.com/2015/03/19/wall-street-journal-editor-recalls-david-bird-devoted-to-his-beat-and-generous-with-his-colleagues/|publisher=[[Jim Romenesko]]|date=March 19, 2015|accessdate=January 4, 2016}}</ref>
==Disappearance== Late in the afternoon of January 11, 2014, Bird, who was recovering from a brief stomach illness,<ref name="NYT initial disappearance story">{{cite news|last1=Schweber|first1=Nate|last2=Schwirtz|first2=Michael|title=Authorities Comb New Jersey Woodland in Hunt for Missing Reporter|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/01/17/nyregion/hundreds-search-for-a-missing-wall-street-journal-reporter.html?_r=0|date=January 17, 2014|accessdate=December 20, 2015}}</ref> left his home in the [[Millington, New Jersey|Millington]] section of [[Long Hill Township, New Jersey]]. He told his wife that he planned to go for a brief walk around nearby wooded trails, clad in a distinctive red raincoat with yellow zippers, jeans and sneakers.<ref name="Baker">Al Baker, [https://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/20/nyregion/body-of-missing-reporter-david-bird-is-pulled-from-passaic-river.html Body of David Bird, Missing Wall Street Journal Reporter, Is Found], ''[[The New York Times]]'' (March 19, 2015).</ref> After his return, he said, he intended to take down the family's [[Christmas lights]]. He left his [[cell phone]] to recharge in his absence.<ref name="One-year anniversary story">{{cite news|last=Hochman|first=Louis C.|title=Missing for a year: Reporter David Bird left his home and vanished|url=http://www.nj.com/morris/index.ssf/2015/01/david_bird_one-year_anniversary.html|newspaper=[[Daily Record (Morristown)|The Daily Record]]|date=January 5, 2015|accessdate=December 20, 2015}}</ref>
By the evening, however, he had not returned. His wife called the police and reported him missing. Finding him alive was of great importance to the family, since he was required to take anti-[[Transplant rejection|rejection]] drugs due to his liver transplant. Those had been left at the house as well.<ref name="NYT initial disappearance story" />
"This wasn't right," his wife said later. "Something was wrong." A fellow [[Boy Scouts of America|Boy Scout]] leader noted that Bird "was stuck somewhere, he knows how to shelter himself enough out of the elements. He knows how to signal if he can."<ref name="NBC Mexico report">{{cite news|last1=Sanders|first1=Kerry|last2=Connor|first2=Tracy|title=Missing WSJ reporter's credit card used in Mexico: source|url=http://usnews.nbcnews.com/_news/2014/01/16/22326127-missing-wsj-reporters-credit-card-used-in-mexico-source|newspaper=[[NBC News]]|date=January 6, 2014|accessdate=January 4, 2016}}</ref>
==Search==
A few days after Bird disappeared, [[NBC News]] reported that his credit card had been used in [[Mexico]]. His family, the network claimed, believed his disappearance was not an accident and somehow related to his work.<ref name="NBC Mexico report" /> The family, through a friend, said those were not serious investigative leads, just theories being floated by those looking for answers.<ref name="Star=Ledger theories story">{{cite news|first=Hoochman|last=Louis|title='A lot of theories going around' about missing Wall Street Journal reporter, friend says|url=http://www.nj.com/morris/index.ssf/2014/01/a_lot_of_theories_going_around_about_missing_wall_street_journal_reporter_friend_says.html|newspaper=[[Newark Star-Ledger]]|date=January 16, 2014|accessdate=January 4, 2016}}</ref> Later they learned that the card had not, in fact, been used in Mexico after he disappeared; it had instead just been hacked.<ref name="People discovery story">{{cite news|last=Fowler|first=Tara|title=Missing Wall Street Journal Reporter's Body Found in New Jersey River |url=http://www.people.com/article/missing-wall-street-journal-reporters-body-found-river|newspaper=[[People (magazine)|People]]|date=March 20, 2015|accessdate=January 4, 2016}}</ref> Later, his wife Nancy called that report "a distraction, honestly."<ref name="NY Daily News body discovery story">{{cite news|last=Goldstein|first=Sasha|title=David Bird, Wall Street Journal reporter missing 14 months, accidentally drowned in Passaic River|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/national/david-bird-wsj-reporter-accidentally-drowned-nj-river-article-1.2253217|newspaper=[[New York Daily News]]|date=June 10, 2015|accessdate=January 5, 2016}}</ref>
Early efforts to search included helicopter patrols by [[New Jersey State Police]], with [[Morris County, New Jersey|Morris County]] park police following up on [[mounted police|horseback]] and [[all-terrain vehicle]] while divers searched the nearby [[Passaic River]].<ref name="Six-month story">{{cite news|last=Zaremba|first=Justin|title=Six months after disappearance, family of David Bird says 'words can't describe the anguish'|url=http://www.nj.com/morris/index.ssf/2014/07/family_of_david_bird_six_months_after_disappearance_words_cant_describe_the_anguish.html|newspaper=[[Newark Star-Ledger]]|date=July 12, 2014|accessdate=January 4, 2016}}</ref> Searchers suffered a setback when the winter weather [[Early 2014 North American cold wave|turned colder than usual]] two weeks later followed by heavy snow throughout the region throughout the next two months;<ref name="Fox News story">{{cite news|title=Search to resume for missing Wall Street Journal reporter David Bird|url=http://www.foxnews.com/us/2014/05/01/search-to-renew-for-missing-wall-street-journal-reporter-david-bird.html|publisher=[[Fox News]]|date=May 1, 2014|accessdate=January 4, 2016}}</ref> they continued their efforts by retracing their steps along the sides of local roadways, looking for signs of an unreported [[motor vehicle accident]] or personal items.<ref name="Echoes-Sentinel story">{{cite news|last=Kelly|first=Denis|title=Fellow Scout leader says Millington's David Bird a strong hiker, camper, Scout leader|url=http://www.newjerseyhills.com/echoes-sentinel/news/fellow-scout-leader-says-millington-s-david-bird-a-strong/article_b38c5676-8e84-11e3-a18a-001a4bcf887a.html|newspaper=Echoes-Sentinel|date=February 7, 2014|accessdate=January 5, 2016}}</ref> In March, when the snow melted, the search resumed, focusing on areas nearby where Bird had been known to hike and retracing earlier routes. In May local police said their goal was to have the entire area within a {{convert|3|mi|km|adj=on}} radius of the Bird home thoroughly searched.<ref name="Fox News story" />
Dow Jones offered a $10,000 reward for information on Bird's whereabouts, and colleagues and others raised $35,000 in contributions for Bird's family.<ref name="Milo">Paul Milo, [http://www.nj.com/morris/index.ssf/2015/06/authorities_say_david_bird_died_in_accidental_drow.html Authorities say David Bird died in accidental drowning, report says], NJ Advance Media for [[NJ.com]] (June 10, 2015).</ref><ref>Kimberly Redmond, [http://www.nj.com/morris/index.ssf/2015/03/wall_street_journal_plans_to_make_10k_donation_to.html Wall Street Journal donating $10k to David Bird's family], NJ Advance Media for NJ.com (March 25, 2015).</ref><ref>Paul Milo & Justin Zaremba, [http://www.nj.com/morris/index.ssf/2015/03/colleagues_missing_reporter_david_bird_found_in_ri.html Reporter David Bird, found dead in river, was 'a mentor, a friend, and a model of integrity' ], NJ Advance Media for NJ.com (March 20, 2015).</ref> Dow Jones also kept paying Bird's salary through the end of July 2014, changing his status to unpaid leave of absence after that point.<ref name="Hochman">Louis C. Hochman, [http://www.nj.com/morris/index.ssf/2014/12/union_donates_10000_after_wall_street_journal_stops_paying_missing_nj_mans_salary.html Union donates $10,000 after Wall Street Journal stops paying missing NJ man's salary], NJ Advance Media for NJ.com (December 18, 2014).</ref> After Bird was taken off the payroll, the Independent Association of Publishers' Employees 1096, the [[trade union]] representing ''Journal'' reporters, donated $10,000 to the family and matched members' contributions up to another $10,000.<ref name="Hochman"/> Although no new leads had surfaced, on the first anniversary of Bird's disappearance his family and friends led a candlelight vigil and walk through a nearby park where he had often walked, ending in a [[bonfire]], to keep attention on the case.<ref name="One-year anniversary story" />
===Discovery of body===
On March 18, 2015, a family website asking for assistance in the search went online. That day, two canoeists on the Passaic, its waters high after [[2014–15 North American winter#Late January blizzard|another winter of heavy snow and bitter cold]],<ref name="Daily Record discovery story">{{cite news|last=Wright|first=Peggy|title=Questions remain in death of David Bird, Long Hill Twp. father of 2|url=http://www.dailyrecord.com/story/news/local/2015/03/20/questions-remain-death-long-hill-twp-father/25075741/|newspaper=[[Daily Record (Morristown)|Daily Record]]|date=March 20, 2015|accessdate=January 5, 2016}}</ref> found Bird's red jacket entangled in branches on the Morris County side of a stretch of the river near King George Road in neighboring [[Somerset County, New Jersey|Somerset County]]'s [[Warren Township, New Jersey|Warren Township]],<ref name="Daily Record identification story">{{cite news|last=Wright|first=Peggy|title=Death of David Bird in Long Hill ruled a drowning|url=http://www.dailyrecord.com/story/news/local/2015/06/09/death-david-bird-long-hill-ruled-drowning/28756505/|newspaper=[[Daily Record (Morristown)|Daily Record]]|date=June 9, 2015|accessdate=January 5, 2016}}</ref> roughly one mile (1.6 km) from Bird's home.<ref name="NY Daily News body discovery story" /> They notified authorities, who found the body about {{convert|20|ft}} off the shoreline,<ref name="Zaremba">Justin Zaremba, [http://www.nj.com/morris/index.ssf/2015/03/14_months_after_disappearance_mourners_gather_for.html Funeral of David Bird brings closure 14 months after he disappeared, friends say], NJ Advance Media for [[NJ.com]] (March 26, 2015)</ref> under {{convert|7|ft}} of water,<ref name="Daily Record identification story" /> an area that had been searched before several times.<ref name="NY Daily News body discovery story" /> The remains were identified through [[dental record]]s.<ref name="West"/><ref name="Zaremba"/><ref name="Baker"/> A subsequent investigation<ref name="Baker"/> determined that the [[cause of death]] was accidental drowning.<ref name="Milo"/> His wife believed it was possible that Bird "slipped and fell into the water while hurrying home ahead of an incoming storm."<ref name="NY Daily News body discovery story" />
==Personal life== Bird met Nancy Fleming around 1988, and they wed in 1991.<ref name="West"/> The couple had two children, a son born in 1998 and a daughter born in 2001.<ref name="West"/>
Bird contracted a rare form of [[hepatitis]] about nine years before his disappearance and death and received a lifesaving [[liver transplant]] in 2004,<ref name="Zaremba"/><ref name="Milo"/> which Bird discussed on his blog and which was reported in local newspapers.<ref name="West"/> Bird was an advocate for [[organ donation]].<ref name="Zaremba"/>
Bird was described in his ''Wall Street Journal'' obituary as "an avid hiker, lover of [[reggae]] music, a [[Boston Red Sox]] fan, cyclist, camper, marathoner and a scout-troop leader" who had traveled to more than 35 countries.<ref name="West"/>
In the last years of his life he had started running [[marathon]]s. In 2012 he finished the [[Harrisburg, Pennsylvania|Harrisburg]] Marathon, followed by the [[New York City Marathon]] the next year. He also competed in the New York City [[Triathlon]] twice and was a member of Team Liberty at the National Transplant Games.<ref name="Website obituary" /> Through his athletic activities he hoped to draw support for organ donation and be an example for other transplant recipients.<ref name="USA Today story">{{cite news|last=Eversley|first=Melanie|title=Missing reporter set example for transplant recipients|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2014/01/17/david-bird-missing-liver-transplant-marathon/4612219/|newspaper=[[USA Today]]|date=January 17, 2014|accessdate=January 5, 2016}}</ref>
Running the marathon had particular significance for Bird since he had first learned he would need a transplant to live on the day of the 2004 marathon. He ran the race with a note thanking his donor pinned to him. "I met my goal of hitting the finish line in less time than I was in surgery," he said later.<ref name="Miles of Smiles">{{cite web|last=Bird|first=David|title=Miles of Smiles|url=http://www.finddavidbird.info/Jan2014/about/|publisher=finddavidbird.info|date=November 2013|accessdate=January 5, 2016}}</ref>
==Alternative theories==
Although no signs of foul play were reported in his death, Bird's fate inspired theories that what happened was somehow the result of a conspiracy of some nature that had also claimed other lives in the financial industry during the same period.<ref name="The Wrap">{{cite news|last=Burchette|first=Jordan|title=Wall Street Journal Reporter’s Body Found a Year After His Disappearance|url=http://www.thewrap.com/wall-street-journal-reporter-david-bird-body-found/|newspaper=[[TheWrap]]|date=March 19, 2015|accessdate=January 6, 2016}}</ref> According to the theory, his disappearance and death were related to a string of suicides and other untimely deaths of present and former [[JPMorganChase]] employees in late 2013 and early 2014, supposedly after two of them had uncovered evidence of major wrongdoing on the company's part. In his final column for ''[[Bloomberg View]]'', several months after Bird was reported missing, [[William D. Cohan]], a former Chase employee himself who had some admitted disputes with the company, looked into the rumors and found that Chase had indeed experienced an unusual number of deaths of employees in their 30s during that period, especially when compared to similarly-sized [[investment bank]]s. But, since several of those deaths were indisputably suicides, he concluded that it was just as likely that those deaths were simply the result of working in an already stressful industry during a stressful period.<ref name="Cohan BV piece">{{cite news|last=Cohan|first=William D.|title=Is Wall Street Killing Its Bankers?|url=http://www.bloombergview.com/articles/2014-05-09/is-wall-street-killing-its-bankers|newspaper=[[Bloomberg View]]|date=May 9, 2014|accessdate=January 6, 2016}}</ref>
==See also== {{portal|Biography|Journalism|New Jersey}} *[[List of drowning victims]] *[[List of organ transplant donors and recipients]] *[[List of Rider University people]] *[[List of people who disappeared mysteriously#Solved cases|List of people who disappeared mysteriously]]

[https://www.academia.edu/29300010/Egyptian_Revolution_A_Demographic_Structural_Analysis Egyptian Revolution: A Demographic Structural Analysis. ''Entelequia. Revista Interdisciplinar'' 13 (2011): 139–169.] * [[Arab Spring|Other regional protests]] |goals = |result = * Overthrow of [[History of Egypt under Hosni Mubarak|Mubarak government]] * Resignation of Prime Ministers [[Ahmed Nazif|Nazif]] and [[Ahmed Shafik|Shafik]]{{cite web|url=http://www.forexyard.com/en/news/Egypts-prime-minsiter-quits-new-govt-soon-army-2011-03-03T093300Z |title=Egypt's prime minister quits, new govt soon-army |publisher=Forexyard.com |accessdate=5 March 2011 |
