below.'' }} | injuries = 6,467 people{{cite web |url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/326562 |title=Egypt's revolution death toll rises to 384 |publisher=Al Masry Al Youm |date=22 February 2011 |accessdate=22 February 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110314134608/http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/326562|archivedate=14 March 2011 |deadurl= no}} | arrests = 12,000{{cite web|author=Faisal Al Yafai |url=http://www.thenational.ae/thenationalconversation/comment/egypts-army-fails-to-grasp-the-post-mubarak-realities |title=Egypt's army fails to grasp the post-Mubarak realities – The National |publisher=Thenational.ae |date=12 November 2012 |accessdate=17 November 2012}} |casualties_label = |notes = }} {{Egyptian crisis (2011–14)}} The '''Egyptian revolution of 2011''', locally known as the '''January 25 Revolution''' ({{lang-arz|ثورة 25 يناير}}; {{transl|ar|''Thawret 25 yanāyir''}}),[http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/01/28/egypt.press.club/index.html?eref=edition_africa Egyptian-American leaders call for U.S. support of 'Lotus Revolution' - CNN.com]. Edition.cnn.com. Retrieved on 2013-12-06. and as the '''Egyptian Revolution of Dignity'''{{cite journal|doi=10.1215/01903659-1506283 | volume=39 | issue=1 | title=A Revolution of Dignity and Poetry | year=2012 | journal=Boundary 2 | pages=137–165 | last1 = Omri | first1 = Mohamed-Salah}}For revolutionary forces' demand for human dignity (''karama ensaneya''){{cite journal|doi=10.4000/socio.408 | volume=2 |title=Contested Meanings in the Egyptian Revolution | year=2013 | journal=Socio | pages=81–98 | last1 = Rennick | first1 = Sarah Anne |issn=2266-3134}} began on 25 January 2011 and took place across all of [[Egypt]]. The date was set by various youth groups to coincide with the annual Egyptian "police day" as a statement against increasing police brutality during the last few years of Mubarak's presidency. It consisted of demonstrations, marches, occupations of plazas, non-violent [[civil resistance]], acts of [[civil disobedience]] and strikes. Millions of protesters from a range of [[socio-economic]] and religious backgrounds demanded the overthrow of [[Egyptian President]] [[Hosni Mubarak]]. The revolution started by calls for protests from online youth groups. Initially these included liberal, anti-capitalist, nationalist, and feminist elements, but they finally included Islamist elements as well. Violent clashes between security forces and protesters resulted in at least 846 people killed and over 6,000 injured.{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/node/385140 |title=شيحة: مكاتب الصحة وثقت سقوط 840 شهيداً خلال ثورة 25 يناير |publisher=Almasry-alyoum.com |date=16 March 2011 |accessdate=4 April 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110429125656/http://www.almasryalyoum.com/node/385140|archivedate= 29 April 2011|deadurl= no}}{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-14075493 |title=Egypt: Cairo's Tahrir Square fills with protesters |publisher=BBC |date=8 July 2011 |accessdate=11 July 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110709112514/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-14075493|archivedate= 9 July 2011|deadurl= no}} Protesters retaliated by burning over 90 police stations across the country.{{cite web|url=http://www.egyptindependent.com/news/was-egyptian-revolution-really-non-violent |title=Was the Egyptian revolution really non-violent? |newspaper=Egypt Independent |date=2012-01-24 |accessdate=2013-03-25}} The protests took place in [[Cairo]], [[Alexandria]], and in all major cities across the nation. The Egyptian protesters' grievances focused on legal and political issues,{{cite web|url=http://www.sbs.com.au/news/article/2011/01/27/qa-whats-behind-unrest|title=Q&A: What's Behind the Unrest?|publisher=SBS|date=27 January 2011|accessdate=29 January 2011}} including [[police brutality]], state-of-emergency laws, lack of free elections and [[freedom of speech]], corruption, and economic issues including high unemployment, food-price inflation and low wages. The protesters' primary demands were the end of the Mubarak regime and emergency law, freedom, justice, a responsive non-military government and a voice in managing Egypt's resources.{{cite news|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2011/01/egyptian-activists-action-plan-translated/70388/|title=Egyptian Activists' Action Plan: Translated|work=[[The Atlantic]]|date=27 January 2011}} Strikes by [[Trade unions in Egypt|labour unions]] added to the pressure on government officials.{{cite web|url=http://www.defenddemocracy.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=11792083&Itemid=347 |title=Trade unions: the revolutionary social network at play in Egypt and Tunisia |publisher=Defenddemocracy.org |accessdate=11 February 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110213094954/http://www.defenddemocracy.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=11792083&Itemid=347|archivedate= 13 February 2011|deadurl= no}} During the uprising, the capital [[Cairo]] was described as "a war zone"{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/global/blog/2011/jan/25/middleeast-tunisia#block-32|title=Protests in Egypt and unrest in Middle East – as it happened|date=25 January 2011 |work=The Guardian |location=UK |first1=Haroon |last1=Siddique |first2=Paul |last2=Owen |first3=Adam |last3=Gabbatt |accessdate=26 January 2011 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110126050109/http://www.guardian.co.uk/global/blog/2011/jan/25/middleeast-tunisia|archivedate= 26 January 2011|deadurl= no}} and the port city of [[Suez]] saw frequent violent clashes. Protesters defied a government-imposed [[curfew]], which was impossible to enforce by the police and military. Egypt's [[Central Security Forces]], loyal to Mubarak, were gradually replaced by military troops. In the chaos, there was some [[looting]] by gangs which was instigated (according to opposition sources) by plainclothes police officers. In response, watch groups were organized by civilians to protect neighbourhoods.{{cite news|last=Fleishman|first=Jeffrey and Edmund Sanders (Los Angeles Times)|title=Unease in Egypt as police replaced by army, neighbors band against looters|url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/nationworld/2014078461_egypt30.html |newspaper=The Seattle Times |date=29 January 2011 |accessdate=1 February 2011 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110201071852/http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/nationworld/2014078461_egypt30.html|archivedate= 1 February 2011|deadurl= no}}{{cite news|title=Looting spreads in Egyptian cities|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/2011129175926266521.html |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=29 January 2011 |accessdate=1 February 2011 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110131072424/http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/2011129175926266521.html|archivedate= 31 January 2011|deadurl= no}}{{cite news|last=Hauslohner|first=Abigail|title=The Army's OK with the Protesters, for now|url=http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,2045124,00.html#ixzz1CfroWYuj |newspaper=Time |date=29 January 2011 |accessdate=1 February 2011 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110131222033/http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,2045124,00.html|archivedate= 31 January 2011|deadurl= no}}{{cite news|title=Mubarak plays last card, the army; Police vanish|url=http://www.worldtribune.com/worldtribune/WTARC/2011/me_egypt0078_01_31.asp |newspaper=World Tribune (online) |date=31 January 2011 |accessdate=1 February 2011 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110201231440/http://www.worldtribune.com/worldtribune/WTARC/2011/me_egypt0078_01_31.asp|archivedate= 1 February 2011|deadurl= no}}{{cite news|last=Stirewalt|first=Chris|title=Egypt: From Police State to Military Rule|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2011/01/31/egypt-police-state-military-rule/ |publisher=Fox News Channel |date=31 January 2011 |accessdate=1 February 2011 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110201053106/http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2011/01/31/egypt-police-state-military-rule/|archivedate= 1 February 2011|deadurl= no}} International reaction has varied, with most Western nations condoning peaceful protests but concerned about the stability of Egypt and the region. The Egyptian and Tunisian revolutions have influenced demonstrations in other Arab countries, including [[Yemen]], [[Bahrain]], [[Jordan]], [[Syria]] and [[Libya]]. Mubarak dissolved his government, appointing former head of the [[Egyptian General Intelligence Directorate]] [[Omar Suleiman]] vice-president in an attempt to quell dissent. Mubarak asked aviation minister and former chief of Egypt's air force [[Ahmed Shafik]] (who ran for presidency later) to form a new government. [[Mohamed ElBaradei]] became a major opposition figure, with all major opposition groups supporting his role as negotiator for a transitional unity government.{{cite news|last1=Shadid|first1=Anthony|last2=Kirkpatrick|first2=David D.|title=Opposition Rallies to ElBaradei as Military Reinforces in Cairo|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/31/world/middleeast/31-egypt.html |newspaper=The New York Times |date=30 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110131071532/http://www.nytimes.com//2011//01//31//world//middleeast//31-egypt.html|archivedate= 31 January 2011|deadurl= no}} In response to mounting pressure, Mubarak, in another attempt to contain the crisis, announced he did not intend to seek re-election in September.{{cite news|author1=El Deeb, Sarah |author2=Al-Shalchi, Hadeel |title=Egypt Crowds Unmoved by Mubarak's Vow Not To Run|url=https://news.yahoo.com/egypt-crowds-unmoved-mubaraks-vow-not-run-20110201-211722-054.html|agency=Associated Press|date=1 February 2011}} On 11 February 2011, Vice President Omar Suleiman announced that Mubarak would resign as president, turning power over to the [[Supreme Council of the Armed Forces]] (SCAF).{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121125158705862.html|title=Hosni Mubarak resigns as president|publisher=Al Jazeera|date=11 February 2011}} The military junta, headed by effective head of state [[Mohamed Hussein Tantawi]], announced on 13 February that the constitution would be suspended, both houses of parliament dissolved and the military would rule for six months (until elections could be held). The previous cabinet, including Prime Minister [[Ahmed Shafik]], would serve as a caretaker government until a new one was formed.{{cite news|last=el-Malawani|first=Hania|url=http://news.smh.com.au/breaking-news-world/egypts-military-dismantles-mubarak-regime-20110214-1as8u.html|title=Egypt's military dismantles Mubarak regime|date=13 February 2011|work=The Sydney Morning Herald}} Shafik, seen by the masses as another Mubarak figure, resigned on 3 March, a day before major protests to force him to step down were planned, and was replaced by former transport minister [[Essam Sharaf]].{{cite web|url=http://www.forexyard.com/en/news/Egypts-prime-minsiter-quits-new-govt-soon-army-2011-03-03T093300Z |title=Egypt's prime minister quits, new govt soon-army |publisher=Forexyard.com |accessdate=5 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110501033518/http://www.forexyard.com/en/news/Egypts-prime-minsiter-quits-new-govt-soon-army-2011-03-03T093300Z |archivedate=1 May 2011 |df=dmy }} On 24 May 2011, Mubarak was ordered to stand trial on charges of [[premeditated murder]] of peaceful protesters and, if convicted, could have faced the death penalty. On 2 June 2012, Mubarak was found guilty of complicity in the murder of protesters and sentenced to life imprisonment, but the sentence was overturned on appeal and a retrial ordered.{{cite news|url= http://www.3news.co.nz/Egypts-Mubarak-to-get-retrial/tabid/417/articleID/282900/Default.aspx|publisher=3 News NZ |title= Egypt's Mubarak to get retrial|date=14 January 2013}} A number of protesters, upset that others tried with Mubarak (including his two sons) were acquitted, took to the streets.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-18306126 |publisher=BBC News |title=Mubarak jailed for protest deaths|date=30 September 2012|accessdate=2 June 2012}} Mubarak was eventually cleared of all charges on 29 November 2014,{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2014/11/29/world/meast/egypt-mubarak-trial/|title=Egypt: Ex-ruler Hosni Mubarak, accused in deaths of hundreds, cleared of charges|agency=CNN|date=29 November 2014|accessdate=9 January 2015}} although Egypt's prosecutor general announced he would appeal the verdict.{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2014/12/egypt-prosecutor-appeal-mubarak-acquittal-2014122124953825532.html|agency=Al Jazeera|title=Egypt prosecutor to appeal Mubarak acquittal|date=2 December 2014|accessdate=9 January 2015}} After the revolution against Mubarak and a period of rule by the [[Supreme Council of the Armed Forces]], the [[Muslim Brotherhood]] took power in Egypt through a series of popular elections, with Egyptians electing Islamist [[Mohamed Morsi]] to the presidency in June 2012.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/jun/24/muslim-brotherhood-egypt-president-mohamed-morsi|newspaper=The Guardian|title=Muslim Brotherhood's Mohamed Morsi declared president of Egypt|date=24 June 2012|accessdate=9 January 2015}} However, Morsi's government encountered fierce opposition after his attempt to pass an Islamic-leaning constitution. Morsi also issued a temporary presidential decree that raised his decisions over judicial review to enable the passing of the constitution.{{cite web|last1=Kirkpatrick|first1=David D.|last2=Sheikh|first2=Mayy El|title=President Morsi in Egypt Seizes New Powers|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/11/23/world/middleeast/egypts-president-morsi-gives-himself-new-powers.html|website=The New York Times|accessdate=9 May 2018|date=22 November 2012}} It sparked general outrage from secularists and members of the military, and [[June 2013 Egyptian protests|mass protests]] broke out against his rule on 28 June 2013.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/photo/2013/07/millions-march-in-egyptian-protests/100543/|title=Millions March in Egyptian Protests|last=Taylor|first=Alan|work=The Atlantic|access-date=2017-05-02|language=en-US}} On 3 July 2013, Morsi was deposed by a [[2013 Egyptian coup d'état|coup d'état]] led by the minister of defense, [[Abdel Fattah el-Sisi|General Abdel Fattah El-Sisi]]{{cite news|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/world/morsi-ousted-under-house-arrest-crowds-celebrate-cairo-v19261466|agency=NBC News|title=Morsi ousted, under house arrest, as crowds celebrate in Cairo|date=3 July 2013|accessdate=9 January 2015}} as millions of Egyptians took to the streets in support of early elections.{{Cite news|url=http://www.takepart.com/feature/2014/02/06/egypt-revolution-timeline|title=The Simplest Explanation of Egypt's Revolution You'll Ever Read|work=TakePart|access-date=2017-05-02|language=en}} [[Abdel Fattah el-Sisi|El-Sisi]] went on to become Egypt's president by popular [[Egyptian presidential election, 2014|election in 2014]].{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2014/05/sisi-wins-egypt-elections-landslide-2014529134910264238.html|agency=Al Jazeera|title=Sisi elected Egypt president by landslide|date=30 May 2014|accessdate=9 January 2015}} == {{anchor|Naming}}Other names == In Egypt and other parts of the Arab world, the protests and governmental changes are also known as the {{Em|25 January Revolution}} ({{lang|ar|ثورة 25 يناير}} ''Thawrat 25 Yanāyir''), {{Em|Freedom Revolution}} ({{lang|ar|ثورة حرية}} ''Thawrat Horeya''){{cite web|url=http://aglobalrevolution.wordpress.com/2011/02/05/egypt-the-bread-and-freedom-revolution/ |title=Egypt: The Bread and Freedom Revolution |A Global Revolution |publisher=Aglobalrevolution.wordpress.com |date=2011-02-05 |accessdate=2013-03-25}} or {{Em|Rage Revolution}} ({{lang|ar|ثورة الغضب}} ''Thawrat al-Ġaḍab''), and (less frequently){{cite news |newspaper=[[Al-Ahram Weekly]] |title=The 25 January Revolution (Special issue) |date=10–16 February 2011 |url=http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2011/1034/special.htm |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110213051549/http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2011/1034/special.htm |archivedate=13 February 2011 |df=dmy }} the {{Em|Youth Revolution}} ({{lang|ar|ثورة الشباب}} ''Thawrat al-Shabāb''), {{Em|[[Nelumbo|Lotus]] Revolution}}{{cite news |url=http://articles.cnn.com/2011-01-28/world/egypt.press.club_1_saad-eddin-ibrahim-egyptian-american-egyptian-people?_s=PM:WORLD |title=Egyptian-American leaders call for U.S. support of 'Lotus Revolution' – CNN |publisher=CNN |date=28 January 2011 |accessdate=21 March 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110314141657/http://articles.cnn.com/2011-01-28/world/egypt.press.club_1_saad-eddin-ibrahim-egyptian-american-egyptian-people?_s=PM%3AWORLD |archivedate=14 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} ({{lang|ar|ثورة اللوتس}}) or {{Em|White Revolution}} ({{lang|ar|الثورة البيضاء}} ''al-Thawrah al-bayḍāʾ'').{{cite web |url=http://www.gulf-daily-news.com/NewsDetails.aspx?storyid=299386 |title=Business News » Investors See White Revolution in Egypt |publisher=3 News NZ |date=13 February 2011 |accessdate=21 March 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110430185548/http://www.gulf-daily-news.com/NewsDetails.aspx?storyid=299386 |archivedate=30 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} == Background == [[File:Hosni Mubarak ritratto.jpg|thumb|upright|alt=Smiling man in suit and tie|[[Hosni Mubarak]] in 2009]] [[Hosni Mubarak]] became [[President of Egypt]] after the [[assassination of Anwar Sadat]] in 1981. Mubarak's [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|National Democratic Party (NDS)]] maintained one-party rule under a continual state of emergency.{{cite news|url=http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/m/hosni_mubarak/index.html|title=Hosni Mubarak|work=The New York Times |date=8 March 2010 |first=Michael |last=Slackman |accessdate=25 January 2011 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110131071410/http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/m/hosni_mubarak/index.html|archivedate= 31 January 2011|deadurl= no}} His government received support from the West and aid from the United States by its suppression of [[Islamic militants]] and peace with [[Israel]]. Mubarak was often compared to an Egyptian [[pharaoh]] by the media and some critics, due to his authoritarian rule.{{cite web|url=http://archive.indianexpress.com/news/history-s-crossroads/748326 |title=History's crossroads |work=The Indian Express |location=India |accessdate=10 February 2011}} He was in the 30th year of his reign when the Revolution of 2011 began.{{cite web|url=http://documentarystorm.com/politics/a-nation-in-waiting/|title=Egypt: A Nation in Waiting|accessdate=15 February 2011}} === Inheritance of power === [[File:Gamal Mubarak.jpg|thumb|upright|alt=Man talking into a microphone at the World Economic Forum|[[Gamal Mubarak]] in 2006]] {{main article|Gamal Mubarak}} Mubarak's younger son, was expected to succeed his father as the next president of Egypt in 2000.Aziz, Muhammad Abdul and Hussein, Youssef (2002) "The President, the Son, and the Military: Succession in Egypt" ''Arab Studies Journal'' 9/10: pp. 73–88 Gamal began receiving attention from the Egyptian media, since there were apparently no other heirs to the presidency.Bee, Jason (2008) [https://web.archive.org/web/20110513071650/https://webspace.utexas.edu/jmb334/www/documents/article.ASJ.2008.pdf "The Heir Apparency of Gamal Mubarak"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120404150833/https://webspace.utexas.edu/jmb334/www/documents/article.ASJ.2008.pdf |date=4 April 2012 }} ''Arab Studies Journal'' pp. 36–56 [[Bashar al-Assad]]'s rise to power in [[Syria]] in June 2000, hours after [[Hafez al-Assad]]'s death, sparked debate in the Egyptian press about the prospects for a similar scenario in Cairo.Sobelman, Daniel (2001) [http://www.meforum.org/27/gamal-mubarak-president-of-egypt "Gamal Mubarak, President of Egypt?"] ''Middle East Quarterly'' 8(2): pp. 31–40 During the years after [[Egyptian presidential election, 2005|Mubarak's 2005 re-election]], several left- and right-wing (primarily unofficial) political groups expressed opposition to the inheritance of power, demanded reforms and asked for a multi-candidate election. In 2006, with opposition increasing, ''[[Daily News Egypt]]'' reported an online campaign initiative (the National Initiative against Power Inheritance) demanding that Gamal reduce his power. The campaign said, "President Mubarak and his son constantly denied even the possibility of [succession]. However, in reality they did the opposite, including amending the constitution to make sure that Gamal will be the only unchallenged candidate."{{cite web |url=http://www.thedailynewsegypt.com/egyptians-abroad-speak-out-against-inheritance-of-power.html |title=Egyptians abroad speak out against inheritance of power |date=3 October 2006 |author=Al-A'sar, Marwa |accessdate=16 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110513151746/http://www.thedailynewsegypt.com/egyptians-abroad-speak-out-against-inheritance-of-power.html|archivedate=13 May 2011|deadurl=no}} During the decade, public perception grew that Gamal would succeed his father. He wielded increasing power as NDP deputy secretary general and chair of the party's policy committee. Analysts described Mubarak's last decade in power as "the age of Gamal Mubarak". With his father's health declining and no appointed vice-president, Gamal was considered Egypt's ''de facto'' president by some.{{cite web |url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/9988/Egypt/Politics-/How-Gamal-brought-down-the-whole-Mubarak-house.aspx |title=How Gamal brought down the whole Mubarak house |publisher=Middle East Online |date=15 April 2011 |author=Gamal Essam El-Din |accessdate=16 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110430024600/http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/9988/Egypt/Politics-/How-Gamal-brought-down-the-whole-Mubarak-house.aspx|archivedate=30 April 2011|deadurl=no}} Although Gamal and Hosni Mubarak denied an inheritance of power, Gamal could be elected; with Hosni Mubarak's presidential term set to expire in 2010, speculation existed that Gamal would run as the NDP candidate in 2011.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/09/20/world/africa/20egypt.html |title=Mubarak's Son Proposes Nuclear Program |work=The New York Times |date=20 September 2006 |author1=Michael Slackman |author2=Mona el-Naggar |accessdate=16 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110501005025/http://www.nytimes.com/2006/09/20/world/africa/20egypt.html|archivedate=1 May 2011|deadurl=no}} However, after the January–February 2011 protest Gamal Mubarak said that he would not run for president in the 2011 elections.{{cite news|last=BBC|title=Egypt unrest: Anti-Mubarak protesters fight back|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12357891|newspaper=British Broadcasting Company|date=3 February 2011}} === Emergency law === {{main article|Emergency law in Egypt}} [[Emergency law in Egypt|Emergency law]] (Law No. 162 of 1958) was enacted in the country after the 1967 [[Six-Day War]]. Although it was suspended for 18 months during the early 1980s,{{cite web|url=http://www.emerglobal.com/lex/law-1958-162|title=Law 1958/162 (Emergency Law)|work=Edinburgh Middle East Report|accessdate=2 April 2010}}{{registration required}} it has otherwise continuously been in effect since [[Anwar Sadat]]'s 1981 assassination.{{cite web|last=Egyptian Organisation for Human Rights|title=Egypt and The Impact of 27 years of Emergency on Human Rights|url=http://en.eohr.org/2008/05/28/%E2%80%9Cegypt-and-the-impact-of-27-years-of-emergency-on-human-rights%E2%80%9D/#more-22|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110129202417/http://en.eohr.org/2008/05/28/%E2%80%9Cegypt-and-the-impact-of-27-years-of-emergency-on-human-rights%E2%80%9D/#more-22|archivedate=29 January 2011 |date=28 May 2008 |accessdate=29 January 2011}} Emergency law extended police powers, suspended [[Constitution of Egypt|constitutional rights]], legalised censorship{{cite web|url=http://conconflicts.ssrc.org/mideast/shehata/|title=Egypt After 9/11: Perceptions of the United States|date=26 March 2004 |last=Shehata |first=Samer |work=Contemporary Conflicts |accessdate=30 January 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060715211012/http://conconflicts.ssrc.org/mideast/shehata/ |archivedate=15 July 2006 |deadurl=no}} and abolished ''[[habeas corpus]]''. It limits non-governmental political activity, including [[Demonstration (people)|demonstrations]], unapproved political organizations and unregistered financial donations. The Mubarak government has cited the threat of terrorism in extending emergency law, claiming that opposition groups such as the [[Muslim Brotherhood in Egypt|Muslim Brotherhood]] could gain power in Egypt if the government did not forgo [[parliamentary elections]] and suppress the group through emergency law.{{cite book|last=Caraley|first=Demetrios|title=American Hegemony: Preventive War, Iraq, and Imposing Democracy|publisher=[[Academy of Political Science]]|date=April 2004|isbn=1-884853-04-8}} This has led to the imprisonment of activists without trial,{{cite web|author=Choney, Suzanne|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/41285248/ns/technology_and_science-tech_and_gadgets/|title=Egyptian bloggers brave police intimidation |date=27 January 2011 |publisher=[[MSNBC]] |accessdate=28 January 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110201041252/http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/41285248/ns/technology_and_science-tech_and_gadgets/|archivedate=1 February 2011|deadurl=no}} illegal, undocumented and hidden detention facilities{{cite web|url=http://www.newyorker.com/archive/2006/10/30/061030ta_talk_mayer|title=The C.I.A.'s Travel Agent|date=30 October 2006 |work=The New Yorker |author=Mayer, Jane |accessdate=28 January 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101229205146/http://www.newyorker.com/archive/2006/10/30/061030ta_talk_mayer|archivedate=29 December 2010|deadurl=no}} and the rejection of university, mosque and newspaper staff based on their political affiliation.{{cite news|author=Shenker, Jack|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/nov/22/egypt-elections-muslim-brotherhood-ndp|title=Egyptian Elections: Independents Fight for Hearts and Minds in 'Fixed Ballot'|work=The Guardian |location=UK |date=22 November 2010|accessdate=28 January 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110128071057/http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2010/nov/22/egypt-elections-muslim-brotherhood-ndp|archivedate=28 January 2011|deadurl=no}} A [[Egyptian parliamentary election, 2010|December 2010 parliamentary election]] was preceded by a media crackdown, arrests, candidate bans (particularly Muslim Brotherhood candidates) and allegations of fraud due to the near-unanimous victory by the NDP in parliament. Human-rights organizations estimate that in 2010, between 5,000 and 10,000 people were in long-term detention without charge or trial.{{cite press release|publisher=[[Amnesty International]]|title=Egypt: Keep Promise to Free Detainees by End of June: Joint Statement|url=https://www.amnesty.org/en/library/info/MDE12/027/2010/en|date=29 June 2010|accessdate=4 February 2011}}{{cite web|author=Holder, R. Clemente|url=http://www.wrmea.org/wrmea-archives/156-washington-report-archives-1994-1999/july-august-1994/7540-human-rights.html|title=Egyptian Lawyer's Death Triggers Cairo Protests|work=[[Washington Report on Middle East Affairs]]|date=July–August 1994|accessdate=31 January 2011}} === Police brutality === {{further|Law enforcement in Egypt}} According to a U.S. Embassy report, police brutality has been widespread in Egypt.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/jan/28/egypt-police-brutality-torture-wikileaks|title=US reported 'routine' police brutality in Egypt, WikiLeaks cables show|last=Harding|first=Luke|date=28 January 2011|work=The Guardian |location=UK |accessdate=20 April 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110504022032/http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jan/28/egypt-police-brutality-torture-wikileaks|archivedate=4 May 2011|deadurl=no}} In the five years before the revolution, the Mubarak regime denied the existence of torture or abuse by police. However, claims by domestic and international groups provided cellphone videos or first-hand accounts of hundreds of cases of police brutality.{{cite news|last=U.S. Embassy in Cairo|title=US embassy cables: Police brutality in Egypt|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/us-embassy-cables-documents/187359|newspaper=The Guardian|date=28 January 2011|location=London}} According to the 2009 Human Rights Report from the U.S. State Department, "Domestic and international human rights groups reported that the Ministry of Interior (MOI) State Security Investigative Service (SSIS), police, and other government entities continued to employ torture to extract information or force confessions. The Egyptian Organization for Human Rights documented 30 cases of torture during the year 2009. In numerous trials defendants alleged that police tortured them during questioning. During the year activists and observers circulated some amateur cellphone videos documenting the alleged abuse of citizens by security officials. For example, on 8 February, a blogger posted a video of two police officers, identified by their first names and last initials, sodomizing a bound naked man named Ahmed Abdel Fattah Ali with a bottle. On 12 August, the same blogger posted two videos of alleged police torture of a man in a Port Said police station by the head of investigations, Mohammed Abu Ghazala. There was no indication that the government investigated either case."{{cite web|last=U.S. Department of State|title=2009 Human Rights Report: Egypt|url=https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2009/nea/136067.htm#|accessdate=11 March 2010|archiveurl=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20100407154846/http%3A//www%2Estate%2Egov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2009/nea/136067%2Ehtm |archivedate= 7 April 2010 |deadurl=no}} The deployment of [[Baltagiya|Baltageya]] ({{lang-ar|بلطجية}})—plainclothes police—by the NDP has been a hallmark of the Mubarak government.{{cite news|author1=Kirkpatrick, David |author2=Fahim, Kareem |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/26/world/middleeast/26egypt.html|title=Gunfire Rings Out as Protesters Clash|work=The New York Times |date=3 February 2011|accessdate=3 February 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110203074307/http://www.nytimes.com//2011//01//26//world//middleeast//26egypt.html |archivedate=3 February 2011 |deadurl=no}} The [[Egyptian Organisation for Human Rights]] has documented 567 cases of torture, including 167 deaths, by police from 1993 to 2007.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/6943704.stm|title=Egyptian Police Sued for Boy's Death|publisher=BBC News |date=13 August 2007|accessdate=4 February 2011}} Excessive force was often used by law-enforcement agencies against popular uprisings.{{cite news|url=http://www.inwent.org/ez/articles/192821/index.en.shtml |title=Arab countries' secret police forces have a reputation for torture and arbitrary arrests |publisher=D+C 2011/03 – International Journal |date=March 2011 |accessdate=16 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110221070951/http://www.inwent.org/ez/articles/192821/index.en.shtml |archivedate=21 February 2011 }} On 6 June 2010 [[Death of Khaled Mohamed Saeed|Khaled Mohamed Saeed died under disputed circumstances]] in the [[Sidi Gaber]] area of [[Alexandria]], with witnesses testifying that he was beaten to death by police - an event which galvanized Egyptians around the issue of police brutality.{{cite web|url=http://www.irinnews.org/report/94505/egypt-police-brutality-focuses-minds|title=EGYPT: Police brutality focuses minds |newspaper=Gulf Daily News |accessdate=25 June 2015}}{{cite news|author=Khalil, Ashraf |url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/51909 |title=Anger in Alexandria: 'We're Afraid of Our Own Government' |work=Egypt Independent |date=25 June 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110427172608/http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/51909 |archivedate=27 April 2011 }}{{cite news|title=Two Witnesses Affirm Alexandria Victim Beaten by Police|url=http://www.egyptindependent.com/news/two-witnesses-affirm-alex-victim-beaten-police|work=[[Almasry Alyoum]]|date=19 June 2010|accessdate=26 January 2011}} Authorities stated that Khaled died choking on [[hashish]] while being chased by police officers. However, pictures of Khaled's disfigured corpse from the morgue showed signs of torture.{{citation needed|date=November 2018}} A Facebook page, "We are all Khaled Said", helped attract nationwide attention to the case.{{cite news|last=Levinson |first=Charles |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703445904576118502819408990 |title=How Cairo, U.S. Were Blindsided by Revolution |work=The Wall Street Journal |date=2 February 2011|accessdate=2 February 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110202072207/http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748703445904576118502819408990.html|archivedate=2 February 2011|deadurl=no}} [[Mohamed ElBaradei]], former head of the [[International Atomic Energy Agency]], led a 2010 rally in Alexandria against police abuse, and visited Saeed's family to offer condolences.{{cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2010/06/201062642955204618.html|title=ElBaradei Leads Anti-Torture Rally|publisher=Al Jazeera|date=26 June 2010|accessdate=13 July 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100702192522/http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2010/06/201062642955204618.html|archivedate=2 July 2010|deadurl=no}} During the January–February 2011 protests, police brutality was common. Jack Shenker, a reporter for ''[[The Guardian]]'', was arrested during the Cairo protests on 26 January. He witnessed fellow Egyptian protesters being tortured, assaulted, and taken to undisclosed locations by police officers. Shenker and other detainees were released after covert intervention by [[Ayman Nour]], the father of a fellow detainee.{{cite news|last=Shenker|first=Jack|title=Bloody and Bruised: The Journalist Caught in Egypt Unrest|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/jan/27/egypt-riot-security-force-action|newspaper=The Guardian|date=27 January 2011|location=London}}{{cite news|last=BBC|title=Profile: Ayman Nour|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/4558054.stm|newspaper=British Broadcasting Company|date=24 December 2005}}{{cite news|title=Profile of Ayman Nour|url=http://egyptelections.carnegieendowment.org/2010/09/09/profile-of-ayman-nour|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110201013744/http://egyptelections.carnegieendowment.org/2010/09/09/profile-of-ayman-nour|dead-url=yes|archive-date=1 February 2011|newspaper=Carnegie Endowment for International Peace|date=9 September 2009}} === {{anchor|Corruption in government elections}}Election corruption === Corruption, coercion not to vote and manipulation of election results occurred during many elections over Mubarak's 30-year rule.{{cite news|last=U.S. Department of State, Embassy of Egypt|title=Subject: Struggling to Address Police Brutality|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/us-embassy-cables-documents/187359|location=London |work=The Guardian |date=28 January 2011}} Until 2005, Mubarak was the only presidential candidate (with a yes-or-no vote).{{cite news|last=Democracy Reporting International and Egyptian Organization for Human Rights |title=Final Report: Assessment of the Electoral Framework in the Arab Republic of Egypt |url=http://www.democracy-reporting.org/files/dri_egypt.pdf |year=2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304072714/http://www.democracy-reporting.org/files/dri_egypt.pdf |archivedate=4 March 2016 |df=dmy }} Mubarak won five consecutive presidential elections with a sweeping majority. Although opposition groups and international election-monitoring agencies charged that the elections were rigged, those agencies were not allowed to monitor elections. The only opposition presidential candidate in recent Egyptian history, Ayman Nour, was imprisoned before the 2005 elections.{{cite news|last=Sharp|first=Jeremy|title=Egypt: Background and U.S. Relations|url=https://fas.org/sgp/crs/mideast/RL33003.pdf|publisher=Congressional Research Service|year=2009}} According to a 2007 UN survey, voter turnout was extremely low (about 25 percent) because of a lack of trust in the political system. === Demographic and economic challenges === ==== Unemployment and reliance on subsidized goods ==== {{further|Demographics of Egypt|Demographic trap|Youth bulge}} [[File:Egypt population pyramid 2005.svg|thumb|alt=Pyramid graph, divided by age and gender|Egyptian [[population pyramid]] in 2005; many people age 30 and younger, despite education, have difficulty finding work.]] The population of Egypt grew from 30,083,419 in 1966The British Oxford Economic Atlas of the World, 4th edition. {{ISBN|0-19-894107-2}} to roughly 79,000,000 by 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.msrintranet.capmas.gov.eg/pls/fdl/tst12e?action=&lname= |title=Central Agency for Population Mobilisation and Statistics — Population Clock (July 2008) |publisher=Msrintranet.capmas.gov.eg |accessdate=25 August 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100908090727/http://www.msrintranet.capmas.gov.eg/pls/fdl/tst12e?action=&lname= |archivedate=8 September 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} The vast majority of Egyptians live near the banks of the [[Nile]], in an area of about {{convert|40000|km2|sp=us}} where the only [[arable land]] is found. In late 2010, about 40 percent of Egypt's population lived on the equivalent of roughly USD$2 per day, with a large portion relying on subsidized goods. According to the [[Peterson Institute for International Economics]] and other proponents of demographic structural approach ([[cliodynamics]]), a basic problem in Egypt is unemployment driven by a demographic [[youth bulge]]; with the number of new people entering the workforce at about four percent a year, unemployment in Egypt is almost 10 times as high for [[college graduate]]s as for those who finished elementary school (particularly educated urban youth—the people who were in the streets during the revolution).[[Korotayev|Korotayev A.]], Zinkina J. [http://cliodynamics.ru/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=276&Itemid=70 Egyptian Revolution: A Demographic Structural Analysis. ''Entelequia. Revista Interdisciplinar'' 13 (2011): 139–169.]{{cite web|url=http://marketplace.publicradio.org/display/web/2011/02/01/pm-the-long-term-challenges-egypt-must-overcome/ |title=The long-term economic challenges Egypt must overcome |work=[[Marketplace (radio program)|Marketplace]] |date=1 February 2011 |accessdate=1 February 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110204123742/http://marketplace.publicradio.org/display/web/2011/02/01/pm-the-long-term-challenges-egypt-must-overcome/ |archivedate=4 February 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} [[File:Flickr - Daveness 98 - Cityscape in Cairo.jpg|thumb|alt=Tenements with satellite dishes and debris|A poor neighbourhood in Cairo]] ==== {{anchor|Poor living conditions and economic conditions}}Economy and poor living conditions ==== {{further|Economy of Egypt}} Egypt's economy was highly centralised during the presidency of [[Gamal Abdel Nasser]], becoming more [[Market economy|market-driven]] under Anwar Sadat and Mubarak. From 2004 to 2008 the Mubarak government pursued economic reform to attract foreign investment and increase GDP, later postponing further reforms because of the [[Great Recession]]. The international [[economic downturn]] slowed Egypt's GDP growth to 4.5 percent in 2009. In 2010, analysts said that the government of Prime Minister [[Ahmed Nazif]] would need to resume economic reform to attract foreign investment, increase growth and improve economic conditions. Despite recent high national economic growth, living conditions for the average Egyptian remained relatively poor{{cite web|url=http://www.theodora.com/wfbcurrent/egypt/egypt_economy.html|title=Egypt Economy 2011|work=[[CIA World Factbook]] |accessdate=3 March 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110228075759/http://www.theodora.com/wfbcurrent/egypt/egypt_economy.html|archivedate= 28 February 2011|deadurl= no}} (albeit better than other African nations with no significant social upheavals). === {{anchor|Corruption among government officials}}Corruption === {{further|Crime in Egypt}} Political corruption in the Mubarak administration's [[Ministry of Interior (Egypt)|Interior Ministry]] rose dramatically, due to increased control of the system necessary to sustain his presidency.{{cite book|last=Rutherford|first=Bruce|title=Egypt after Mubarak: Liberalism, Islam, and Democracy in the Arab World|publisher=[[Princeton University Press]]|date=November 2008|isbn= 0-691-13665-3}} The rise to power of powerful businessmen in the NDP, the government and the [[House of Representatives (Egypt)|House of Representatives]] led to public anger during the Ahmed Nazif government. [[Ahmed Ezz (businessman)|Ahmed Ezz]] [[Monopoly|monopolised]] the steel industry, with more than 60 percent of market share.{{cite book|title=The Report: Egypt 2007|publisher=Oxford Business Group|date=January 2007|isbn= 1-902339-57-6}} Aladdin Elaasar, an Egyptian biographer and American professor, estimated that the Mubarak family was worth from $50 to $70 billion.{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/aladdin-elaasar/egyptians-rise-against-th_b_815520.html |title=Egyptians Rise Against Their Pharoah |publisher=The Huffington Post |location=USA |last=Elaasar |first=Aladdin |date=28 January 2011 |accessdate=6 February 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110207193214/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/aladdin-elaasar/egyptians-rise-against-th_b_815520.html|archivedate= 7 February 2011|deadurl= no}}{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Business/egypt-mubarak-family-accumulated-wealth-days-military/story?id=12821073&page=2|title=Egypt's Mubarak Likely to Retain Vast Wealth|publisher=[[ABC News]]|accessdate=5 February 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110207193928/http://abcnews.go.com/Business/egypt-mubarak-family-accumulated-wealth-days-military/story?id=12821073&page=2|archivedate= 7 February 2011|deadurl= no}} The wealth of former NDP secretary Ezz was estimated at 18 billion [[Egyptian pound]]s;{{cite web|url=http://www.allheadlinenews.com/briefs/articles/90033584?Obama%20optimistic%20about%20Egypt%20as%20negotiators%20make%20concessions |title=Obama optimistic about Egypt as negotiators make concessions |publisher=AHN |accessdate=9 February 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110426155647/http://www.allheadlinenews.com/briefs/articles/90033584?Obama%20optimistic%20about%20Egypt%20as%20negotiators%20make%20concessions |archivedate=26 April 2011 }} the wealth of former housing minister Ahmed al-Maghraby was estimated at more than 11 billion Egyptian pounds; that of former tourism minister [[Zuhair Garrana]] is estimated at 13 billion Egyptian pounds; former minister of trade and industry Rashid Mohamed Rashid is estimated to be worth 12 billion Egyptian pounds, and former interior minister Habib al-Adly was estimated to be worth eight billion Egyptian pounds. The perception among Egyptians was that the only people benefiting from the nation's wealth were businessmen with ties to the National Democratic Party: "Wealth fuels political power and political power buys wealth."{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/programmes/insidestory/2011/02/201128111236245847.html |title=How did Egypt become so corrupt? – Inside Story |publisher=Al Jazeera |accessdate=9 February 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110209084337/http://english.aljazeera.net/programmes/insidestory/2011/02/201128111236245847.html|archivedate= 9 February 2011|deadurl= no}} During the [[Egyptian parliamentary election, 2010|2010 elections]], opposition groups complained about government harassment and fraud. Opposition and citizen activists called for changes to [[National Association for Change#Platform|a number of legal]] and [[National Association for Change#Goals|constitutional provisions affecting elections]].{{citation needed|date=April 2011}} In 2010, [[Transparency International]]'s [[Corruption Perceptions Index]] (CPI) gave Egypt a score of 3.1 based on perceptions by business people and analysts of the degree of corruption (with 10 being clean, and 0 totally corrupt).{{cite web|url=http://www.transparency.org/policy_research/surveys_indices/cpi/2010/results|title=CPI 2010 table|publisher=[[Transparency International]]|accessdate=26 October 2010|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101027072430/http://www.transparency.org/policy_research/surveys_indices/cpi/2010/results|archivedate= 27 October 2010|deadurl= no}} == {{anchor|Lead-up to the protests}}Prelude == To prepare for the possible overthrow of Mubarak, opposition groups studied [[Gene Sharp]]'s work on nonviolent action and worked with leaders of [[Otpor!]], the student-led [[Serbia]]n [[Overthrow of Slobodan Milošević|organisation]]. Copies of Sharp's list of 198 non-violent "weapons", translated into Arabic and not always attributed to him, were circulated in [[Tahrir Square]] during its occupation.{{cite news |first = David D. |last = Kirkpatrick|author2=David E. Sanger|title = A Tunisian-Egyptian link that shook Arab history|date=13 February 2011|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/14/world/middleeast/14egypt-tunisia-protests.html|work=The New York Times|accessdate=27 February 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110307143444/http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/14/world/middleeast/14egypt-tunisia-protests.html|archivedate=7 March 2011 |deadurl= no}}{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12522848|title=Gene Sharp: Author of the nonviolent revolution rulebook|publisher=BBC News|date=21 February 2011}} ===Tunisian revolution=== {{main article|Tunisian Revolution}} Following the ousting of Tunisian president Zine El Abidine Ben Ali after mass protests, many analysts (including former [[European Commission President]] [[Romano Prodi]]) saw Egypt as the next country where such a revolution might occur.{{cite news|last=Remondini|first=Chiara|title=Prodi Says Egypt to Be Monitored After Tunisia, Messaggero Says|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-16/prodi-says-egypt-to-be-monitored-after-tunisia-messaggero-says.html |publisher=Bloomberg |date=16 January 2011 |accessdate=12 February 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110213095128/http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-16/prodi-says-egypt-to-be-monitored-after-tunisia-messaggero-says.html|archivedate= 13 February 2011|deadurl= no}} According to ''[[The Washington Post]]'', "The Jasmine Revolution [...] should serve as a stark warning to Arab leaders – beginning with Egypt's 83-year-old Hosni Mubarak – that their refusal to allow more economic and political opportunity is dangerous and untenable."{{cite news|title=Tunisia's revolution should be a wake-up call to Mideast autocrats|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/01/15/AR2011011503141.html |newspaper=The Washington Post |date=15 January 2011 |accessdate=11 February 2011}} Others believed that Egypt was not ready for revolution, citing little aspiration by the Egyptian people, low educational levels and a strong government with military support.{{cite news|last=Hauslohner|first=Abigail|title=After Tunisia: Why Egypt Isn't Ready to Have Its Own Revolution|url=http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,2043497,00.html |newspaper=Time |date=20 January 2011 |accessdate=12 February 2011 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110204093004/http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,2043497,00.html|archivedate= 4 February 2011|deadurl= no}} The [[BBC]] said, "The simple fact is that most Egyptians do not see any way that they can change their country or their lives through political action, be it voting, activism, or going out on the streets to demonstrate."{{cite news|last=Leyne|first=Jon|title=No sign Egypt will take the Tunisian road|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12202937 |publisher=BBC |date=17 January 2011 |accessdate=11 February 2011 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110125203342/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12202937|archivedate= 25 January 2011|deadurl= no}} === Self-immolation === [[File:The lion of Egyptian revolution (Qasr al-Nil Bridge)-edit2.jpg|thumb|alt=Man crouched on top of a large stone lion, waving a red, white and blue flag|Protester holds Egyptian flag during protests which began on 25 January 2011.]] After the [[self-immolation]] of [[Mohamed Bouazizi]] in Tunisia on 17 December, a man set himself afire on 18 January in front of the Egyptian parliament{{cite news|last=Zayed|first=Dina|title=Egyptians set themselves ablaze after Tunisia unrest|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/01/18/us-tunisia-egypt-immolation-idUSTRE70H3L720110118 |agency=Reuters |date=16 January 2011 |accessdate=12 February 2011 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110211191739/https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/01/18/us-tunisia-egypt-immolation-idUSTRE70H3L720110118|archivedate= 11 February 2011|deadurl= no}} and five more attempts followed. On 17 January, Abdou Abdel Monaam, a baker, also set himself on fire to protest a law that prevented restaurant owners from buying subsidized bread, leading him to buy bread at the regular price - which is five times higher than the subsidized. Mohammed Farouq Mohammed, who is a lawyer, also set himself afire in front of the parliament to protest his ex-wife, who did not allow him to see his daughters.{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/01/17/AR2011011703381.html|title=2 in Egypt torch themselves; 1 dead|last=Staff|first=By the CNN Wire|date=|work=|access-date=2016-11-19|via=}} In Alexandria, an unemployed man by the name of Ahmed Hashem Sayed was also a victim of self-immolation.{{Cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/01/18/egypt.self.immolation/index.html|title=2 in Egypt torch themselves; 1 dead|last=Staff|first=By the CNN Wire|access-date=2016-11-19}} === National Police Day protests === Opposition groups planned a day of revolt for 25 January, coinciding with [[National Police Day (Egypt)|National Police Day]], to protest police brutality in front of the [[Ministry of Interior (Egypt)|Ministry of Interior]].{{cite news|title=Muslim Brotherhood To Participate in 25 January Protest|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/303296 |work=[[Almasry Alyoum]] |date=23 January 2011 |accessdate=8 April 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110429130029/http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/303296|archivedate= 29 April 2011|deadurl= no}} Protesters also demanded the resignation of the Minister of Interior, an end to State corruption, the end of emergency law and presidential [[term limit]]s for the president. Many political movements, opposition parties and public figures supported the day of revolt, including Youth for Justice and Freedom, the [[Coalition of the Youth of the Revolution]], the Popular Democratic Movement for Change, the [[Revolutionary Socialists]] and the [[National Association for Change]]. The [[April 6 Youth Movement]] was a major supporter of the protest, distributing 20,000 leaflets saying "I will protest on 25 January for my rights". The [[Ghad El-Thawra Party]], [[Dignity Party (Egypt)|Karama]], [[Wafd party|Wafd]] and [[Democratic Front Party|Democratic Front]] supported the protests. The Muslim Brotherhood, Egypt's largest opposition group, confirmed on 23 January that it would participate.{{cite web|url=http://www.alwafd.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=12821&cpage=30|title=بوابة الوفد الالكترونية|publisher=|accessdate=25 June 2015}} Public figures, including novelist [[Alaa Al Aswany]], writer [[Belal Fadl]] and actors [[Amr Waked]] and [[Khaled Aboul Naga]], announced that they would participate. The [[left-wing politics|leftist]] [[National Progressive Unionist Party]] (the ''Tagammu'') said that it would not participate, and the Coptic Church urged Christians not to participate in the protests.{{cite news|last=Afify|first=Heba|title=Activists Hope 25 January Protest Will Be Start of 'Something Big'|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/activists-25-january-protest-be-start-something-big |work=[[Almasry Alyoum]]|date=24 January 2011 |accessdate=14 March 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110228080642/http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/activists-25-january-protest-be-start-something-big |archivedate=28 February 2011 |deadurl= no}} Twenty-six-year-old [[Asmaa Mahfouz]] was instrumentalMekay, Emad (11 February 2011). [http://www.ipsnews.net/2011/02/arab-women-lead-the-charge/ "Arab Women Lead the Charge"]. [[Inter Press Service]]. Retrieved 14 March 2011. in sparking the protests.{{cite report|title = Unveiling the Revolutionaries: Cyberactivism and the Role of Women in the Arab Uprisings |ssrn = 2252556 |date= 17 May 2012}}{{cite news|title = Women Play Vital Role in Egypt's Uprising |url = https://www.npr.org/2011/02/04/133497422/Women-Play-Vital-Role-In-Egypts-Uprising |date=4 February 2011 |work=[[Tell Me More]] |publisher=[[NPR]] |accessdate=14 March 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110205032511/http://www.npr.org/2011/02/04/133497422/Women-Play-Vital-Role-In-Egypts-Uprising|archivedate= 5 February 2011|deadurl= no}} In a video blog posted a week before National Police Day,[http://www.democracynow.org/2011/2/8/asmaa_mahfouz_the_youtube_video_that Asmaa Mahfouz & the YouTube Video that Helped Spark the Egyptian Uprising] [[Democracy Now!]], 8 February 2011. Retrieved 2 March 2012. she urged the Egyptian people to join her on 25 January in Tahrir Square to bring down the Mubarak regime.[https://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/02/world/middleeast/02iht-letter02.html?_r=1]. ''[[The New York Times]]''. Mahfouz's use of [[video blogging]] and [[social media]] went [[Viral video|viral]][[Xeni Jardin|Jardin, Xeni]] (2 February 2011). [http://boingboing.net/2011/02/02/egypt-the-viral-vlog.html "Egypt: The Viral Vlog of Asmaa Mahfouz That Helped Spark an Uprising"]. ''[[Boing Boing]]''. Retrieved 14 March 2011. and urged people not to be afraid.[[Staff writer]] (5 February 2011). [http://www.thecanadiancharger.com/page.php?id=5&a=774 "Asmaaa Mahfouz, a Woman Behind Egypt's Pro-Democracy Revolution"]. ''The Canadian Charger''. Retrieved 14 March 2011. The Facebook group for the event attracted 80,000 people. == {{anchor|Timeline}}(Pre-)revolution timeline == {{refimprove section|date=April 2011}} {{main article|Egyptian Crisis (2011–14)}} === {{anchor|From King Farouk to Mubarak}}Farouk to Mubarak === Most causes of the 2011 Egyptian revolution against Mubarak also existed in 1952, when the [[Free Officers Movement (Egypt)|Free Officers]] ousted [[Farouk of Egypt|King Farouk]]:{{cite book|last=El-Hewie|first=Mohamed F.|title=Chain Reaction: Egypt's Revolt 2011 Illustrated |year=2011|publisher=Shaymaa |isbn=1461093953|pages=1–120}} inherited power, corruption, under-development, unemployment, unfair distribution of wealth and the presence of Israel. A new cause of the Arab Spring is the increase in population, which increased unemployment. The first sign along the road to Mubarak was the 1967 [[Six-Day War|war between Egypt and Israel]]. [[Gamal Abdel Nasser]]'s defeat brought Anwar Sadat to power after Nasser's death in 1970. Sadat undid Nasser's social reforms and dependence on the Soviet Union, predicting its [[Revolutions of 1989|collapse]] nearly two decades before it occurred. Sadat neglected the modernization of Egypt, and his cronyism cost the country infrastructure industries which could generate new jobs. He was succeeded by Hosni Mubarak after Sadat's 1981 death. With no academic or governmental experience, Mubarak implemented emergency rule throughout his 30 years in office, not appointing a vice president until he was pressured to resign. Communications media such as the internet, cell phones and satellite TV channels augmented mosques and Friday prayers, traditional means of mass communications. The mosques brought the Muslim Brotherhood to power, and the Brotherhood has pressured all governments from 1928 through 2011 (as it also does in neighboring countries).{{cite book|last=El-Hewie|first=Mohamed F.|title=A Matter of Faith: The Islamic Spring |year=2013|publisher=Shaymaa|isbn=1481997688|page=162}} === {{anchor|Under Hosni Mubarak's rule}}Under Mubarak === {{main article|Timeline of the Egyptian revolution of 2011}} [[File:Al Jazeera -Footage Of Egyptian protests 2 - 01292011.ogv|thumb|alt=Watchable video|[[Al Jazeera]] footage of Egyptian protests]] [[File:Day of Anger marchers in street.jpg|thumb|alt=Large demonstration, with protesters filling a street|The "Day of Revolt", 25 January]] [[File:Tahrir Square during Friday of Departure.png|thumb|alt=Aerial photo of very large demonstration|Protest in [[Tahrir Square]], 4 February]] [[File:Tahrir Square on February11.png|thumb|alt=Large nighttime demonstration with fireworks|Celebrating the announcement of Hosni Mubarak's resignation in Tahrir Square, 11 February]] {{em|25 January 2011 ("Day of Revolt")}}: Protests erupted throughout Egypt, with tens of thousands gathering in Cairo and thousands more in other Egyptian cities. The protests targeted the Mubarak government; while mostly non-violent, there were some reports of civilian and police casualties. {{em|26 January 2011}}: Civil unrest in Suez and other areas throughout the country. Police arrested many activists. {{em|27 January 2011}}: The government shuts down four major ISPs at approximately 5:20 p.m. EST.{{cite news|last=Singel|first=Ryan|title=Egypt Shut Down Its Net With a Series of Phone Calls|url=https://www.wired.com/threatlevel/2011/01/egypt-isp-shutdown/|work=Wired |date=28 January 2011 |accessdate=30 April 2011}} disrupting Internet traffic and telephone services{{cite web|last=Van Beijnum|first=Iljitsch|title=How Egypt did (and your government could) shut down the Internet|url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/news/2011/01/how-egypt-or-how-your-government-could-shut-down-the-internet.ars|work=Ars Technica|accessdate=30 April 2011}} {{em|28 January 2011}}: The "Friday of Anger" protests began, with hundreds of thousands demonstrating in Cairo and other Egyptian cities after Friday prayers. Opposition leader Mohamed ElBaradei arrived in Cairo amid reports of looting. Prisons were opened and burned down, allegedly on orders from Interior Minister Habib El Adly. Prison inmates escaped ''en masse'', in what was believed to be an attempt to terrorise protesters. Police were withdrawn from the streets, and the military was deployed. International fears of violence grew, but no major casualties were reported. Mubarak made his first address to the nation, pledging to form a new government. Later that night clashes broke out in Tahrir Square between revolutionaries and pro-Mubarak demonstrators, leading to casualties. No fatalities have been reported in Cairo, however, 11 people were killed in Suez and another 170 were injured.1,030 people were reported injured nationwide. {{em|29 January 2011}}: The military presence in Cairo increased. A curfew was imposed, which was widely ignored as the flow of protesters into Tahrir Square continued through the night. The military reportedly refused to follow orders to fire live ammunition, exercising overall restraint; there were no reports of major casualties. On 31 January, Israeli media reported that the 9th, 2nd, and 7th Divisions of the [[Egyptian Army]] had been ordered into Cairo to help restore order.{{cite news |author=Ehud Yaari |url=http://www.mako.co.il/news-specials/egypt/Article-64af2c4c648dd21004.htm |title=צפו: סיור וירטואלי במוקדי המהפכה |language=he |trans-title=Watch: Virtual Tour revolution centers |date=30 January 2011 |publisher=[[Israeli News Company]] |accessdate=2013-08-14}} {{em|1 February 2011}}: Mubarak made another televised address, offering several concessions. He pledged political reforms and said he would not run in the elections planned for September, but would remain in office to oversee a peaceful transition. Small-but-violent clashes began that night between pro- and anti-Mubarak groups. {{em|2 February 2011 (Camel Incident)}}: Violence escalated as waves of Mubarak supporters met anti-government protesters; some Mubarak supporters rode camels and horses into Tahrir Square, reportedly wielding sticks. The attack caused 3 deaths and 600 injuries as a result of the violence.{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/violence-erupts-in-cairo-army-mostly-stands-by/|title=Violence Erupts in Cairo; Army Mostly Stands By|access-date=2016-11-19}} Mubarak repeated his refusal to resign in interviews with several news agencies. Violence toward journalists and reporters escalated, amid speculation that it was encouraged by Mubarak to bring the protests to an end. The camel and horse riders later claimed that they were "good men", and they opposed the protests because they wanted tourists to come back to keep their jobs and feed their animals. The horse and camel riders deny that they were paid by anyone, though they said that they were told about the protests from a ruling party MP. Three hundred people were reported dead by the Human Rights Watch the following day, since January 25.{{Cite book|title=This is what they tell US: The US Printing Press on the 2011 Revolution in Egypt|last=Witzel|first=Annika|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=|quote=|via=}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/egypt/8306223/Egypt-protests-camel-and-horse-riders-who-invaded-Tahrir-Square-say-they-are-good-men.html|title=Egypt protests: camel and horse riders who invaded Tahrir Square say they are 'good men'|newspaper=Telegraph.co.uk|access-date=2016-11-19}} Wael Ghonim, Google executive and creator of the page ''We are all Khaled Said'', was reported missing and the company asked the public to help find him.{{Cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2011/feb/02/business/la-fi-google-missing-exec-20110202|title=Google's Wael Ghonim is missing in Egypt; company asks public for help finding him|last=Guynn|first=Jessica|date=2011-02-02|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035|access-date=2016-11-19}} {{em|6 February 2011}}: An interfaith service was held with [[Copts|Egyptian Christians]] and [[Islam in Egypt|Muslims]] in Tahrir Square. Negotiations by Egyptian Vice President [[Omar Suleiman]] and opposition representatives began during continuing protests throughout the country. The Egyptian army assumed greater security responsibilities, maintaining order and guarding The [[Egyptian Museum|Egyptian Museum of Antiquity]]. Suleiman offered reforms, while others in Mubarak's regime accused foreign nations (including the U.S.) of interfering in Egypt's affairs. {{em|10 February 2011}}: Mubarak addressed the Egyptian people amid speculation of a military coup. Instead of resigning (which was widely expected), he said he would delegate some powers to Vice President Suleiman while remaining Egypt's head of state. Mubarak's statement was met with anger, frustration and disappointment, and in a number of cities there was an escalation in the number and intensity of demonstrations. {{em|11 February 2011 ("Friday of Departure")}}: Large protests continued in many cities, as Egyptians refused to accept Mubarak's concessions. At 6:00 pm Suleiman announced Mubarak's resignation, entrusting the Supreme Council of Egyptian Armed Forces with the leadership of the country.Right after Omar Suleiman had spoken, Mubarak had given an entire speech about his love to the country and his apologies for not being what the citizens expected. It was saddening to many, but at the end it was what the people wanted. Nationwide celebrations immediately followed. == Post-revolution timeline == {{main article|Timeline of the Egyptian Crisis under the Supreme Council of the Armed Forces}} === {{anchor|Under Supreme Council of the Armed Forces}}Under the Supreme Council of the Armed Forces === {{em|13 February 2011}}: The [[Supreme Council of the Armed Forces|Supreme Council]] dissolved Egypt's parliament and suspended the constitution in response to demands by demonstrators. The council declared that it would wield power for six months, or until elections could be held. Calls were made for the council to provide details and more-specific timetables and deadlines. Major protests subsided, but did not end. In a gesture to a new beginning, protesters cleaned up and renovated Tahrir Square (the epicenter of the demonstrations); however, many pledged to continue protesting until all demands had been met. {{em|17 February}}: The army said that it would not field a candidate in the upcoming presidential elections.{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/17/us-egypt-military-idUSTRE71G41U20110217 |title=Egypt army says won't field presidential candidate |publisher=Reuters}} Four important figures in the former regime were arrested that day: former interior minister [[Habib el-Adly]], former minister of housing [[Ahmed Maghrabi]], former tourism minister H.E. [[Zuheir Garana]] and steel tycoon [[Ahmed Ezz (businessman)|Ahmed Ezz]].{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12500968 |title=Egypt after Mubarak: Three ex-ministers arrested |publisher=BBC |date=15 February 2011 |accessdate=20 February 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110218052005/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12500968|archivedate= 18 February 2011|deadurl= no}} {{em|2 March}}: The [[Egyptian constitutional referendum, 2011|constitutional referendum]] was tentatively scheduled for 19 March 2011.{{cite news|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/d67e07da-4420-11e0-931d-00144feab49a.html#axzz1FTmeSur8 |title=Egypt sets constitutional referendum date |work=Financial Times |date=1 March 2011 |accessdate=16 March 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110304030548/http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/d67e07da-4420-11e0-931d-00144feab49a.html|archivedate=4 March 2011 |deadurl= no}} {{em|3 March}}: A day before large protests against him were planned, [[Ahmed Shafik]] stepped down as prime minister and was replaced by [[Essam Sharaf]].{{cite web|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2011/03/03/egypt-government-idINWEB322320110303 |title=Egypt's prime minister quits, new govt soon-army |publisher=Reuters |date=3 March 2011 |accessdate=16 March 2011}} {{em|5 March}}: Several [[State Security Intelligence]] (SSI) buildings across Egypt were raided by protesters, including the headquarters for the [[Alexandria Governorate]] and the national headquarters in [[Nasr City]], Cairo. Protesters said that they raided the buildings to secure documents they believed to proved crimes by the SSI against the people of Egypt during Mubarak's rule.{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/03/201134228359128.html |title=Egypt security building stormed |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=5 March 2011 |accessdate=7 March 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110306142126/http://english.aljazeera.net//news/middleeast/2011/03/201134228359128.html |archivedate=6 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12674714 |title=Egyptians demand secret police give up torture secrets |author=Leithead, Alastair |publisher=BBC News |date=8 March 2011 |accessdate=8 March 2011 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110309054324/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12674714|archivedate= 9 March 2011|deadurl= no}} {{em|6 March}}: From the Nasr City headquarters, protesters acquired evidence of [[mass surveillance]] and vote-rigging, noting rooms full of videotapes, piles of shredded and burned documents and cells in which activists recounted their experiences of detention and torture.{{cite news |url = http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/spotlight/anger-in-egypt/2011/03/2011368410372200.html |title = A first step towards prosecutions? |first = Gregg |last = Carlstrom |date=6 March 2011 |publisher=Al Jazeera}} {{em|19 March}}: The constitutional referendum passed with 77.27 percent of the vote.{{cite web|url=http://referendum.eg/84-slideshow/158-2011-03-20-19-09-58.html |script-title=ar:الأرقام الفعلية للتصويت |publisher=اللجنة القضائية العليا للإشراف علي استفتاء تعديل الدستور المصري |language=Arabic |accessdate=20 March 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110430032815/http://referendum.eg/84-slideshow/158-2011-03-20-19-09-58.html |archivedate=30 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} {{em|22 March}}: Portions of the Interior Ministry building caught fire during police demonstrations outside.{{cite news |url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/03/22/AR2011032202314.html |title=Fire sweeps Egypt's Interior Ministry building as police protest outside to demand higher pay |date=22 March 2011 |newspaper=The Washington Post}} {{em|23 March}}: The [[Cabinet of Egypt|Egyptian Cabinet]] ordered a law criminalising protests and strikes which hamper work at private or public establishments. Under the new law, anyone organising such protests will be subject to imprisonment or a fine of [[Egyptian pound|EGP]]500,000 (about USD$100,000).{{cite news |url = http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/371465 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20111228070645/http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/371465 |archivedate = 2011-12-28 |title=New Egyptian law criminalizes protests |date=23 March 2011 |publisher=Al Masri Al Youm}} {{em|1 April ("Save the Revolution Day")}}: About 4,000 demonstrators filled Tahrir Square for the largest protest in weeks, demanding that the ruling military council more quickly dismantle lingering aspects of the old regime;{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/02/world/middleeast/02egypt.html?_r=1 |title=Protesters Scold Egypt's Military Council |publisher=Neil MacFarquhar |date=1 April 2011 |accessdate=2 April 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20111128102712/http://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/02/world/middleeast/02egypt.html?_r=1|archivedate=28 November 2011 |deadurl= no}} protestors also demanded trials for [[Hosni Mubarak]], [[Gamal Mubarak]], [[Ahmad Fathi Sorour]], [[Safwat El-Sherif]] and [[Zakaria Azmi]]. {{em|8 April ("Cleansing Friday")}}: Tens of thousands of demonstrators again filled Tahrir Square, criticizing the Supreme Council of the Armed Forces for not following through on their demands: the resignation of remaining regime figures and the removal of Egypt's public prosecutor, due to the slow pace of investigations of corrupt former officials.{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/391552 |title=Tens of thousands in Tahrir as some threaten to extend protests | Al-Masry Al-Youm: Today's News from Egypt |publisher=Al-Masry Al-Youm |accessdate=9 April 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110429013554/http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/391552|archivedate= 29 April 2011|deadurl= no}} {{em|7 May}}: The [[2011 Imbaba church attacks|Imbaba church attacks]], in which [[Salafi]] Muslims attacked [[Copts|Coptic]] Christian churches in the working-class neighborhood of [[Imbaba]] in [[Cairo]].{{cite news|title=Egypt Sectarian Clash Leads To Multiple Deaths|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/05/07/egypt-sectarian-clash-multiple-deaths_n_859021.html|agency=Reuters|publisher=The Huffington Post |author=Sami Aboudi |date=7 May 2011 |accessdate=24 June 2012}} {{em|27 May ("Second Friday of Anger", "Second Revolution of Anger" or "The Second Revolution")}}: Tens of thousands of demonstrators filled Tahrir Square,NRC Handelsblad (Dutch), 28 May 2011. in addition to demonstrations in Alexandria, Suez, Ismailia and Gharbeya, in the largest demonstrations since the ouster of the Mubarak regime. Protestors demanded no military trials for civilians, restoration of the Egyptian Constitution before parliament elections and for all members of the old regime (and those who killed protestors in January and February) to stand trial. {{em|1 July ("Friday of Retribution")}}: Thousands of protesters gathered in Suez, Alexandria and Tahrir Square to voice frustration with the ruling Supreme Council of the Armed Forces for what they called the slow pace of change, five months after the revolution, some also feared that the military is to rule Egypt indefinitely.{{cite web|url=http://wireupdate.com/wires/18540/thousands-of-egyptians-protest-against-police-brutality/ |title=Thousands of Egyptians protest against police brutality |publisher=WireUpdate |accessdate=2 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140514130415/http://wireupdate.com/wires/18540/thousands-of-egyptians-protest-against-police-brutality/ |archivedate=14 May 2014 }} {{em|8 July ("Friday of Determination")}}: Hundreds of thousands of protesters gathered in Suez, Alexandria and Tahrir Square, demanding immediate reform and swifter prosecution of former officials from the ousted government.{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/15899/Egypt/Politics-/Hundreds-of-thousands-revitalise-Egypts-revolution.aspx |title=Hundreds of thousands revitalise Egypt'sEgypt's revolution on Determination Friday |publisher=Ahram Online |accessdate=10 July 2011}} {{em|15 July}}: Tahrir Square protests continued. {{em|23 July}}: Thousands of protesters attempted to march to the defense ministry after a speech by Mohammed Tantawi commemorating the [[Egyptian Revolution of 1952]], but are met with counter-insurgents with sticks, stones and Molotov cocktails. {{em|1 August}}: Egyptian soldiers clashed with protesters, tearing down tents. Sixty-six people were arrested, and most Egyptians supported the military's action.{{citation needed|date=December 2012}} {{em|6 August}}: Hundreds of protesters gathered and prayed in Tahrir Square before they were attacked by soldiers.{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/News/18213.aspx|title=Military police's latest Tahrir clampdown reignites popular anger|publisher=english.ahram.org.eg}} {{em|9 September ([[2011 Israeli embassy attack]]; the "Friday of Correcting the Path")}}: Tens of thousands of people protested in Suez, Alexandria and Cairo; however, Islamist protesters were absent. {{em|9 October ([[Maspero demonstrations]])}}:{{cite news|last=Gaber|first=Yassin|title=Reconstructing Maspero's Bloody Sunday: An Ahram Online investigation|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/0/25521/Egypt/0/Reconstructing-Masperos-Bloody-Sunday-An-Ahram-Onl.aspx |publisher=[[Al-Ahram Online]] |date=1 November 2011 |accessdate=10 October 2012}}{{cite news|title=Reconstructing Maspero's Bloody Sunday: An Ahram Online investigation – Part 2|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/0/25708/Egypt/0/Reconstructing-Masperos-Bloody-Sunday-An-Ahram-Onl.aspx |publisher=Ahram Online |date=2 November 2011|author=Nada Hussein Rashwan |accessdate=10 October 2012}} Late in the evening of 9 October, during a protest in the [[Maspiro television building]],{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-15235212 |title=BBC News — Cairo clashes leave 24 dead after Coptic church protest |publisher=BBC |date=9 October 2011 |accessdate=10 October 2011}} peaceful Egyptian protesters calling for the dissolution the Supreme Council of the Armed Forces, the resignation of Chairman Field Marshal Mohamed Tantawi and the dismissal of the governor of Aswan province were attacked by military police. At least 25 people{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/10/10/world/meast/egypt-protest-clashes/index.html?hpt=wo_c2 |title=Death toll rises in Egypt Christian clashes as tension continues — CNN.com |publisher=CNN |date=11 October 2011 |accessdate=10 October 2011}} were killed, and more than 200 wounded. {{em|19 November}}: Clashes erupted as demonstrators reoccupied Tahrir Square. Central Security Forces used [[tear gas]] to control the situation.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/11/22/world/middleeast/facing-calls-to-give-up-power-egypts-military-battles-crowds.html|work=The New York Times|date=21 November 2011 |title=Egypt Clashes Enter 3rd Day as Military Faces Pressure|first=David D.|last=Kirkpatrick |accessdate=21 November 2011}} {{em|20 November}}: Police attempted to forcibly clear the square, but protesters returned in more than double their original numbers. Fighting continued through the night, with police using tear gas, beating and shooting demonstrators. {{em|21 November}}: Demonstrators returned to the square, with [[Coptic Christian]]s standing guard as Muslims protesting the regime pause for prayers. The Health Ministry said that at least 23 died and over 1,500 were injured since 19 November. Solidarity protests were held in [[Alexandria]] and [[Suez]].{{cite news|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/liveblog/egypt-nov-21-2011-1627 |agency=Al Jazeera Blogs |title=Mon, 21 Nov 2011, 13:27 GMT+3 – Egypt |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111226144303/http://blogs.aljazeera.net/liveblog/egypt-nov-21-2011-1627 |archivedate=26 December 2011 |df=dmy }} Dissident journalist [[Hossam el-Hamalawy]] told [[Al Jazeera]] that Egyptians would begin a [[general strike]] because they "had enough" of the SCAF.{{cite news|agency=Al Jazeera Blogs |url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/liveblog/egypt-nov-21-2011-1746 |title=Mon, 21 Nov 2011, 14:46 GMT+3 – Egypt |deadurl=yes [[w:Egyptian parliamentary election, 2011–2012|Parliamentary elections]] {{em|17 December 2011}}: The Institute d'Egypte caught fire during clashes between protesters and Egyptian military; thousands of rare documents burned.{{cite news|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/id/45727231/ns/technology_and_science-science/t/thousands-rare-documents-burned-egypt-clash|agency=Associated Press|title=Thousands of rare documents burned in Egypt clash|date=19 December 2011|accessdate=21 July 2013}} {{em|23 January 2012}}: Democratically elected representatives of the People's Assembly met for the first time since Egypt's revolution, and the Supreme Council of the Armed Forces gave them legislative authority.{{cite The former president, his two sons and a business tycoon were acquitted of corruption charges because the [[statute of limitations]] had expired. Six senior police officials were also acquitted for their role in the killing of demonstrators, due to lack of evidence.{{cite news|last=Kirkpatrick|first=Patrick D.|title=New Turmoil in Egypt Greets
