power|url=http://www.cnn.com/2012/06/14/world/meast/egypt-ruling/index.html|author=Mohamed Fadel Fahmy and Josh Levs|publisher=CNN|accessdate=14 June 2012|date=14 June 2012}} {{em|14 June}}: The Egyptian Supreme Constitutional Court ruled that a law passed by Parliament in May, banning former regime figures from running for office, was unconstitutional; this ended a threat to [[Ahmed Shafik]]'s candidacy for president during [[Egyptian presidential election, 2012|Egypt's 2012 presidential election]]. The court ruled that all articles making up the law regulating the 2011 parliamentary elections were invalid, upholding a lower-court ruling which found that candidates running on party slates were allowed to contest the one-third of parliamentary seats reserved for independents. The Egyptian parliament was dissolved, and the Supreme Council of the Armed Forces resumed legislative authority. The SCAF said that it would announce a 100-person assembly to write the country's new constitution.{{cite news|last=Kirkpatrick|first=David D.|title=New Political Showdown in Egypt as Court Invalidates Parliament|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/15/world/middleeast/new-political-showdown-in-egypt-as-court-invalidates-parliament.html?hp|accessdate=14 June 2012|newspaper=The New York Presidential powers include the power to choose his vice president and cabinet, to propose the state budget and laws and to issue pardons. The interim constitution removed the military and the defense minister from presidential authority and oversight. According to the interim constitution, a permanent constitution must be written within three months and be subject to a referendum 15 days later. When a permanent constitution is approved, a parliamentary election will be held within a month to replace the dissolved parliament.{{cite web|last=Hill|first=Evan|title=Background: SCAF's last-minute President, Says He Wants Unity, Peace |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/06/24/mohammed-morsi-egyptian-president-unity-peace_n_1622751.html |agency=Agence France-Presse (AFP) |accessdate=24 June 2012 |author1=Maggie Michael |author2=Sarah El Deeb |date=24 June 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130620002846/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/06/24/mohammed-morsi-egyptian-president-unity-peace_n_1622751.html |archivedate=20 June 2013 |df=dmy }} {{em|26 June}}: The Supreme Administrative Court revoked Decree No. 4991/2012 from the Minister of Justice, which granted military intelligence and police the power to arrest civilians (a right previously reserved for civilian police officers).{{cite web|title=Egypt Supreme Court blocks arrest powers for military, hailed by experts|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/46250/Egypt/Politics-/Egypt-Supreme-Court-blocks-arrest-powers-for-milit.aspx|publisher=Ahram Online|accessdate=30 June 2012|author=Randa Ali|date=26 June 2012}}{{cite web|title=In Egypt, the Court revoked the right of military arrest civil|url=http://www.news-en.com/2012/06/26/in-egypt-the-court-revoked-the-right-of-military-arrest-civil/|publisher=European news in English|accessdate=30 June 2012|date=26 June 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121029025145/http://www.news-en.com/2012/06/26/in-egypt-the-court-revoked-the-right-of-military-arrest-civil/|archivedate=2012-10-29}}{{cite web|title=Administrative Court Rules in Favor of Appeal Presented by Human Rights NGOs, Revokes Decree Enabling Military Intelligence and Military Police to Arrest Civilians|url=http://nazra.org/en/2012/06/administrative-court-revokes-decree-enabling-military-intelligence-and-military-police|publisher=Nazra for Feminist Studies|accessdate=30 June 2012|date=26 June 2012}}{{cite web|title=Administrative Court Rules in Favor of Appeal Presented by Human Rights NGOs, Revokes Decree Enabling Military Intelligence and Military Police to Arrest Civilians|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201206280306.html|publisher=allAfrica|accessdate=30 June 2012|date=26 June 2012}} {{em|27–28 June}}: After the first [[Constituent Assembly of Egypt]] was declared unconstitutional and dissolved in April by Egypt's Supreme Administrative Court, the second constituent assembly met to establish a framework for drafting a post-Mubarak constitution.{{cite web|title=Egypt's constituent assembly convenes Tuesday with future still in doubt|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/46274/Egypt/Politics-/Egypts-constituent-assembly-convenes-Tuesday-with-.aspx|accessdate=30 June 2012|publisher=Ahram Online|author=Nada Hussein Rashwan|date=27 June 2012}}{{cite web |title=Constituent Assembly carries on |url=http://thedailynewsegypt.com/2012/06/28/constituent-assembly-carries/ |work=Daily News Egypt |accessdate=30 June 2012 |author=Ahmed Aboul Enein |date=28 June 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120702234933/http://thedailynewsegypt.com/2012/06/28/constituent-assembly-carries/ |archivedate=2 July 2012 |df=dmy }} {{em|29 June}}: Mohamed Morsi took a symbolic oath of office in Tahrir Square, affirming that the people are the source of power.{{cite news|title=Egyptian President-elect Mohamed Morsi defiant on eve of taking office|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/middle_east/egyptian-president-elect-mohamed-morsi-defiant-on-eve-of-taking-office/2012/06/29/gJQAFOuECW_story.html|accessdate=30 June 2012|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=29 June 2012|author1=Ernesto Londoño |author2=Haitham Mohamed }}{{cite news|last=Kirkpatrick|first=David D.|title=Morsi Says He Will Work for Release of Sheik Jailed in U.S.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/30/world/middleeast/morsi-promises-to-work-for-release-of-omar-abdel-rahman.html|accessdate=30 June 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|date=29 June 2012}}{{cite web|title=Egypt: Morsi Takes Symbolic Oath in Tahrir Square|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201206291262.html|publisher=allAfrica|accessdate=30 June 2012|author=Aswat Masriya|location=Cairo|date=29 June 2012}} {{em|30 June}}: Morsi was sworn in as Egypt's first democratically-elected president before the Supreme Constitutional Court at the podium used by U.S. President Barack Obama to reach out to the Islamic world in 2009 in his [[A New Beginning]] speech.{{cite news|title=New president: Egypt turns page to new era|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2012/06/30/world/africa/egypt-morsi/index.html |publisher=CNN|accessdate=30 June 2012|date=30 June 2012}}{{cite news|last=Londoño|first=Ernesto|title=Islamist Morsi is sworn in as president of Egypt|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/middle_east/islamist-morsi-is-sworn-in-as-president-of-egypt/2012/06/30/gJQA84vZDW_story.html|accessdate=30 June 2012|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=30 June 2012}}{{cite news|title=Update: Egypt won't reverse says Morsi, vowing to support Palestinians, Syrians |url=http://eg4.me/en/?p=14119 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130502122520/http://eg4.me/en/?p=14119 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2 May 2013 |accessdate=30 June 2012 |newspaper=Egypt News English |date=30 June 2012 }}{{cite news|title=Army hands over power to Egypt's first Islamist president|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/06/30/us-egypt-politics-idUSBRE85S0JP20120630|agency=Reuters|accessdate=30 June 2012|author1=Alistair Lyon |author2=Yasmine Saleh |date=30 June 2012}}{{cite news|last=Kirkpatrick|first=David D.|title=Morsi Is Sworn In, Marking a New Stage in Egypt Struggle|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/07/01/world/middleeast/morsi-is-sworn-in-as-president-of-egypt.html?pagewanted=all|accessdate=30 June 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|date=30 June 2012}} === Under President Mohamed Morsi === For a chronological summary of the major events which took place ''after'' the 2011–2012 Egyptian revolution under President Mohamed Morsi, see [[Timeline of the 2011–2012 Egyptian revolution (Post-revolution timeline)]]. ==== November 2012 declaration ==== {{main article|2012–13 Egyptian protests}} On 22 November 2012, Morsi issued a declaration immunizing his decrees from challenge and attempting to protect the work of the constituent assembly drafting the new constitution.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-20451208 |title=Egypt's President Mursi assumes sweeping powers |publisher=BBC News |date=22 November 2012 |accessdate=23 November 2012}} The declaration required a retrial of those acquitted of killing protesters, and extended the constituent assembly's mandate by two months. The declaration also authorized Morsi to take any measures necessary to protect the revolution. Liberal and secular groups walked out of the constituent assembly because they believed that it would impose strict Islamism, while the Muslim Brotherhood supported Morsi.{{cite news|url=http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/M/ML_EGYPT?SITE=AP&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT&CTIME=2012-11-22-11-27-48 |title=Rallies for, against Egypt president's new powers |work=Associated Press |date=23 November 2012}}{{cite AV media |title=Story of the Egyptian Revolution 2011-2013 |medium=Documentary |language=English, Arabic |url=https://archive.org/details/EgyptRevolution |date=15 November 2013 |minutes=10 |publisher=[[Internet Archive]]}} Morsi's declaration was criticized by Constitution Party leader [[Mohamed ElBaradei]] (who said that he had "usurped all state powers and appointed himself Egypt's new [[pharaoh]]"),{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/ElBaradei/status/271656968341581824 |title = Twitter / ELBaradei |date=22 November 2012 |accessdate=23 November 2012}}{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/egypts-president-morsi-takes-sweeping-new-powers/2012/11/22/8d87d716-34cb-11e2-92f0-496af208bf23_story.html |title=Egypt's President Morsi takes sweeping new powers |newspaper=The Washington Post |date=22 November 2012 |accessdate=23 November 2012 |first=Michael |last=Birnbaum}} and led to violent protests throughout the country.{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/9699801/Violence-breaks-out-across-Egypt-as-protesters-decry-Mohammed-Morsis-constitutional-coup.html|first=Richard|last=Spencer|date=23 November 2012|accessdate=23 November 2012|title=Violence breaks out across Egypt as protesters decry Mohamed Morsi's constitutional 'coup'|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|location=London}} Protesters again erected tents in [[Tahrir Square]], demanding a reversal of the declaration and the dissolving of the constituent assembly. A "huge protest" was planned for Tuesday, 27 November,{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-20474124|title=Egypt activists vow further anti-Mursi protests |publisher=BBC News |date=24 November 2012 |accessdate=23 November 2012}} with clashes reported between protesters and police.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/11/24/world/middleeast/amid-protest-egypts-leader-defends-his-new-powers.html?hp&_r=0 |title=Clashes Break Out After Morsi Seizes New Power in Egypt |work=The New York Times |date=23 November 2012 |accessdate=1 December 2014}} The declaration was also condemned by [[Amnesty International|Amnesty International UK]].{{cite web |url=https://www.amnesty.org.uk/news_details.asp?NewsID=20468 |title=Press Releases |publisher=Amnesty International |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121130114406/http://www.amnesty.org.uk/news_details.asp?NewsID=20468 |archivedate=30 November 2012 |df=dmy }} In April 2013 a youth group was created opposing Morsi and attempting to collect 22 million signatures by 30 June 2013 (the first anniversary of his presidency) on a petition demanding early presidential elections. This triggered the June 2013 protests. Although protests were scheduled for 30 June, opponents began gathering on the 28th.{{cite web|title=Anti-Morsi protesters occupy Tahrir in preparation for 30 June - Daily News Egypt |url=http://www.dailynewsegypt.com/2013/06/28/anti-morsi-protesters-occupy-tahrir-in-preparation-for-30-june/ |work= |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6HtqZlMCI?url=http://www.dailynewsegypt.com/2013/06/28/anti-morsi-protesters-occupy-tahrir-in-preparation-for-30-june/ |archivedate=6 July 2013 |deadurl=no |accessdate=2013-07-03 |df=dmy }} Morsi supporters (primarily from Islamic parties) also protested that day.[http://www.upi.com/Top_News/World-News/2013/06/28/Cairos-Nasr-City-site-of-pro-Morsi-rallies/UPI-92441372420322/ [UPDATE] Morsi supporters rally in Cairo; opponents plan sit-in]. UPI (2013-06-28). Retrieved on 2013-08-14. On 30 June the group organized large protests in Tahrir Square and the presidential palace demanding early presidential elections, which later spread to other [[Governorates of Egypt|governorates]].[http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2013/06/2013627181458885287.html Egypt opposition calls for early elections - Middle East]. Al Jazeera English. Retrieved on 2013-08-14. === June—July 2013 protests and overthrow === {{main article|June 2013 Egyptian protests|2013 Egyptian coup d'état}} [[File:Demonstration in Tahrir Square Against Mubarak - 30Jan2011.webm|thumb| Demonstration in Tahrir Square Against Mubarak - 30Jan2011 ]] On 30 June 2013, marking the one-year anniversary of Morsi's inauguration as president, millions of Egyptians protested against him, demanding he step down from office. Morsi refused to resign. A 48-hour ultimatum was issued to him, demanding that he respond to the demands of the Egyptians,{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2013/07/201371231726346358.html |title=Egyptian army issues 48-hour ultimatum|publisher=Al-Jazeera English |date=July 1, 2013|accessdate=February 4, 2016}} and on 3 July 2013, the President of Egypt was overthrown. Unlike the imposition of [[martial law]] which followed the 2011 resignation of Hosni Mubarak, on 4 July 2013, a civilian senior jurist [[Adly Mansour]] was appointed interim president and was sworn in over the new government following Morsi's removal. Mansour had the right to issue constitutional declarations and vested executive power in the [[Supreme Constitutional Court of Egypt|Supreme Constitutional Court]], giving him executive, judicial and constitutional power.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/07/05/us-egypt-protests-downfall-specialreport-idUSBRE9640SP20130705|title=Special Report: Mursi's downfall|agency=Reuters|date=6 July 2013|accessdate=6 July 2013}} Morsi refused to accept his removal from office, and many supporters vowed to reinstate him. They originally intended their sit-ins to celebrate Morsi's one-year anniversary, but they quickly became opposed to the new authorities.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/07/06/world/middleeast/egypt.html|title=Mayhem in Cairo as Morsi Backers Fight for Return|newspaper=The New York Times|date=6 July 2013|accessdate=6 July 2013|first=Ben|last=Hubbard}} Their sit-ins [[August 2013 Rabaa massacre|were dispersed]] on August 14 that year by security forces, leading to 638 deaths, including 43 police officers.{{Cite news|author=Mohsen, Manar |url=http://www.dailynewsegypt.com/2013/08/16/health-ministry-raises-death-toll-of-wednesdays-clashes-to-638/ |title=Health Ministry raises death toll of Wednesday's clashes to 638 |newspaper=Daily News Egypt |date=16 August 2013 |accessdate=19 August 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Iz4po5fD?url=http://www.dailynewsegypt.com/2013/08/16/health-ministry-raises-death-toll-of-wednesdays-clashes-to-638/ |archivedate=19 August 2013 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} On 18 January 2014, the interim government institutionalised a [[Egyptian Constitution of 2014|new constitution]] following a referendum in which 98.2% of voters were supportive. Participation was low with only 38.6% of registered voters participating{{cite web|title=Egypt constitution 'approved by 98.1 percent'|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2014/01/egypt-constitution-approved-981-percent-201411816326470532.html|publisher=Al Jazeera English|date=18 January 2014|accessdate=18 January 2014}} although this was higher than the 33% who voted in a referendum during Morsi's tenure.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jan/18/egypt-constitution-yes-vote-mohamed-morsi|title=Egypt's new constitution gets 98% 'yes' vote|author=Patrick Kingsley|work=The Guardian|accessdate=25 June 2015}} On 26 March 2014 [[Abdel Fattah el-Sisi]] the head of the [[Egyptian Armed Forces]], who at this time was in control of the country, resigned from the military, announcing he would stand as a candidate in the [[Egyptian presidential election, 2014|2014 presidential election]].{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/97612/Egypt/Politics-/Egypts-ElSisi-bids-military-farewell,-says-he-will.aspx|title=Egypt's El-Sisi bids military farewell, says he will run for presidency|publisher=Ahram Online|date=26 March 2014|accessdate=26 March 2014}} The poll, which had a 47% turnout, and was held between 26 and 28 May 2014, resulted in a resounding victory for el-Sisi.{{cite news|title=Former army chief scores landslide victory in Egypt presidential polls|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/may/29/abdel-fatah-al-sisi-sweeps-victory-egyptian-election|accessdate=29 May 2014|newspaper=The Guardian}} Sisi sworn into office as [[President of Egypt]] on 8 June 2014. == {{anchor|Protests in cities and regions}}Protests by city == [[File:Flickr - Moe- - IMG 0262.jpg|thumb|alt=Seaside demonstration, with protesters wearing red, white and blue|Protesters in Alexandria]] === Cairo === Cairo has been at the epicentre of the revolution; the largest protests were held in downtown Tahrir Square, considered the "protest movement's beating heart and most effective symbol".{{cite web|title=The different shades of Tahrir – Anger in Egypt |publisher=Al Jazeera |accessdate=9 February 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110209051003/http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/spotlight/anger-in-egypt/2011/02/20112811181499676.html |archivedate=9 February 2011 |deadurl=yes |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/spotlight/anger-in-egypt/2011/02/20112811181499676.html |df=dmy }} During the first three days of the protests there were clashes between the central security police and demonstrators, but on 28 January the police withdrew from all of Cairo. Citizens formed neighbourhood-watch groups to maintain order, and widespread looting was reported. Traffic police were reintroduced to Cairo the morning of 31 January.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/01/31/AR2011013102845.html|title=Egypt Unrest and Protests Continue as Police Return to Cairo Streets|work=The Washington Post |accessdate=1 February 2011|date=31 January 2011}} An estimated two million people protested at Tahrir Square.{{Citation needed|date=February 2015}} During the protests, reporters Natasha Smith, [[Lara Logan]] and [[Mona Eltahawy]] were [[Rape in Egypt|sexually assaulted]] while covering the events.{{cite news |title=Student journalist assaulted in Tahrir Square |author=Dan Rivers |url=http://articles.cnn.com/2012-06-27/middleeast/world_meast_egypt-journalist-assaulted_1?_s=PM:MIDDLEEAST |publisher=CNN |date=27 June 2012 |accessdate=2 October 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120806181951/http://articles.cnn.com/2012-06-27/middleeast/world_meast_egypt-journalist-assaulted_1?_s=PM:MIDDLEEAST |archivedate=6 August 2012 |df=dmy-all }}{{cite news |title=Lara Logan breaks her silence on '60 Minutes': 'They raped me with their hands' |author=Melissa Maerz |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/showtracker/2011/05/lara-logan-breaks-her-silence-on-60-minutes-.html |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=2 May 2011 |accessdate=2 October 2012}}{{cite news |title=Journalists sexually assaulted in Cairo protests |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2011-11-25/journalists-sexually-assaulted-in-cairo-protests/3693798 |publisher=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] |date=25 November 2011 |accessdate=2 October 2012}}{{cite news |title=Arrests and Attacks on Women Covering Protests in Cairo |author=Noam Cohen |url=http://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/11/25/arrests-and-attacks-on-women-covering-protests-in-cairo/ |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=25 November 2011 |accessdate=2 October 2012}} === Alexandria === [[Alexandria]], home of [[Death of Khaled Mohamed Saeed|Khaled Saeed]], experienced major protests and clashes with police. There were few confrontations between demonstrators, since there were few Mubarak supporters (except for a few police-escorted convoys). The breakdown of law and order, including the general absence of police from the streets, continued until the evening of 3 February. Alexandria's protests were notable for the joint presence of Christians and Muslims in the events following the [[2011 Alexandria bombing|church bombing]] on 1 January, which sparked protests against the Mubarak regime. === Mansoura === In the northern city of [[Mansoura, Egypt|Mansoura]], there were daily protests against the Mubarak regime beginning on 25 January; two days later, the city was called a "war zone".{{citation needed|date=June 2014}} On 28 January, 13 were reported dead in violent clashes; on 9 February, 18 more protesters died. One protest, on 1 February, had an estimated attendance of one million. The remote city of [[Siwa Oasis|Siwa]] had been relatively calm,{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/02/03/egypt.protests.anxiety/|title=Across dusty Egypt, anxiety has filled the air|last=Sterling|first=Joe|date=4 February 2011|publisher=CNN|accessdate=5 February 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110205143940/http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/02/03/egypt.protests.anxiety/|archivedate= 5 February 2011|deadurl= no}} but local [[sheikhs]] reportedly in control put the community under [[lockdown]] after a nearby town was [[Arson|burned]].{{cite news|url=http://www.stalbansreview.co.uk/news/8823127.Family__cut_off__amid_Egypt_riots/|title=Mother from St. Albans Speaks to the Review from Egypt|last=Mistry|first=Manisha|work=St. Albans Review (part of [[Newsquest]])|date=31 January 2011|accessdate=4 February 2011}} === Suez === [[Suez]] also saw violent protests. Eyewitness reports suggested that the death toll was high, although confirmation was difficult due to a ban on media coverage in the area.{{cite web|last=Tencer|first=Daniel|url=http://www.rawstory.com/rs/2011/01/reports-massacre-suez-protests-egypt/|title=Reports of 'Massacre' in Suez as Protests in Egypt Move into Third day|publisher=[[The Raw Story]]|date=14 January 2011|accessdate=28 January 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110201013406/http://www.rawstory.com/rs/2011/01/reports-massacre-suez-protests-egypt/|archivedate= 1 February 2011|deadurl= no}} Some online activists called Suez Egypt's [[Sidi Bouzid]] (the Tunisian city where protests began).{{cite news|last=Dziadosz|first=Alexander|title=Could Suez be Egypt's Sidi Bouzid?|url=https://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFLDE70Q1KZ20110127|accessdate=29 January 2011|agency=Reuters |date=27 January 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110201013424/https://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFLDE70Q1KZ20110127|archivedate= 1 February 2011|deadurl= no}} On 3 February, 4,000 protesters took to the streets to demand Mubarak's resignation.{{cite news|url=https://af.reuters.com/article/tunisiaNews/idAFLDE71014Z20110203?pageNumber=3&virtualBrandChannel=0 |title=TIMELINE-Protests in Egypt | Reuters |agency=Reuters |date=3 February 2011 |accessdate=13 April 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110426051801/https://af.reuters.com/article/tunisiaNews/idAFLDE71014Z20110203?pageNumber=3&virtualBrandChannel=0|archivedate= 26 April 2011|deadurl= no}} A labour strike took place on 8 February,{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/09/world/middleeast/09egypt.html?_r=1&pagewanted=2 |title=As Egypt Protest Swells, U.S. Sends Specific Demands |work=The New York Times |accessdate=10 February 2011 |first=David D. |last=Kirkpatrick |date=8 February 2011 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20111128102733/http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/09/world/middleeast/09egypt.html?_r=1&pagewanted=2|archivedate=28 November 2011 |deadurl= no}} and large protests were held on 11 February.{{cite news|last = Schemm|first = Paul|last2 = Michael|first2 = Maggie|agency=Associated Press|date=5 February 2011|url = http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/2011/feb/11/mubarak-leaves-cairo-for-sinai-as-protests-spread/|title = Mubarak leaves Cairo for Sinai as protests spread|newspaper=The San Diego Union-Tribune |accessdate=12 February 2011 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110213095008/http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/2011/feb/11/mubarak-leaves-cairo-for-sinai-as-protests-spread/|archivedate= 13 February 2011|deadurl= no}} The MENA news agency reported the death of two protestors and one police officers on January 26.{{Cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/01/25/egypt.protests/|title=3 dead after thousands protest in rare Egypt outpouring|last=CNN|first=From Ben Wedeman and Amir Ahmed,|access-date=2016-11-19}} === Other cities === There were protests in [[Luxor]].{{cite web|url=http://www.fco.gov.uk/en/travel-and-living-abroad/travel-advice-by-country/middle-east-north-africa/egypt/ |title=Egypt Travel Advice |publisher=Fco.gov.uk |accessdate=2 February 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110201231652/http://www.fco.gov.uk/en/travel-and-living-abroad/travel-advice-by-country/middle-east-north-africa/egypt/|archivedate= 1 February 2011|deadurl= no}} On 11 February police opened fire on protesters in [[Dairut]], tens of thousands of protesters took to the streets of [[Shebin el-Kom]], thousands protested in [[El-Arish]] on the Sinai Peninsula, large protests took place in the southern cities of [[Sohag]] and [[Minya, Egypt|Minya]] and nearly 100,000 people protested in and around local-government headquarters in [[Ismaïlia]]. Over 100,000 protesters gathered on 27 January in front of the city council in [[Zagazig]].{{cite web|author=eljazeera77 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hmhCDc0LK68 |title=مظاهرات مدينه الزقازيق محافظه الشرقيه 28 يناير |publisher=YouTube |date=9 February 2011 |accessdate=17 November 2012}} [[Bedouins]] in the [[Sinai Peninsula]] fought security forces for several weeks.{{cite news|newspaper=The New York Times|title=Protests Swell in Rejection of Egypt"s Limited Reforms|date=8 February 2011|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/09/world/middleeast/09egypt.html?pagewanted=2|accessdate=8 February 2011|first=David D.|last=Kirkpatrick|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20111124135046/http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/09/world/middleeast/09egypt.html?pagewanted=2|archivedate=24 November 2011 |deadurl= no}} As a result of the decreased military border presence, Bedouin groups protected the borders and pledged their support of the revolution.{{cite web|url=http://www.arabawy.org/2011/02/16/bedouins/ |title=Sinai Bedouins support the #Jan25 Revolution بدو سيناء يعلنون تأييدهم للثورة المصرية " 3arabawy |publisher=Arabawy.org |accessdate=13 April 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110328234013/http://www.arabawy.org/2011/02/16/bedouins/|archivedate= 28 March 2011|deadurl= no}} However, despite mounting tension among tourists no protests or civil unrest occurred in [[Sharm-El-Sheikh]].{{cite news|author=Stevenson, Rachel|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/jan/31/egypt-sharm-el-sheikh-tourists-tension|title=Sharm El-Sheikh's Tourists Talking About a Revolution|work=The Guardian |location=UK |accessdate=1 February 2011|date=31 January 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110201021401/http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jan/31/egypt-sharm-el-sheikh-tourists-tension|archivedate= 1 February 2011|deadurl= no}} == Deaths == [[File:Martyrs memorial in Tahrir.jpg|thumb|alt=Roped-off rectangle of framed photographs|Tahrir Square memorial made by demonstrators in honour of those who died during the protests, regarded as ''[[Shahid|shuhada']]'' {{lang-ar|شهداء}} (martyrs). The photo captions attribute most of the deaths to police violence.]] [[File:Graffiti at Tahrir square.jpg|thumb|alt=Portraits of people on a wall, below deer-like animals|Graffiti at Tahrir square, commemorating martyrs of the revolution]] Before the protests six cases of [[self-immolation]] were reported, including a man arrested while trying to set himself afire in downtown Cairo.{{cite web|author=Rosenberg, David |url=http://www.themedialine.org/news/news_detail.asp?NewsID=31194 |title=Self-Immolation Spreads Across the Mideast, Inspiring Protest, Controversy |work=The Media Line |date=24 January 2011 |accessdate=25 January 2011 |subscription=yes |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110427032241/http://www.themedialine.org/news/news_detail.asp?NewsID=31194 |archivedate=27 April 2011 }} The cases were inspired by (and began one month after) the acts of self-immolation in Tunisia which triggered the Tunisian revolution. The self-immolators included Abdou Abdel-Moneim Jaafar,{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/7F5D64C8-241F-4F34-B36A-4F259CBF3371.htm?GoogleStatID=20|script-title=ar:مصري يحرق نفسه أمام البرلمان|language=Arabic|publisher=Al Jazeera|date=17 January 2011|accessdate=25 January 2011}} Mohammed Farouk Hassan,{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE70H3L720110118|title=Egyptians Set Themselves Ablaze After Tunisia Unrest|author=Zayed, Dina|date=18 January 2011|agency=Reuters |accessdate=25 January 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110119045756/https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE70H3L720110118|archivedate= 19 January 2011|deadurl= no}} Mohammed Ashour Sorour{{cite web|url=http://www.elosboaonline.com/show.asp?id=20522&vnum=fesal&page=mahalyat |script-title=ar:موظف بـ'مصر للطيران' يهدد بحرق نفسه أمام نقابة الصحفيين |language=Arabic |date=18 January 2011 |work=El-Aosboa (newspaper) |accessdate=25 January 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110421032332/http://www.elosboaonline.com/show.asp?id=20522&vnum=fesal&page=mahalyat |archivedate=21 April 2011 }} and Ahmed Hashim al-Sayyed, who later died from his injuries.{{cite web |url=https://news.yahoo.com/nphotos/slideshow/photo//110118/ids_photos_wl/r3428700330.jpg/ |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5w6N48d3H?url=http://news.yahoo.com/nphotos/slideshow/photo//110118/ids_photos_wl/r3428700330.jpg/ |archivedate=29 January 2011 |title=Mother of Ahmed Hashim al-Sayyed |date=18 January 2011 |work=[[Reuters]] (via ''[[Yahoo! News]]'') |accessdate=2 February 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} As of 30 January, ''Al Jazeera'' reported as many as 150 deaths in the protests.{{cite news |last=Tomasevic |first=Goran |title=Curfew Hours Extended in Egypt as Turmoil Continues |url=http://en.rian.ru/world/20110130/162383449.html |accessdate=31 January 2011 |agency=[[RIA Novosti]] |date=30 January 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110202063803/http://en.rian.ru/world/20110130/162383449.html |archivedate=2 February 2011 |df=dmy }} ''[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]'' reported that the dead included at least ten policemen, three of whom were killed in [[Rafah]] by "an enraged mob".{{cite news|author=Parker, Nick|url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/news/3378537/Troops-battle-rioters-in-Egypt.html?OTC-RSS&ATTR=News|title=Troops Battle Rioters in Egypt|work=The Sun |location=UK |date=29 January 2011|accessdate=30 January 2011}} By 29 January, 2,000 people were confirmed injured.{{cite news|url=https://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFLDE70S0LX20110129|title=Update 1-Death Toll in Egypt's Protests Tops 100 – Sources |agency=Reuters |date=29 January 2009|accessdate=5 February 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110204123844/https://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFLDE70S0LX20110129|archivedate= 4 February 2011|deadurl= no}} That day, an employee of the [[Azerbaijan]]i embassy in Cairo was killed on their way home from work;{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-30/azerbaijani-embassy-worker-shot-dead-in-egypt-ministry-says.html|title=Azerbaijani Embassy Worker Shot Dead in Egypt, Ministry Says|author=Agayev, Zulfugar|work=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]|date=30 January 2011|accessdate=2 February 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110201231917/http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-30/azerbaijani-embassy-worker-shot-dead-in-egypt-ministry-says.html|archivedate= 1 February 2011|deadurl= no}} the following day, Azerbaijan sent a plane to evacuate citizens{{cite web|url=http://en.trend.az/news/politics/1820813.html |title=Ambassador: Embassy will continue providing necessary help to Azerbaijanis in Egypt |publisher=En.trend.az |date=31 January 2011 |accessdate=5 February 2011}} and opened a criminal investigation into the killing.{{cite web|url=http://en.trend.az/news/society/1821118.html|title=Prosecutor General's Office Files Lawsuit on Murder of Accountant of Azerbaijani Embassy in Egypt|date=31 January 2011}} Funerals for those killed during the "Friday of Anger" were held on 30 January. Hundreds of mourners gathered, calling for Mubarak's removal.{{cite web|author=Nolan, Dan|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/video/middleeast/2011/01/2011129171519806580.html|title=Hundreds Mourn the Dead in Egypt|publisher=Al Jazeera|date=29 January 2011|accessdate=2 February 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110201120747/http://english.aljazeera.net/video/middleeast/2011/01/2011129171519806580.html|archivedate= 1 February 2011|deadurl= no}} By 1 February the protests left at least 125 people dead,{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/egypt/8293442/Egypt-crisis-country-braced-for-march-of-a-million.html|title=Egypt Crisis: Country Braced for 'March of a Million' |work=The Daily Telegraph |location=UK |date=31 January 2011|accessdate=2 February 2011 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110201231445/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/egypt/8293442/Egypt-crisis-country-braced-for-march-of-a-million.html|archivedate= 1 February 2011|deadurl= no}} although Human Rights Watch said that UN High Commissioner for Human Rights [[Navi Pillay]] claimed that as many as 300 might have died in the unrest. The unconfirmed tally included 80 Human-Rights-Watch-verified deaths at two Cairo hospitals, 36 in Alexandria and 13 in Suez;{{cite news|author=Carol J. Williams |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/babylonbeyond/2011/02/egypt-rights-advocates-report-protest-death-toll-as-high-as-300.html |title=Egypt: Rights Advocates Report Protest Death Toll as High as 300 |work=Los Angeles Times|date=1 February 2011 |accessdate=2 February 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110201232154/http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/babylonbeyond/2011/02/egypt-rights-advocates-report-protest-death-toll-as-high-as-300.html|archivedate= 1 February 2011|deadurl= no}}{{cite web|url=http://www.allvoices.com/contributed-news/8060066-egypt-unrest-claimed-about-300-lives-un-high-commissioner-for-human-rights-navi-pillay|title=Egypt Unrest Claimed About 300 Lives – UN High Commissioner for Human Rights Navi Pillay|publisher=Allvoices.com|accessdate=1 February 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110201231550/http://www.allvoices.com/contributed-news/8060066-egypt-unrest-claimed-about-300-lives-un-high-commissioner-for-human-rights-navi-pillay|archivedate=1 February 2011|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/international/un-human-rights-chief-300-reported-dead-in-egypt-protests-1.340583?localLinksEnabled=false|title=UN Human Rights Chief: 300 Reported Dead in Egypt Protests|work=[[Haaretz]]|date=1 February 2011 |accessdate=1 February 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110201231910/http://www.haaretz.com/news/international/un-human-rights-chief-300-reported-dead-in-egypt-protests-1.340583?localLinksEnabled=false|archivedate= 1 February 2011|deadurl= no}} over 3,000 people were reported injured. An Egyptian governmental fact-finding commission about the revolution announced on 19 April that at least 846 Egyptians died in the nearly three-week-long uprising.{{cite web|url=http://www.ffnc-eg.org/assets/ffnc-eg_final.pdf|title=Fact-Finding National Commission About 25 Jan Revolution Final Report |date=19 April 2011 |accessdate=19 April 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110421051229/http://www.ffnc-eg.org/assets/ffnc-eg_final.pdf|archivedate= 21 April 2011|deadurl= no}}{{cite news|url=http://hosted2.ap.org/APDEFAULT/*/Article_2011-04-19-ML-Egypt/id-ccead68d1b1749dc9bae6d30db014c6|title=Egypt: At least 846 killed in protests |work=Associated Press |date=19 April 2011 |accessdate=19 April 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/406169|title=At least 846 killed in Egypt's revolution |work=[[Al-Masry Al-Youm]]|date=19 April 2011 |accessdate=19 April 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110429125954/http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/406169|archivedate= 29 April 2011|deadurl= no}} One prominent Egyptian who was killed was [[Emad Effat]], a senior cleric at the [[Dar al-Ifta al-Misriyyah]] school of [[Al-Azhar University]]. He died 16 December 2011, after he was shot in front of the cabinet building.[http://blogs.reuters.com/faithworld/2011/12/18/senior-al-azhar-sheikh-emad-effat-shot-dead-during-cairo-protests/ Senior al-Azhar Sheikh Emad Effat shot dead during Cairo protests] Reuters 18 December 2011 At Effat's funeral the following day, hundreds of mourners chanted "Down with military rule".[http://www.nybooks.com/blogs/nyrblog/2012/jan/04/egypt-mayhem/ Egypt: The Mayhem], Yasmine El Rashidi, ''The New York Review of Books'' == {{anchor|International reactions}}International reaction == {{Main article|International reactions to the Egyptian revolution of 2011}} International response to the protests was initially mixed,{{cite web |url=http://www.eurasiareview.com/world-news/world/regional-reaction-mixed-for-egypt-protests-30012011/ |title=Regional Reaction Mixed For Egypt Protests |work=Eurasia Review |accessdate=19 February 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110222062734/http://www.eurasiareview.com/world-news/world/regional-reaction-mixed-for-egypt-protests-30012011/ |archivedate=22 February 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} although most governments called for peaceful action on both sides and a move towards reform. Most Western nations expressed concern about the situation, and many governments issued travel advisories and attempted to evacuate their citizens from Egypt.{{cite web|url=http://english.peopledaily.com.cn/90001/90777/90854/7277514.html|title=Travel warning issued, evacuation to start as protests continue in Egypt|date=31 January 2011|publisher=English People's Daily Online|accessdate=19 February 2011}} The European Union Foreign Affairs Chief said, "I also reiterate my call upon the Egyptian authorities to urgently establish a constructive and peaceful way to respond to the legitimate aspirations of Egyptian citizens for democratic and socioeconomic reforms."{{cite news|last=Ashton|first=Catherine|title=Factbox: International Reaction to Egyptian Protests|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/01/29/us-egypt-world-idUSTRE70S2B920110129?pageNumber=2|accessdate=9 April 2011|agency=Reuters |date=29 January 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110501063148/https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/01/29/us-egypt-world-idUSTRE70S2B920110129?pageNumber=2|archivedate= 1 May 2011|deadurl= no}} The United States, the United Kingdom, France and Germany issued similar statements calling for reform and an end to violence against peaceful protesters. Many states in the region expressed concern and supported Mubarak; Saudi Arabia issued a statement "strongly condemn[ing]" the protests,{{cite news|title=Egypt Protests Draw Mixed Reaction in Region|url=http://articles.cnn.com/2011-01-29/world/egypt.middle.east.reaction_1_egyptian-people-egyptian-president-hosni-mubarak-populous-arab-nation?_s=PM:WORLD|accessdate=9 April 2011|date=15 February 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110402000717/http://articles.cnn.com/2011-01-29/world/egypt.middle.east.reaction_1_egyptian-people-egyptian-president-hosni-mubarak-populous-arab-nation?_s=PM%3AWORLD|archivedate=2 April 2011|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}} while Tunisia and Iran supported them. Israel was cautious, with [[Prime Minister of Israel|Prime Minister]] [[Benjamin Netanyahu]] asking his government ministers to maintain silence and urging Israel's allies to curb their criticism of President Mubarak;{{cite news|title=Israel's Big Fears over a Post-Mubarak Egypt|url=http://www.euronews.net/2011/01/31/israels-big-fears-over-a-post-mubarak-egypt/|accessdate=31 January 2011|publisher=[[Euronews]]|date=31 January 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110201014913/http://www.euronews.net/2011/01/31/israels-big-fears-over-a-post-mubarak-egypt/|archivedate= 1 February 2011|deadurl= no}}{{cite news|title=Israel Urges World To Curb Criticism of Egypt's Mubarak|url=http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/news/israel-urges-world-to-curb-criticism-of-egypt-s-mubarak-1.340238|accessdate=31 January 2011|work=[[Haaretz]]|date=31 January 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110131193335/http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/news/israel-urges-world-to-curb-criticism-of-egypt-s-mubarak-1.340238|archivedate= 31 January 2011|deadurl= no}} however, an [[Arab-Israeli]] parliamentarian supported the protests. Solidarity demonstrations for the protesters were held worldwide. [[Non-governmental organization]]s expressed concern about the protests and the heavy-handed state response, with [[Amnesty International]] describing attempts to discourage the protests as "unacceptable".{{cite web|last=Trimel|first=Suzanne|title=Amnesty International Rebukes Egyptian Leaders for "Failed" Response to Protest Demands Organization Says Leaders' Efforts to Discourage Protests are "Unacceptable"|url=http://www.amnestyusa.org/document.php?id=ENGUSA20110211001&lang=e&rss=recentnews|accessdate=9 April 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110501085142/http://www.amnestyusa.org/document.php?id=ENGUSA20110211001&lang=e&rss=recentnews|archivedate=1 May 2011|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}} Many countries (including the U.S., Israel, the UK and Japan) issued travel warnings or began evacuating their citizens, and [[multinational corporation]]s began evacuating [[expatriate]] employees.{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/01/30/egypt.evacuations/|title=Foreign governments, businesses begin evacuations from Egypt|publisher=CNN|date=30 January 2011|accessdate=30 January 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110130170918/http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/01/30/egypt.evacuations/|archivedate= 30 January 2011|deadurl= no}} Many university students were also evacuated. === {{anchor|Post-ousting}}Post-ouster === Many nations, leaders and organizations hailed the end of the Mubarak regime, and celebrations were held in Tunisia and Lebanon. World leaders, including German Chancellor [[Angela Merkel]] and UK Prime Minister [[David Cameron]], joined in praising the revolution.{{cite web|last=Baird-Remba|first=Rebecca|title=Mubarak Steps Down: Reactions From Around the World.|url=http://www.allmediany.com/details_news_article.php?news_artid=658|accessdate=9 April 2011}}{{Dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} U.S. President Barack Obama praised the achievement of the Egyptian people and encouraged other activists, saying "Let's look at Egypt's example".{{cite web|last=Obama|first=Barack|title=Follow Egypt's Example, Obama Tells Mideast.|url=http://www.alarabiya.net/articles/2011/02/15/137779.html|accessdate=9 April 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110403114641/http://www.alarabiya.net/articles/2011/02/15/137779.html|archivedate= 3 April 2011|deadurl= no}} Amid growing concern for the country, David Cameron was the first world leader to visit Egypt (10 days after Mubarak's resignation). A news blackout was lifted as the prime minister landed in Cairo for a brief five-hour stopover, hastily added to the beginning of a planned tour of the Middle East.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2011/feb/21/david-cameron-visits-egypt?CMP=twt_fd |title=David Cameron visits Egypt |work=The Guardian |location=London |accessdate=21 February 2011 |first=Nicholas |last=Watt |date=21 February 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110307153510/http://www.guardian.co.uk/politics/2011/feb/21/david-cameron-visits-egypt?CMP=twt_fd|archivedate= 7 March 2011|deadurl= no}} On 15 March, United States Secretary of State Hillary Clinton visited Egypt; she was the highest-ranking U.S. official to visit the country since the handover of power from Mubarak to the military. Clinton urged military leaders to begin the process of a democratic transition, offering support to protesters and reaffirming ties between the two nations.{{cite news|last=Thomson|title=Hillary Clinton Egypt Trip Marks Highest Level Visit Since Mubarak's Ouster|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/03/15/hillary-clinton-egypt-arrives_n_835897.html|accessdate=9 April 2011|publisher=The Huffington Post|date=15 March 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110317093807/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/03/15/hillary-clinton-egypt-arrives_n_835897.html|archivedate= 17 March 2011|deadurl= no}} == Results == {{main article|Domestic responses to the Egyptian revolution of 2011}} On 29 January Mubarak indicated that he would change the government because, despite the crossing of a "point of no return", national stability and [[law and order (politics)|law and order]] must prevail. He asked the government, formed only months ago, to step down and promised that a new government would be formed.{{cite web|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/41318467/|title=Protesters Return to Cairo's Main Square – Egyptian President Fires His Cabinet But Refuses To Step Down|publisher=[[MSNBC]]|date=29 January 2011|accessdate=4 February 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110201041505/http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/41318467/|archivedate= 1 February 2011|deadurl= no}} Mubarak appointed [[Omar Suleiman]], head of Egyptian Intelligence, vice president and [[Ahmed Shafik]] prime minister.{{cite news|last=Slackman|first=Michael|title=Choice of Suleiman Likely to Please the Military, Not the Crowds|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/30/world/middleeast/30suleiman.html?src=twrhp|accessdate=3 February 2011|work=The New York Times|date=29 January 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20121115034154/http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/30/world/middleeast/30suleiman.html?src=twrhp|archivedate=15 November 2012 |deadurl= no}} On 1 February, he said he would stay in office until the next election in September, and then leave. Mubarak promised political reform, but made no offer to resign. The Muslim Brotherhood joined the revolution on 30 January, calling on the military to intervene and all opposition groups to unite against Mubarak. It joined other opposition groups in electing Mohamed el Baradei to lead an interim government.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/blog/2011/jan/30/egypt-protests-live-updates#block-33|title=Egypt protests – as they happened |location=London |work=The Guardian |first1=Matthew|last1=Weaver|first2=Owen|last2=Bowcott|date=30 January 2011}} Many of the [[Al-Azhar Mosque|Al-Azhar]] [[imam]]s joined protesters throughout the country on 30 January.{{cite web|url=http://www.elaph.com/Web/arts/2011/1/628400.html|script-title=ar:خالد الصاوي يقود مظاهرة في ميدان التحرير|language=Arabic|date=30 January 2011|work=[[Elaph]]|accessdate=30 January 2011}} Christian leaders asked their congregations not to participate in the demonstrations, although a number of young Christian activists joined protests led by [[New Wafd Party]] member [[Raymond Lakah]].{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/1049E146-447D-45F9-800E-7F2A064112E1.htm?GoogleStatID=9 |script-title=ar:الكنيسة بمنأى عن مظاهرات مصر |language=Arabic |date=27 January 2011 |publisher=Al Jazeera |accessdate=29 January 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110131142733/http://www.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/1049E146-447D-45F9-800E-7F2A064112E1.htm?GoogleStatID=9 |archivedate=31 January 2011 }} On 31 January, Mubarak swore in his new cabinet in the hope that the unrest would fade. Protesters in [[Tahrir Square]] continued demanding his ouster, since a vice-president and prime minister were already appointed.{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/2011131132324475241.html |title=Mubarak Swears in New Cabinet – Egypt's President Appoints New Cabinet in an Attempt To Quell Ongoing Mass Street Protests Against His Rule |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=31 January 2011 |accessdate=1 February 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110131230817/http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/2011131132324475241.html|archivedate= 31 January 2011|deadurl= no}} He told the new government to preserve subsidies, control inflation and provide more jobs.{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201113101237787481.html |title=Mubarak Orders State Subsidies – Hosni Mubarak Ordered His New PM To Preserve Subsidies, Control Inflation and Provide More Jobs |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=31 January 2011 |accessdate=1 February 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110131220746/http://english.aljazeera.net//news/middleeast/2011/01/201113101237787481.html |archivedate=31 January 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} On 1 February Mubarak said that although his candidacy had been announced by high-ranking members of his National Democratic Party,{{cite web|author=El-Ghatrify, Alaa|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/211975 |title=NDP Official: President To Run for 6th Term; Gamal Mubarak Candidacy 'Delusory' |work=[[Almasry Alyoum]] |date=21 October 2010|accessdate=4 February 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110629044340/http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/211975|archivedate=29 June 2011 |deadurl= no}} he never intended to run for reelection in September.{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121191413252982.html |title=Defiant Mubarak Vows To Finish Term – Violence Erupts in Alexandria Shortly After Egyptian President's Announcement That He Will Not Seek Another Term|publisher=Al Jazeera |date=2 February 2011|accessdate=4 February 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110203102926/http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121191413252982.html|archivedate= 3 February 2011|deadurl= no}} He asked parliament for reforms: {{quote|text=According to my constitutional powers, I call on parliament in both its houses to discuss amending article 76 and 77 of the constitution concerning the conditions on running for presidency of the republic and it sets specific a period for the presidential term. In order for the current parliament in both houses to be able to discuss these constitutional amendments and the legislative amendments linked to it for laws that complement the constitution and to ensure the participation of all the political forces in these discussions, I demand parliament to adhere to the word of the judiciary and its verdicts concerning the latest cases which have been legally challenged.|sign=Hosni Mubarak|source=1 February 2011{{cite news|title=Hosni Mubarak's Speech: Full Text – Egypt President Delivers TV Address to the Nation – and Pledges To Step Down at the Next Election and Pave Way for New Leader|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/feb/02/president-hosni-mubarak-egypt-speech|work=The Guardian |location=UK |date=2 February 2011|accessdate=2 February 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110202074353/http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/02/president-hosni-mubarak-egypt-speech|archivedate= 2 February 2011|deadurl= no}}}} Opposition groups, including the Muslim Brotherhood (MB), repeated their demand that Mubarak resign; after the protests turned violent, the MB said that it was time for military intervention.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12307698 |title=Live: Egypt Unrest |accessdate=29 January 2011 |date=28 January 2011 |publisher=BBC News |archivedate=29 January 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5w5dpTRTE?url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12307698 |quote="Mubarak must step down. It is time for the military to intervene and save the country" |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} [[Mohamed ElBaradei]], who said he was ready to lead a transitional government,{{cite web|last=Memmott|first=Mark|url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/thetwo-way/2011/01/27/133275390/el-baradei-back-in-egypt-says-its-time-for-a-new-government|title=ElBaradei Back in Egypt; Says It's Time for a New Government: The Two-Way|publisher=[[NPR]]|date=27 January 2011|accessdate=1 February 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110201025025/http://www.npr.org/blogs/thetwo-way/2011/01/27/133275390/el-baradei-back-in-egypt-says-its-time-for-a-new-government|archivedate= 1 February 2011|deadurl= no}} was a consensus candidate from a unified opposition, which included the [[6 April Youth Movement]], the We Are All Khaled Said Movement, the [[National Association for Change]], the 25 January Movement, [[Kefaya]] and the Muslim Brotherhood.{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/arabic/middleeast/2011/01/110130_egypt_demo_new.shtml|script-title=ar:الجيش يدفع بتعزيزات اضافية وطائرات حربية تحلق فوق المتظاهرين في القاهرة|language=Arabic|publisher=[[BBC Arabic]]|date=30 January 2011|accessdate=30 January 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110131210955/http://www.bbc.co.uk/arabic/middleeast/2011/01/110130_egypt_demo_new.shtml|archivedate= 31 January 2011|deadurl= no}} ElBaradei formed a "steering committee".{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/A5D9789E-24E2-4A8F-B8E5-CC585AF34A23.htm|script-title=ar:لجنة وطنية لمفاوضة نظام مبارك|language=Arabic|publisher=Al Jazeera|date=30 January 2011|accessdate=31 January 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110207212302/http://aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/A5D9789E-24E2-4A8F-B8E5-CC585AF34A23.htm|archivedate= 7 February 2011|deadurl= no}} On 5 February, talks began between the government and opposition groups for a transitional period before elections. The government cracked down on the media, halting internet access{{cite web|last=Cowie|first=James|date=27 January 2011|url=http://www.renesys.com/blog/2011/01/egypt-leaves-the-internet.shtml|title=Egypt Leaves the Internet|publisher=Renesys|accessdate=4 February 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110204074349/http://www.renesys.com/blog/2011/01/egypt-leaves-the-internet.shtml|archivedate= 4 February 2011|deadurl= no}} (a primary means of opposition communication) with the help of London-based [[Vodafone]].{{cite news|first=Matt|last=Richtel| title=Egypt Cuts Off Most Internet and Cell Service|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/29/technology/internet/29cutoff.html|accessdate=1 June 2013|newspaper=The New York Times |date=28 January 2011}}{{cite news|first=Stephen C.|last=Webster| title=Vodafone confirms role in Egypt's cellular, Internet blackout|url=http://www.rawstory.com/rs/2011/01/28/vodafone-confirms-role-egypts-cellular-internet-blackout/ |publisher=The Raw Story|date=28 January 2011 | accessdate=1 June 2013}}{{cite news|first=Ryan|last=Singel| title=Egypt Shut Down Its Net With a Series of Phone Calls| url=https://www.wired.com/threatlevel/2011/01/egypt-isp-shutdown/ |newspaper=Wired |date=28 January 2011 | accessdate=1 June 2013}} Journalists were harassed by supporters of the regime, eliciting condemnation from the [[Committee to Protect Journalists]], European countries and the United States. [[Narus (company)|Narus]], a subsidiary of [[Boeing]], sold the Mubarak government surveillance equipment to help identify dissidents.{{cite web|first=Amy |last=Goodman |title=Digital Darkness: U.S., U.K. Companies Help Egyptian Regime Shut Down Telecommunications and Identify Dissident Voices |url=http://www.democracynow.org/seo/2011/2/1/digital_darkness_us_uk_companies_help |work=Democracy Now! |date=1 February 2011 |accessdate=1 June 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130517063808/http://www.democracynow.org/seo/2011/2/1/digital_darkness_us_uk_companies_help |archivedate=17 May 2013 |df=dmy }} === {{anchor|Reform process|After-Revolution Freedom of Establishing Political Parties}}Reforms === {{see also|Egyptian constitutional review committee of 2011|List of political parties in Egypt}} The revolution's primary demands, chanted at every protest, were bread (jobs), freedom, social justice and human dignity. The fulfillment of these demands has been uneven and debatable. Demands stemming from the main four include the following: [[File:A sign with the protesters demands.jpg|thumb|upright|alt=Large banner hanging from tall apartment building, with woman holding sign in foreground|Sign with protester demands]] [[File:Shreaded paper in Egypt's SS HQ.jpg|thumb|upright|alt=Cardboard box overflowing with shredded paper, with more shredded paper on floor|Shredded documents at the State Security Investigations Service]] {|class="wikitable" |+ Protesters' demands{{cite web |url=http://globalvoices.org/2011/02/10/egypt-a-list-of-demands-from-tahrir-square/ |title=Egypt: A List of Demands from Tahrir Square |publisher=Global Voices |date=10 February 2011 }} ! style="width:70%;"|Demand ! style="width:15%;"|Status ! style="width:15%;"|Date |- |1. Resignation of President Mubarak |{{done|Met}} |11 February 2011 |- |2. New minimum and maximum wages |{{done|Met}} |The basic minimum wage rose from EGP 246 to EGP 870 on 22 March 2015[http://www.dailynewsegypt.com/2015/03/22/basic-minimum-wage-jumps-from-egp-250-to-egp-870/ "Basic minimum wage jumps from EGP 250 to EGP 870"], Daily News Egypt. |- |3. Canceling emergency law |{{done|Met}}{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-18283635 |publisher=BBC News |title=Egypt state of emergency lifted after 31 years |date=31 May 2012}} |31 May 2012 |- |4. Dismantling the [[State Security Investigations Service]] |{{done|Claimed met}};[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12751234 Egypt dissolves notorious internal security agency], [[BBC News]], 31 May 2012 reneged in 2013{{cite news |author=Patrick Kingsley |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jul/29/egypt-restores-secret-police-units |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130730131327/http://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jul/29/egypt-restores-secret-police-units |dead-url=yes |archive-date=30 July 2013 |title=Egypt restores feared secret police units |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date=29 July 2013}} |31 May 2012 |- |5. Announcement by vice-president [[Omar Suleiman]] that he would not run for president |{{done|Claimed met}};{{cite news|url=https://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFWEA576620110203/|title=Egypt's Suleiman says will not run for president|agency=Reuters Africa|date=3 February 2011}}
reneged in April 2012 |3 February 2011 |- |6. Dissolving Parliament |{{done|Met}} |13 February 2011 |- |7. Ending the curfew |{{done|Met}}{{cite news |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/video/middleeast/2011/06/201161563513344977.html |title=Egypt's military council lifts nightly curfew |publisher=Al Jazeera News |date=15 June 2011}} |15 June 2011 |- |9. Firing Minister of Information [[Anas el-Fiqqi]] and halting [[State media#Press freedom|media]] propaganda |{{notdone|Not met}}; minister fired, [[Ministry of Information (Egypt)|ministry]] still exists and propaganda ongoing{{cite news |author=Abigail Hauslohner |url=http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,2107910,00.html |title=The Most Powerful Weapon of Egypt's Ruling Generals: State TV |work=Time |date=29 February 2012}} | |- |12.
