Arrest, interrogation and trial of Hosni Mubarak and his sons, Gamal and [[Alaa Mubarak|Alaa]] |{{done|Met}}{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-18306126 |publisher=BBC News |title=Mubarak sentenced to jail for life over protest deaths |date=2 June 2012}} |24 May 2011 |- |16. Transfer of power from SCAF to civilian council |{{done|Met}}{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-18656396 |publisher=BBC News |title=Brotherhood's Mursi sworn in as Egyptian president |date=30 June 2012}} |30 June 2012 |- |17. Removal of Mohamed Morsi in a military coup, after protests in Tahrir Square and throughout Egypt |{{done|Met}} |3 July 2013 |} [[File:Referendum in the desert.jpg|275px|thumb|alt+Very long line of men outside a building|Voter line in [[Mokattam]], Cairo, during the 19 March 2011 [[Egyptian constitutional referendum, 2011|constitutional referendum]] extending from the built-up area of Mokattam into the desert. The referendum had an unprecedented voter turnout (over 18 million).]] On 17 February, an Egyptian prosecutor ordered the detention of three former ministers (interior minister Habib el-Adli, tourism minister Zuhair Garana and housing minister Ahmed el-Maghrabi) and steel magnate Ahmed Ezz pending trial for wasting public funds. The public prosecutor froze the bank accounts of Adli and his family following accusations that over 4 million Egyptian pounds ($680,000) were transferred to his personal account by a businessman. The foreign minister was requested to contact European countries to freeze the other defendants' accounts.{{cite news |title=Egypt detains ex-ministers |publisher=Al Jazeera|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/2011217221111216445.html |date=17 February 2011 |accessdate=18 February 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110218053134/http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/2011217221111216445.html|archivedate= 18 February 2011|deadurl= no}} That day, the United States announced that it would give Egypt $150 million in aid to help it transition towards democracy. U.S. Secretary of State [[Hillary Clinton]] said that [[William Joseph Burns|William Burns]] (undersecretary of state for political affairs) and [[David Lipton]] (a senior White House adviser on international economics) would travel to Egypt the following week. On 19 February a moderate Islamic party which had been banned for 15 years, [[Al-Wasat Party|Al-Wasat Al-Jadid]] ({{Lang-ar|حزب الوسط الجديد}}, New Center Party), was finally recognised by an Egyptian court. The party was founded in 1996 by activists who split from the Muslim Brotherhood and sought to create a tolerant, liberal Islamic movement, but its four attempts to register as an official party were rejected. That day, Prime Minister Ahmed Shafiq also said that 222 political prisoners would be released. Shafiq said that only a few were detained during the uprising; he put the number of remaining political prisoners at 487, but did not say when they would be released.{{cite news |title=Egypt recognizes moderate Islamic party, promises to release political prisoners |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/crisis-in-egypt/egypt-recognizes-moderate-islamic-party-promises-to-release-political-prisoners/article1914290/ |date=19 February 2011 |accessdate=20 February 2011 |work=The Globe and Mail |location=Toronto |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110222062733/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/crisis-in-egypt/egypt-recognizes-moderate-islamic-party-promises-to-release-political-prisoners/article1914290/ |archivedate=22 February 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} On 20 February {{Interlanguage link multi|Yehia El Gamal|ar|3=يحيى الجمل|vertical-align=sup}}, an activist and law professor, accepted on television the position of deputy prime minister. The next day, the Muslim Brotherhood announced that it would form a political party, the [[Freedom and Justice Party (Egypt)|Freedom and Justice Party]] led by Saad Ketatni, for the upcoming parliamentary election.{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/325599 |title=Muslim Brotherhood to establish 'Freedom and Justice Party' |publisher=Al-Masry Al-Youm |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110314145947/http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/325599 |archivedate=14 March 2011 }}{{cite web |url=http://www.ikhwanweb.com/article.php?id=28088 |title=The Muslim Brotherhood Official English Website |publisher=Ikhwanweb |date=23 February 2011 |accessdate=5 March 2011 }}{{cite web |last=Gordon |first=Evelyn |url=http://www.jpost.com/MiddleEast/Article.aspx?id=209563&R=R3 |title=Muslim Brotherhood sits at Egypt's new democratic table |work=The Jerusalem Post |date=23 February 2011 |accessdate=5 March 2011 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110224110646/http://www.jpost.com/MiddleEast/Article.aspx?id=209563&R=R3|archivedate= 24 February 2011|deadurl= no}} A spokesperson said, "When we talk about the slogans of the revolution – freedom, social justice, equality – all of these are in the [[Sharia]] (Islamic law)."{{cite web |url=http://www.alarabiya.net/articles/2011/02/23/138826.html |title=Muslim Brothers see corruption-free Egypt flourishing |publisher=Al Arabiya |date=23 February 2011 |accessdate=5 March 2011 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110307151844/http://www.alarabiya.net/articles/2011/02/23/138826.html|archivedate= 7 March 2011|deadurl= no}} On 3 March, Prime Minister Shafiq submitted his resignation to the Supreme Council of the Armed Forces. The SCAF appointed [[Essam Sharaf]], a former transportation minister and a vocal critic of the regime following his resignation after the 2006 [[Qalyoub rail accident]], to replace Shafik and form a new government. Sharaf's appointment was seen as a concession to protesters, since he was actively involved in the events in Tahrir Square.{{cite news|publisher=BBC News|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12634117|title=Egypt's Prime Minister Ahmed Shafiq resigns|date=3 March 2011|accessdate=3 March 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110303102725/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12634117|archivedate= 3 March 2011|deadurl= no}}{{cite web |url=http://fr.euronews.net/depeches/772863-egypte-demission-du-premier-ministre-ahmad-chafic/ |title=Egypte: le Premier ministre remplacé, satisfaction des opposants |publisher=Euronews |language=French |date=3 March 2011 |accessdate=3 March 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110307143402/http://fr.euronews.net/depeches/772863-egypte-demission-du-premier-ministre-ahmad-chafic/|archivedate= 7 March 2011|deadurl= no}}{{cite web |url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/~/NewsContent/1/64/6892/Egypt/Politics-/Meet-Essam-Sharaf-Egypts-first-postrevolution-Prim.aspx |title=Meet Essam Sharaf: Egypt's first post-revolution Prime Minister |publisher=Ahram Online |date=3 March 2011 |accessdate=3 March 2011}} Sharaf appointed former [[International Court of Justice]] judge [[Nabil Elaraby]] foreign minister and Mansour El Essawi as interior minister.{{cite web |url=http://www.jpost.com/Headlines/Article.aspx?id=211001 |title=Egypt's Elaraby accepts foreign minister post |work=The Jerusalem Post |accessdate=7 March 2011 }}{{cite web |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/03/2011365436227288.html |title=Egypt PM appoints new key ministers |publisher=Al Jazeera |accessdate=7 March 2011 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110307091655/http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/03/2011365436227288.html|archivedate= 7 March 2011|deadurl= no}} On 16 April the Higher Administrative Court dissolved the former ruling National Democratic Party (NDP), ordering its funds and property to be transferred to the government.{{cite news |title=Egypt dissolves former ruling party |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/04/2011416125051889315.html |date=16 April 2011 |accessdate=16 April 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110419053336/http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/04/2011416125051889315.html|archivedate= 19 April 2011|deadurl= no}} On 24 May it was announced that Hosni Mubarak and his sons, Gamal and Alaa, would be for over the deaths of anti-government protesters during the revolution.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-13527102|title=Egypt: Hosni Mubarak and sons to be tried over deaths and should be killed for their crimes.|date=24 May 2011|publisher=BBC News |accessdate=24 May 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110525112010/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-13527102|archivedate= 25 May 2011|deadurl= no}} === {{anchor|Court trials of state officials accused of corruption}}Trials === {{main article|Trials and judicial hearings following the Egyptian Revolution of 2011}} Mubarak's resignation was followed by a series of arrests of, and travel bans on, high-profile figures on charges of causing the deaths of 300–500 demonstrators, injuring 5,000 more, [[embezzlement]], [[Profiteering (business)|profiteering]], [[money laundering]] and [[human rights abuses]]. Among those charged were Mubarak, his wife [[Suzanne Mubarak|Suzanne]], his sons Gamal and Alaa, former interior minister [[Habib el-Adly]], former housing minister Ahmed El-Maghrabi, former tourism minister [[Zoheir Garana]] and former secretary for organizational affairs of the National Democratic Party Ahmed Ezz.{{cite web|url=http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2011/1036/eg31.htm |title=How the mighty have fallen |newspaper=Al-Ahram Weekly |date=2 February 2011 |accessdate=16 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110501064050/http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2011/1036/eg31.htm |archivedate=1 May 2011 |df=dmy }} Mubarak's ouster was followed by allegations of corruption against other government officials and senior politicians.{{cite news|first=Phillip |last=Inman |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/feb/04/hosni-mubarak-family-fortune |title=Mubarak family fortune could reach $70bn, say experts |work=The Guardian |location=UK |date=4 February 2011 |accessdate=16 March 2011 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110314144323/http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/04/hosni-mubarak-family-fortune|archivedate= 14 March 2011|deadurl= no}}{{cite web|url=http://www.almasry-alyoum.com/article2.aspx?ArticleID=289811&IssueID=2068 |title=مصطفى الفقى: شخصية كبيرة فى الرئاسة أكدت لى أن "مبارك" لن يترشح وابنه سيكون البديل |language=ar |trans-title=Mustafa Fiki: a big figure in the presidency confirmed that 'Mubarak' will not run, his son would be the alternative |publisher=Almasry-alyoum.com |accessdate=16 March 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110425201529/http://www.almasry-alyoum.com/article2.aspx?ArticleID=289811&IssueID=2068 |archivedate=25 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} On 28 February 2011, Egypt's top prosecutor ordered an [[Asset freezing|assets freeze]] on Mubarak and his family.{{cite web|url=http://www.voanews.com/english/news/Egypt-Issues-Travel-Ban-Asset-Freeze-on-Mubarak-117076003.html |title=Egypt Issues Travel Ban, Asset Freeze on Mubarak |publisher=Voice of America |date=28 February 2011 |accessdate=16 March 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110302143133/http://www.voanews.com/english/news/Egypt-Issues-Travel-Ban-Asset-Freeze-on-Mubarak-117076003.html|archivedate= 2 March 2011|deadurl= no}} This was followed by arrest warrants, travel bans and asset freezes for other public figures, including former parliament speaker [[Fathi Sorour]] and former [[Shura Council]] speaker [[Safwat El Sherif]].{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/6644/Egypt/Politics-/NDP-fires-Mubarak--then-what.aspx |title=NDP fires Mubarak – then what? |publisher=Ahram Online |date=28 February 2011 |accessdate=16 March 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110430024635/http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/6644/Egypt/Politics-/NDP-fires-Mubarak--then-what.aspx|archivedate= 30 April 2011|deadurl= no}}{{cite web|url=http://www.masrawy.com/news/Egypt/Politics/2011/March/6/elshrief_announcement.aspx |title=الشريف ينفي امتلاكه حسابات خاصة خارج مصر |publisher=Masrawy.com |date=6 March 2011 |accessdate=16 March 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110314144003/http://www.masrawy.com/news/Egypt/Politics/2011/March/6/elshrief_announcement.aspx |archivedate=14 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} Arrest warrants were issued for financial misappropriations by public figures who left the country at the outbreak of the revolution, including former trade and industry minister [[Rachid Mohamed Rachid]] and businessman [[Hussein Salem]]; Salem was believed to have fled to Dubai.{{cite web|url=http://www.globes.co.il/serveen/globes/docview.asp?did=1000619367&fid=1725 |title=Hussein Salem caught in Dubai with $500m |publisher=Globes |date=31 January 2011 |accessdate=16 March 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110131230843/http://www.globes.co.il/serveen/globes/docview.asp?did=1000619367&fid=1725 |archivedate=31 January 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} Trials of the accused officials began on 5 March 2011, when former interior minister Habib el-Adli appeared at the Giza Criminal Court in Cairo.{{cite web|url=http://www.masrawy.com/News/Egypt/Politics/2011/february/27/adly_judgment.aspx |title=5 مارس.. بدء محاكمة العادلي أمام الجنايات |publisher=Masrawy.com |date=27 February 2011 |accessdate=16 March 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110314144015/http://www.masrawy.com/News/Egypt/Politics/2011/february/27/adly_judgment.aspx |archivedate=14 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} In March 2011 [[Abbud al-Zumar]], one of Egypt's best-known political prisoners, was freed after 30 years. Founder and first [[emir]] of the [[Egyptian Islamic Jihad]], he was implicated in the 6 October 1981 [[assassination of Anwar Sadat]].{{cite book |last=Atkins|first=Stephen E.|title=The 9/11 Encyclopædia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PDDIgWRN_HQC&pg=PA456|accessdate=6 May 2011|date=31 May 2011|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-1-59884-921-9|pages=456–}} On 24 May, Mubarak was ordered to stand trial on charges of [[premeditated murder]] of peaceful protestors during the revolution; if convicted, he could face the death penalty. The list of charges, released by the public prosecutor, was "intentional murder, attempted killing of some demonstrators ... misuse of influence and deliberately wasting public funds and unlawfully making private financial gains and profits". == Analysis == === Regional instability === {{main article|Arab Spring}} The Egyptian and Tunisian revolutions sparked a [[Revolutionary wave|wave of uprisings]], with demonstrations spreading across the [[MENA|Middle East and North Africa]]. [[2010–2011 Algerian protests|Algeria]], [[2011 Bahraini protests|Bahrain]], [[2011 Iranian protests|Iran]], [[2011 Jordanian protests|Jordan]], [[2011 Libyan civil war|Libya]], [[2011 Morocco protests|Morocco]], [[2011 Yemeni uprising|Yemen]] and [[2011 Syrian uprising|Syria]] witnessed major protests, and minor demonstrations occurred in [[2011 Iraqi protests|Iraq]], Kuwait, [[Mauritania]], [[2011 Omani protests|Oman]], [[2011 Saudi Arabian protests|Saudi Arabia]], Somalia{{citation needed|date=June 2014}} and [[2011 Sudanese protests|Sudan]]. The Egyptian protests in Egypt were not centred around religion-based politics, but nationalism and social consciousness.{{cite web|url=http://palestinenote.com/blogs/blogs/archive/2011/02/28/secularism-is-what-the-arab-world-needs.aspx |title=Secularism is what the Arab world needs – Blog Post |publisher=Palestinenote.com |date=28 February 2011 |accessdate=5 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110307200155/http://palestinenote.com/blogs/blogs/archive/2011/02/28/secularism-is-what-the-arab-world-needs.aspx |archivedate=7 March 2011 }} Before the uprising, the best-organised and most-prominent opposition movements in the Arab world usually came from Islamist organisations with members who were motivated and ready to sacrifice. However, secular forces emerged from the revolution espousing principles shared with religious groups: freedom, social justice and dignity. Islamist organisations emerged with a greater freedom to operate. Although the cooperative, inter-faith revolution was no guarantee that partisan politics would not re-emerge in its wake, its success represented a change from the intellectual stagnation (created by decades of repression) which pitted modernity and Islamism against one another. Islamists and secularists are faced with new opportunities for dialogue on subjects such as the role of Islam and Sharia in society, freedom of speech and the impact of secularism on a predominantly-Muslim population.{{cite web |url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Middle-East/2011/0304/An-upside-of-Arab-revolts-Islamists-talk-democracy |title=An upside of Arab revolts: Islamists talk democracy |work=The Christian Science Monitor |accessdate=5 March 2011 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110305035013/http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Middle-East/2011/0304/An-upside-of-Arab-revolts-Islamists-talk-democracy|archivedate= 5 March 2011|deadurl= no}} Despite the optimism surrounding the revolution, commentators expressed concern about the risk of increased power and influence for Islamist forces in the country and region and the difficulty of integrating different groups, ideologies and visions for the country. Journalist [[Caroline Glick]] wrote that the Egyptian revolution foreshadowed a rise in religious radicalism and support for terrorism, citing a 2010 [[Pew]] Opinion poll which found that Egyptians supported Islamists over modernizers by an over two-to-one margin.{{cite web|url=http://www.jpost.com/Opinion/Columnists/Article.aspx?id=206121|title=Our World: Clueless in Washington|author=Glick, Caroline|accessdate=10 April 2011|work=The Jerusalem Post|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110427073738/http://www.jpost.com/Opinion/Columnists/Article.aspx?id=206121|archivedate= 27 April 2011|deadurl= no}} Another journalist, [[Shlomo Ben-Ami]], said that Egypt's most formidable task was to refute the old paradigm of the Arab world which sees the only choices for regimes repressive, secular dictatorships or repressive theocracies. Ben-Ami noted that with Islam a central part of the society, any emergent regime was bound to be attuned to religion. In his view, a democracy which excluded all religion from public life (as in France) could succeed in Egypt but no genuine Arab democracy could disallow the participation of political Islam.{{cite web|url=http://www.project-syndicate.org/commentary/benami51/English7 |title=Saving the Egyptian Revolution |publisher=[[Project Syndicate]] |date=3 March 2011 |accessdate=6 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110430171001/http://www.project-syndicate.org/commentary/benami51/English7 |archivedate=30 April 2011 }} Since the revolution Islamist parties (such as the Muslim Brotherhood) have strengthened in the democratic landscape, leading constitutional change, voter mobilization and protests.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/21/world/middleeast/21egypt.htm|title=Egyptian Voters Approve Constitutional Changes|author=MacFarquhar, Neil|accessdate=10 April 2011|work=The New York Times|date=20 March 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20111128102754/http://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/21/world/middleeast/21egypt.htm|archivedate=28 November 2011 |deadurl= no}}{{cite news|last=Bradley |first=Matt |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704587004576244922383434098 |title=Egypt's Muslim Brotherhood to Rejoin Protests |work=The Wall Street Journal |date=3 February 2011 |accessdate=13 April 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110409104007/http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748704587004576244922383434098.html|archivedate= 9 April 2011|deadurl= no}} This was a concern of the secular and youth movements, who wanted elections to be held later so they could catch up to the already-well-organized groups. Elections were held in September 2011, with Liberty and Justice (the Muslim Brotherhood party) winning 48.5 percent of the vote. In 2014 in Upper Egypt, several newspapers reported that [[Upper Egypt]] wanted to secede from the rest of the country to improve its standard of living.{{cite news | url=http://www.iar-gwu.org/content/egypt-breaking-apart | title=Is Egypt Breaking Apart? | work=International Affairs Review | date=17 February 2014 | author=Gratowski, J. Thomas | accessdate=18 February 2014}} ==== Alexandria church bombing ==== {{main article|2011 Alexandria bombing}} Early on New Year's Day 2011 a bomb exploded in front of an Alexandria church, killing 23 [[Copts|Coptic]] Christians. Egyptian officials said that "foreign elements" were behind the attack.{{cite news|title=Egypt Church Blast Death Toll Rises to 23|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE7010M020110104|agency=[[Reuters]]|date=4 January 2011|accessdate=4 February 2011}} Other sources claim that the bomb killed 21 people only and injured more than 70.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-12101748|title=Egypt bomb kills 21 at Alexandria Coptic church|date=2011-01-01|newspaper=BBC News|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-11-19}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/02/world/middleeast/02egypt.html|title=Coptic Church in Egypt Is Hit by Fatal Bomb Attack|last=Fahim|first=Kareem|date=2011-01-01|last2=Stack|first2=Liam|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|access-date=2016-11-19}} Some Copts accused the Egyptian government of negligence;{{cite news|last= Slackman|first= Michael|url= https://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/04/world/middleeast/04egypt.html|title= Clashes Grow as Egyptians Remain Angry After an Attack|work=[[The New York Times]] |date= 4 January 2011}} after the attack, many Christians protested in the streets (with Muslims joining later). After clashing with police, protesters in Alexandria and Cairo shouted slogans denouncing Mubarak's rule{{cite news|title=Egypt Media Warn of Civil War after Bombing |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gM4ojQSkgen45AIWUkmRXYIsEFwA |accessdate=28 January 2011 |agency=Agence France-Presse |publisher=[[Google News]] |date=2 January 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110304210621/https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gM4ojQSkgen45AIWUkmRXYIsEFwA |archivedate=4 March 2011 }}{{cite news|author1=Stack, Liam |author2=Kirkpatrick, David D. |title=Egypt Orders Tighter Security After Church Bombing|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/03/world/middleeast/03egypt.html?partner=rss&emc=rss|accessdate=28 January 2011|work=[[The New York Times]] |date=2 January 2011}}{{cite news|last=Jouini |first=Hassen |title=Muslims Protect Churches |url=http://www.nationalpost.com/news/world/Muslims+protect+churches/4078614/story.html |archive-url=http://arquivo.pt/wayback/20110122114611/http://www.nationalpost.com/news/world/Muslims+protect+churches/4078614/story.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=22 January 2011 |accessdate=28 January 2011 |work=[[National Post]] |location=Canada |date=8 January 2011 }} in support of unity between Christians and Muslims. Their sense of being let down by national security forces was cited as one of the first grievances sparking the 25 January uprising.Interview. "Vivian Ibrahim of the [[School of Oriental and African Studies]] at the [[University of London]]". [[BBC News]] 3 February 2011; 12:55 UTC. On 7 February a complaint was filed against Habib al-Adly (interior minister until Mubarak dissolved the government during the protests' early days), accusing him of directing the attack.{{cite news|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/tuesday%E2%80%99s-papers-funeral-martyr-journalist-ghoneim-release-al-adli-under-investigation |title=Tuesday's papers: Funeral for martyr journalist, Ghoneim release, al-Adli under investigation |author=Heba Helmy |date=8 February 2011 |publisher=Al Masry Al Youm |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110222121358/http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/tuesday%E2%80%99s-papers-funeral-martyr-journalist-ghoneim-release-al-adli-under-investigation |archivedate=22 February 2011 }} === {{anchor|Women's role}}Role of women === [[File:Flickr - Floris Van Cauwelaert - The messages on Tahrir Square (8).jpg|thumb|alt=Woman covered in black except for her eyes, holding a sign|Female protester wearing a [[Niqāb in Egypt|niqāb]]{{cite news|author=Fatma Naib |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/features/2011/02/2011217134411934738.html |title=Women of the revolution – Features |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=19 February 2011 |accessdate=13 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110415070749/http://english.aljazeera.net//indepth/features/2011/02/2011217134411934738.html |archivedate=15 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}]] [[Women in Egypt|Egyptian women]] have been participating actively in the revolution, in the same way that they played an active role in the strike movement in the few last years, in several cases pressurizing the men to join the strikes.{{cite web|url=http://www.marxist.com/key-role-of-women-in-egyptian-revolution.htm|title=The key role of women in the Egyptian revolution|author=Niklas Albin Svensson|work=In Defence of Marxism|accessdate=25 June 2015}} In earlier protests in Egypt, women only accounted for about 10 per cent of the protesters, but on Tahrir Square they accounted for about 40 to 50 per cent in the days leading up to the fall of Mubarak. Women, with and without veils, participated in the defence of the square, set up barricades, led debates, shouted slogans and, together with the men, risked their lives. Some participated in the protests, were present in news clips and on Facebook forums and were part of the revolution's leadership during the Egyptian revolution. In Tahrir Square, female protesters (some with children) supported the protests. The diversity of the protesters in Tahrir Square was visible in the women who participated; many wore [[head scarves]] and other signs of religious conservatism, while others felt free to kiss a friend or smoke a cigarette in public. Women organised protests and reported events; female bloggers, such as Leil Zahra Mortada, risked abuse or imprisonment by keeping the world informed of events in Tahrir Square and elsewhere.{{cite news |last = Wolf |first = Naomi |date=28 February 2011 |url = http://www.project-syndicate.org/commentary/wolf33/English |title = The Middle East's Feminist Revolution |publisher=[[Project Syndicate]] |accessdate=1 March 2011 }} Among those who died was Sally Zahran, who was beaten to death during one of the demonstrations. [[NASA]] reportedly planned to name one of its [[Mars]] exploration spacecraft in Zahran's honour.{{cite news |date=12 February 2011 |url = http://www.ndtv.com/article/world/nasa-rocket-to-bear-name-of-egyptian-woman-killed-in-protests-84866 |title = NASA rocket to bear name of Egyptian woman killed in protests |publisher=[[NDTV]] |accessdate=6 March 2011 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110307143359/http://www.ndtv.com/article/world/nasa-rocket-to-bear-name-of-egyptian-woman-killed-in-protests-84866|archivedate= 7 March 2011|deadurl= no}} The participation and contributions by Egyptian women to the protests were attributed to the fact that many (especially younger women) were better educated than previous generations and represent more than half of Egyptian university students. This is an empowering factor for women, who have become more present and active publicly. The advent of social media also provided a tool for women to become protest leaders. === {{anchor|The military's role}}Role of the military === [[File:Burning amy vehicle.png|thumb|alt=A truck ablaze|One of two army vehicles burnt during the army attacks on 9 April 2011]] The [[Egyptian Armed Forces]] initially enjoyed a better public reputation than the police did; the former was seen as a professional body protecting the country, and the latter was accused of [[systemic corruption]] and lawless violence. However, when the SCAF cracked down on protesters after becoming the ''de facto'' ruler of Egypt the military's popularity decreased.{{citation needed|date=January 2015}} All four [[Egyptian president]]s since the 1950s have a military background. Key Egyptian military personnel include defense minister [[Mohamed Hussein Tantawi]] and armed forces chief of staff [[Sami Hafez Enan]].{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110213/D9LC1NLO0.html |title=Key members of Egypt Armed Forces Supreme Council |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |accessdate=13 February 2011}}{{cite news|author=[[Ian Black (journalist)|Black, Ian]]|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/jan/30/egypt-military-hosni-mubarak|title=All Eyes on Egypt's Military as Hosni Mubarak Fortifies Position |work=The Guardian |location=UK |date=30 January 2011|accessdate=31 January 2011 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110131053323/http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jan/30/egypt-military-hosni-mubarak|archivedate= 31 January 2011|deadurl= no}} The Egyptian military numbers about 468,500 active personnel, plus a reserve of 479,000.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/01/30/uk-egypt-protests-military-idUKTRE70T29420110130|title=Factbox – Egypt's Powerful Military|agency=Reuters |date=30 January 2011|accessdate=31 January 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110201013300/https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/01/30/uk-egypt-protests-military-idUKTRE70T29420110130|archivedate= 1 February 2011|deadurl= no}} As head of Egypt's armed forces, Tantawi has been described as "aged and change-resistant" and is attached to the old regime. He has used his position as defense minister to oppose economic and political reform he saw as weakening central authority. Other key figures ([[Sami Hafez Anan]] chief among them) are younger, with closer connections to the U.S. and the Muslim Brotherhood. An important aspect of the relationship between the Egyptian and American military establishments is the $1.3 billion in annual military aid provided to Egypt, which pays for American-made military equipment and allows Egyptian officers to train in the U.S. Guaranteed this aid package, the ruling SCAF is resistant to reform.{{cite web |last=Kotb |first=Amrou |date=2013-10-31 |url=http://masroregypt.wordpress.com/2013/10/31/inclusive-democracy-is-no-longer-a-suggestion-its-an-order/ |title=In Egypt, Inclusive Democracy is no Longer just a Suggestion |publisher=Masr or Egypt |accessdate=2013-12-06}}{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/feb/14/wikileaks-cables-egyptian-military-head |title=WikiLeaks cables: Egyptian military head is 'old and resistant to change' |work=The Guardian |location=UK |date=14 February 2011 |accessdate=6 March 2011 |first1=Julian |last1=Borger |first2=James |last2=Ball|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110307153819/http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/14/wikileaks-cables-egyptian-military-head|archivedate= 7 March 2011|deadurl= no}}{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/cifamerica/2011/feb/04/egypt-arms-trade?INTCMP=ILCNETTXT3487 |title=Egypt's military-industrial complex |work=The Guardian |location=UK |date=4 February 2011 |accessdate=6 March 2011 |first=Pratap |last=Chatterjee|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110307154001/http://www.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/cifamerica/2011/feb/04/egypt-arms-trade?INTCMP=ILCNETTXT3487|archivedate= 7 March 2011|deadurl= no}} One analyst, conceding the military's conservatism, says it has no option but to facilitate democratisation. It will have to limit its political role to continue good relations with the West, and cannot restrict Islamist participation in a genuine democracy. The military has led a violent crackdown on the Egyptian revolution since the fall of Mubarak. On 9 March 2011 military police violently dispersed a sit-in in Tahrir Square, arresting and torturing protesters. Seven female protesters were forcibly subjected to [[virginity test]]s.{{cite web|url=https://www.amnesty.org/en/news-and-updates/egypt-admission-forced-virginity-tests-must-lead-justice-2011-05-31|title=Egypt: Admission of forced 'virginity tests' must lead to justice - Amnesty International|date=31 May 2011|publisher=Amnesty International}} During the night of 8 April 2011 military police attacked a sit-in in Tahrir Square by protesters and sympathetic military officers, killing at least one.{{cite web|url=http://newsblogged.com/video-tahrir-square-egypt-army-attack-protesters-89-april-2011-youtube |title=Video: Tahrir Square Egypt Army Attack Protesters 8/9 April 2011 (Youtube) |publisher=Newsblogged.com |date=9 April 2011 |accessdate=17 November 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121122074505/http://newsblogged.com/video-tahrir-square-egypt-army-attack-protesters-89-april-2011-youtube |archivedate=22 November 2012 |df=dmy }} On 9 October the Egyptian military crushed protesters under armed personnel carriers and shot live ammunition at a demonstration in front of the [[Maspero television building]], [[Maspero demonstrations|killing at least 24]].[http://www.jadaliyya.com/pages/index/3022/the-maspero-crime_accounts-against-the-counter-rev The "Maspero Crime": Accounts Against the Counter-Revolution] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120109185518/http://www.jadaliyya.com/pages/index/3022/the-maspero-crime_accounts-against-the-counter-rev |date=9 January 2012 }}. ''[[Jadaliyya]]'' On 19 November the military and police engaged in a continuous six-day battle with protestors in the streets of downtown Cairo and [[Alexandria]], killing nearly 40 and injuring over 2,000.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/nov/24/egypts-generals-defy-tahrir-protests-elections |location=London |work=The Guardian |first1=Martin |last1=Chulov |first2=Jack |last2=Shenker |title=Egypt's generals defy Tahrir protests over elections |date=25 November 2011}} On 16 December 2011 military forces dispersed a [[sit-in]] at the Cabinet of Ministers building, killing 17.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/dec/23/tahrir-square-rally-denounces-violence |location=London |work=The Guardian |title=Tahrir Square rally denounces violence against protesters |date=23 December 2011}} Soldiers fired live ammunition and attacked from the rooftop with Molotov cocktails, rocks and other missiles.{{cite web|author=Manshy007 |url=http://scaf-crimes.blogspot.com/ |title=SCAF Crimes – جرائم العسكر |publisher=Scaf-crimes.blogspot.com |date=19 December 2011 |accessdate=17 November 2012}} === {{anchor|Foreign relations}}Impact on foreign relations === {{Main|Foreign relations of Egypt}} Foreign governments in the West (including the U.S.) regarded Mubarak as an important ally and [[Foreign relations of Egypt#Israeli–Palestinian conflict|supporter]] in the [[Israeli–Palestinian conflict|Israeli–Palestinian]] peace negotiations. After wars with [[Israel]] in 1948, 1956, 1967 and 1973, Egypt signed a [[Egypt–Israel Peace Treaty|peace treaty]] in 1979 (provoking controversy in the [[Arab world]]). According to the 1978 [[Camp David Accords]] (which led to the peace treaty), Israel and Egypt receive billions of dollars in aid annually from the United States; Egypt received over US$1.3 billion in military aid each year, in addition to economic and development assistance.{{cite web|title=Background Note: Egypt|publisher=United States Department of State|date=10 November 2010|url=https://www.state.gov/r/pa/ei/bgn/5309.htm#relations|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110126132105/https://www.state.gov/r/pa/ei/bgn/5309.htm#relations|archivedate=2011-01-26|accessdate=22 September 2013|deadurl= no}} According to Juan Cole many Egyptian youth felt ignored by Mubarak, feeling that he put the interests of the West ahead of theirs.{{cite news |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2011/01/30/opinion/main20030008.shtml|title=Why Egypt's Class Conflict Is Boiling Over – Juan Cole: How Decades of Economic Stumbles Set the Stage for Egypt's Current Political Turmoil|author=Cole, Juan|date=30 January 2011|publisher=[[CBS News]]|accessdate=4 February 2011}} The cooperation of the Egyptian regime in enforcing the [[blockade of the Gaza Strip]] was deeply unpopular with the Egyptian public.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2008/jan/25/egypt.israelandthepalestinians1 |title=Mubarak under pressure |work=The Guardian |location=UK |accessdate=6 February 2011 |date=25 January 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110207195918/http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2008/jan/25/egypt.israelandthepalestinians1 |archivedate=7 February 2011|deadurl=no}} === {{anchor|Online activism and the role of social media}}Online activism and social media === [[File:2011 Egyptian protests Facebook & jan25 card.jpg|thumb|alt=Red, white and blue placard in English and Arabic, with a Twitter hashtag|Man holding a poster reading "Facebook, #jan25, The Egyptian Social Network" during the 2011 protests]] [[File:April 2008 uprisings in Mahalla, Egypt.JPG|thumb|People take to the streets on 7 April 2008, in Mahalla, Egypt. In the days following the planned strike on 6 April that was shut down by government force, a series of uprisings and military reprisals turned the city of Mahalla, about two hours north of Cairo, into a conflict zone. Rising food prices fueled the unrest. The 6 April Movement was formed in the wake of the uprisings which fed revolutionary sentiment and helped lead to the 2011 revolution.]] The [[6 April Youth Movement]] (Arabic: حركة شباب 6 أبريل) is an Egyptian Facebook group begun in spring 2008 to support workers in El-Mahalla El-Kubra, an industrial town, who were planning to [[2008 Egyptian general strike|strike on 6 April]]. Activists called on participants to wear black and stay home the day of the strike. Bloggers and citizen journalists used Facebook, Twitter, Flickr, blogs and other media tools to report on the strike, alert their networks about police activity, organize legal protection and draw attention to their efforts. ''The New York Times'' has called it the political Facebook group in Egypt with the most dynamic debates.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/01/25/magazine/25bloggers-t.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0 |title=Revolution, Facebook-style |work=The New York Times Magazine |accessdate=22 June 2014}} In March 2012 it had 325,000{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/shabab6april |title=6th of April Youth Movement – حركة شباب 6 إبريل |publisher=Facebook |accessdate=17 November 2012}} predominantly young and members, most previously inactive politically, whose concerns included free speech, nepotism in government and the country's stagnant economy. Their Facebook forum features intense and heated discussions, and is frequently updated. [[We are all Khaled Said]] is a Facebook group which formed in the aftermath of Said's beating and death. The group attracted hundreds of thousands of members worldwide, playing a prominent role in spreading (and drawing attention to) the growing discontent. As the protests began, Google executive [[Wael Ghonim]] revealed that he was behind the account. He was later detained for a few days until the government was able to get a hold of certain information that they needed. Many questions were left around that subject, no one really understood what had actually happened or what has had been said. {{cite news|title = Who is Wael Ghonim?|date=8 February 2011|publisher=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]]|url = http://www.cbc.ca/world/story/2011/02/08/f-wael-ghonim.html|work=[[CBC News]]|accessdate=17 February 2011}} In a TV interview with SCAF members after the revolution, Abdul Rahman Mansour (an underground activist and media expert) was disclosed as sharing the account with Ghonim.{{cite news|title = تقرير خاص- من داخل الثورة المصرية|url = http://ara.reuters.com/article/topNews/idARACAE73C0QW20110413?sp=true|date=13 April 2011|agency=Reuters |format = transcript|accessdate=6 February 2011}} Another online contribution was made by [[Asmaa Mahfouz]], an activist who posted a video challenging people to publicly protest.{{cite news|title = Women play vital role in Egypt's uprising|url = https://www.npr.org/2011/02/04/133497422/Women-Play-Vital-Role-In-Egypts-Uprising|date=4 February 2011|publisher=NPR|format = transcript|accessdate=6 February 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110205032511/http://www.npr.org/2011/02/04/133497422/Women-Play-Vital-Role-In-Egypts-Uprising|archivedate= 5 February 2011|deadurl= no}} Facebook had previously suspended the group because some administrators were using pseudonyms, a violation of the company's terms of service.{{cite news|title = Can Egypt's Internet Movement Be Exported?|date=18 February 2011|work=[[The Nation]]|url = http://www.thenation.com/print/article/158717/can-egypts-internet-movement-be-exported|accessdate=23 February 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110222074906/http://www.thenation.com/print/article/158717/can-egypts-internet-movement-be-exported|archivedate= 22 February 2011|deadurl= no}} [[Social media]] has been used extensively.{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/gadgets-and-tech/social-media-cellphone-video-fuel-arab-protests-2227088.html |title=Social media, cellphone video fuel Arab protests |work=The Independent |location=UK |date=27 February 2011 |accessdate=6 March 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110301071004/http://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/gadgets-and-tech/social-media-cellphone-video-fuel-arab-protests-2227088.html|archivedate=1 March 2011|deadurl=y }}{{cite web |url=http://www.worldpoliticsreview.com/articles/8089/the-realist-prism-politics-vs-social-media-in-the-arab-uprising |title=The Realist Prism: Politics vs. Social Media in the Arab Uprising |publisher=World Politics Review |date=25 January 2011 |accessdate=6 March 2011 }}{{cite web |url=http://www.dailykos.com/story/2011/02/17/946150/-History-of-the-Revolution-on-Facebook |title=History of the Revolution on Facebook |work=Daily Kos |date=17 February 2011 |accessdate=29 May 2011 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110518094058/http://www.dailykos.com/story/2011/02/17/946150/-History-of-the-Revolution-on-Facebook|archivedate= 18 May 2011|deadurl= no}}{{cite web |url=https://techcrunch.com/2011/02/11/feb11/ |title=Mubarak Shut Down The Internet, And The Internet Paid Him in Kind |publisher=TechCrunch |date=11 February 2011 |accessdate=26 June 2011 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110515172848/http://techcrunch.com/2011/02/11/feb11/|archivedate= 15 May 2011|deadurl= no}} As one Egyptian activist tweeted during the protests, "We use Facebook to schedule the protests, Twitter to coordinate, and YouTube to tell the world."{{cite web |url=http://www.miller-mccune.com/politics/the-cascading-effects-of-the-arab-spring-28575/ |title=The Arab Uprising's Cascading Effects |publisher=Miller-McCune |date=23 February 2011 |accessdate=6 March 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110301052550/http://www.miller-mccune.com/politics/the-cascading-effects-of-the-arab-spring-28575/ |archivedate=1 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} Internet censorship has also been extensive, in some cases to the extent of taking entire nations virtually offline.{{cite web |url = http://www.monkey.org/~labovit/blog/ |title = Craig Labovitz's Blog |publisher = Monkey.org |accessdate = 6 March 2011 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110308060557/http://www.monkey.org/~labovit/blog/ |archivedate = 8 March 2011 |df = dmy-all }} Facebook, Twitter and blogging helped spread the uprising. Egyptian businessman Khaled Said was beaten to death by police in June 2010, reportedly in retaliation for a video he posted showing Egyptian police sharing the spoils of a drug bust. Wael Ghonim's memorial Facebook page to Said grew to over 400,000 followers, creating an online arena where protestors and those discontented with the government could gather and organise. The page called for protests on 25 January, later known as the "Day of Wrath". Hundreds of thousands of protestors flooded the streets to show their discontent with murder and corruption in their country. Ghonim was jailed on 28 January, and released 12 days later. Egyptian activist and 6 April Youth Movement member Asmaa Mahfouz posted a video urging the Egyptian people to meet her at Tahrir Square, rise up against the government and demand democracy. In the video, she spoke about four protesters who had immolated themselves in protest of 30 years of poverty and degradation. On 24 January Mahfouz posted another video relating efforts made in support of the protest, from printing posters to creating flyers. The videos were posted on Facebook and then YouTube. The day after her last video post, hundreds of thousands of Egyptians poured into the streets in protest. Since 25 January 2011, videos (including those of a badly-beaten Khaled Said, disproving police claims that he had choked to death), tweets and Facebook comments have kept the world abreast of the situation in Egypt. Amir Ali documents the ways in which social media was used by Egyptian activists, Egyptian celebrities and political figures abroad to fan the protests.{{cite journal |first=Amir |last=Ali |url=http://harvardhrj.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/09/185-220.pdf |title=The Power of Social Media in Developing Nations: New Tools for Closing the Global Digital Divide and Beyond |journal=Harvard Human Rights Journal |volume=24 |issue=1 |pages=185–189, 208–210}} [[Democracy Now!]] journalist [[Sharif Abdel Kouddous]] provided live coverage and [[Twitter|tweets]] from [[Tahrir Square]] during the protests, and was credited with using social media to increase awareness of the protests.{{cite web|url=http://www.democracynow.org/2011/3/30/sharif_abdel_kouddous_transitions_from_democracy |title=Sharif Abdel Kouddous Transitions from Democracy Now! Senior Producer to Middle East Correspondent |publisher=Democracy Now |accessdate=17 November 2012}}{{cite web|url=http://pulitzercenter.org/people/sharif-abdel-kouddous |title=Sharif Abdel Kouddous |publisher=Pulitzer Center |accessdate=17 November 2012}} The role of social media in the Egyptian uprising was debated in the first edition of the [[Dubai Debates]]: "Mark Zuckerberg – the new hero of the Arab people?"{{cite web|url=http://www.dubaidebates.com/debates/view/1/mark-zuckerberg-the-new-hero-of-the-arab-people |title=Previous Debate |publisher=DubaiDebates.com |date=22 February 2011 |accessdate=17 November 2012}} Amir Ali has argued that, based in part on the Egyptian revolution, social media may be an effective tool in developing nations.{{cite journal |first=Amir |last=Ali |url=http://harvardhrj.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/09/185-220.pdf |title=The Power of Social Media in Developing Nations: New Tools for Closing the Global Digital Divide and Beyond |journal=Harvard Human Rights Journal |volume=24 |issue=1 |pages=205–208}} Critics who downplay the influence of social networking on the Arab Spring cite several points:{{cite web|last=Wong |first=David |url=http://www.cracked.com/article_19225_5-reasons-twitter-isnt-actually-overthrowing-governments.html |title=5 Reasons Twitter Isn't Actually Overthrowing Governments |publisher=Cracked.com |date=31 May 2011 |accessdate=17 November 2012}} *Fewer than 20 percent of Egyptians had internet access, and the internet reached less than 40 percent of the country[http://www.internetworldstats.com/stats1.htm Africa Internet Usage, Facebook and Population Statistics]. Internetworldstats.com. Retrieved on 2013-12-06. *Social-networking sites were generally unpopular in the Middle East,{{cite web|url=http://blog.sysomos.com/2009/06/21/a-look-at-twitter-in-iran/ |title=A Look at Twitter in Iran « Sysomos Blog |publisher=Blog.sysomos.com |date=21 June 2009 |accessdate=17 November 2012}}{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/jun/09/iran-twitter-revolution-protests |location=London |work=The Guardian |first=Matthew |last=Weaver |title=Iran's 'Twitter revolution' was exaggerated, says editor |date=9 June 2010}} *Such sites were not sufficiently private to evade authorities{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB125978649644673331 |work=The Wall Street Journal |first=Farnaz |last=Fassihi |title=Iranian Crackdown Goes Global |date=3 December 2009}} *Many people did not trust social networking as a news source{{cite web |url=http://www.businessweek.com/technology/content/jun2009/tc20090617_803990_page_2.htm |title=Businessweek - Business News, Stock market & Financial Advice |work=Businessweek.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110914103909/http://www.businessweek.com/technology/content/jun2009/tc20090617_803990_page_2.htm |archivedate=14 September 2011 |df=dmy }} *Social-networking sites were promoted by the media{{cite web|url=http://www.rferl.org/content/tunisia_can_we_please_stop_talking_about_twitter_revolutions/2277052.html |title=Tunisia: Can We Please Stop Talking About 'Twitter Revolutions'? |publisher=Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty |accessdate=17 November 2012}} *Social-networking sites did not involve non-activists in the revolution{{cite web|author=Rebekah Heacock |url=http://globalvoices.org/2011/04/15/egypt-gene-sharp-taught-us-how-to-revolt/ |title=Egypt: Gene Sharp Taught Us How To Revolt! |publisher=Global Voices |date=15 April 2011 |accessdate=17 November 2012}} Some protesters discouraged the use of social media. A widely circulated pamphlet by an anonymous activist group titled "How to Protest Intelligently" (Arabic: كيف للاحتجاج بذكاء؟), asked readers "not to use Twitter or Facebook or other websites because they are all being monitored by the Ministry of the Interior".{{cite web|last1=Madrigal|first1=Alexis C.|title=Egyptian Activists' Action Plan: Translated|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2011/01/egyptian-activists-action-plan-translated/70388/|website=The Atlantic|accessdate=15 June 2014}} Television, particularly live coverage by ''[[Al Jazeera English]]'' and [[BBC News]], was important to the revolution; the cameras provided exposure, preventing mass violence by the government in Tahir Square (in contrast to the lack of live coverage and more-widespread violence in Libya).Hearns-Branaman, Jesse Owen (2012), 'The Egyptian Revolution did not take place: On live television coverage by Al Jazeera English', ''[[International Journal of Baudrillard Studies]]'' Vol 9, no 1 {{cite web|url=https://www.ubishops.ca/baudrillardstudies/vol-9_1/v9-1-branaman.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=17 May 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150321094852/http://www.ubishops.ca/baudrillardstudies/vol-9_1/v9-1-branaman.html |archivedate=21 March 2015 }} Its use was important in order to portray the violence of the Egyptian government, as well as, building support for the revolution through several different mediums. On one front was social media giving minute by minute updates via YouTube, Facebook and Twitter, and in the other hand was the use of the mainstream media to report to a wider audience about the overall developments occurring in Egypt.{{Cite journal|last=Eltantawy|first=Nahed|last2=Wiest|first2=Julie B.|date=2011-09-02|title=The Arab Spring{{!}} Social Media in the Egyptian Revolution: Reconsidering Resource Mobilization Theory|url=http://ijoc.org/index.php/ijoc/article/view/1242|journal=International Journal of Communication|language=en|volume=5|issue=0|pages=18|issn=1932-8036}} The ability of protesters to focus their demonstrations on a single area (with live coverage) was fundamental in Egypt but impossible in Libya, Bahrain and Syria, irrespective of social-media use. A social-media expert launched a network of messages with the hashtag #jan25 on 11 February 2011, when Mubarak's resignation was announced.{{cite web|last=Panisson |first=André |title=The Egyptian Revolution on Twitter |url=https://gephi.org/2011/the-egyptian-revolution-on-twitter/ |accessdate=26 December 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111225095702/http://gephi.org/2011/the-egyptian-revolution-on-twitter/ |archivedate=25 December 2011 }} Social media helped secure solidarity for the revolutionaries from people outside of Egypt. This is evident through movements like the "March of Millions", "Voice of Egypt Abroad", "Egyptians Abroad in Support of Egypt" and "New United Arab States", who had their inception during the revolution inside the realms of Twitter and Facebook. Journalism scholar [[Heather Ford]] studied the use of [[infoboxes]] and [[cleanup templates]] in the Wikipedia article regarding the revolution. Ford claims that infoboxes and cleanup tags were used as objects of "bespoken-code" by Wikipedia editors. By using these elements, editors shaped the news narrative in the first 18 days of the revolution. Ford used the discussion page and the history of edits to the page. She shows how political cartoons were removed, and how the number of casualties became a source of heated debate. Her research exemplifies how editors coordinated and prioritized work on the article, but also how political events are represented through collaborative journalism.'Ford, Heather. "Infoboxes and cleanup tags: Artifacts of Wikipedia newsmaking". Journalism (2014): 1464884914545739. === Role of media disruption on 28 January 2011 === During the early morning hours of 28 January the Mubarak regime shut down internet and cell phone networks in the whole country. This media shutdown was likely one of the reasons why the numbers of protestors exploded on 28 January. While the regime disrupted the media, people needed to engage in face-to-face communication on a local level, which the regime could not monitor or control. In such a situation it is more likely that radicals will influence their neighbors, who are not able to see the public opinion displayed in social media, therefore these people are then more likely to also engage in civil unrest. {{Cite journal|last=Hassanpour|first=Navid|date=2014|title=Media Disruption and Revolutionary Unrest:Evidence From Mubarak's Quasi-Experiment|url=|journal=Political Communication|volume=31|pages=1-24|via=}} This vicious circle can be explained through a [[threshold model]] of collective behavior, which states that people are more likely to engage in risky actions if other people inside their networks (neighbors, friends, etc.) have taken action. Radicals have a small threshold and are more likely to form new networks during an information blackout, influencing the people. Disrupting the media and communication had 2 main results: it increased the local mobilization of people and empowered radicals who influenced their surroundings, which resulted in an increase in protests. {{Cite journal|last=Hassanpour|first=Navid|date=2014|title=Media Disruption and Revolutionary Unrest: Evidence From Mubarak’s Quasi-Experiment|url=|journal=Political Communication|volume=31|pages=5-6|via=}} During 28 January the increased local mobilization pushed a large amount of apolitical Egyptians into action, either to look after their friends and family in the absence of mobile communication or to complain about the shutdown, resulting in large protests not only in Cairo. Meanwhile the Mubarak regime was unable to communicate a possible threat to the protestors via social media and was therefore unable to dissuade the crowds through this mean, which spread the protests further. === {{anchor|Egyptian Arts: Graffiti & Music}}Post-revolutionary art === {{main article|Contemporary Art in Egypt#Egyptian Arts post 2011 Revolution|l1= Egyptian art after the 2011 Revolution}} The 25 January Revolution and the fall of Hosni Mubarak the following month ushered in a new artistic era reflecting a changed social and political environment;{{cite web|last=Smith|first=Amelia|title=Revolution Graffiti: Street Art of the new Egypt|url=http://www.middleeastmonitor.com/media-review/book-review/5599-revolution-graffiti-street-art-of-the-new-egypt|publisher=Middle East Monitor|accessdate=15 April 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130412121254/http://www.middleeastmonitor.com/media-review/book-review/5599-revolution-graffiti-street-art-of-the-new-egypt|archivedate=12 April 2013|df=dmy-all}} "the revolution triggered a new public culture".{{cite journal|last=Abaza|first=Mona|title=Walls, Segregating Downtown Cairo and the Mohammed Mahmud Street Graffiti|journal=Theory, Culture & Society |date=9 October 2012|volume=30|issue=1}} Since its beginning, artists played a significant role in the protests; [[street art]] and music (''electro'' or ''techno sha'bi'') were used to craft a public culture.{{cite magazine |last=Parshley|first=Lois|title=For Egypt's Graffiti Artists Revolution Brings Inspiration and Uncertainty|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2011/10/for-egypts-graffiti-artists-revolution-brings-inspiration-and-uncertainty/245941/|magazine=The Atlantic|accessdate=15 April 2013}} Artists documented and captured the essence of the revolution, distributing their art through online and face-to-face social networks.{{cite web|last=Kholeif|first=Omar|title=The Social Impulse: Politics, Meida and Art After the Arab Uprisings|url=http://www.artandeducation.net/paper/the-social-impulse-politics-media-and-art-after-the-arab-uprisings/|publisher=Art & Education|accessdate=15 April 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130403032924/http://www.artandeducation.net/paper/the-social-impulse-politics-media-and-art-after-the-arab-uprisings/|archivedate=3 April 2013|df=dmy-all}} == {{anchor|Political activists}}See also == {{Portal|Egypt|Human rights|Politics|2010s}} {{colbegin}} * [[Lebanese Civil War]] * [[Syrian Civil War]] * [[Democracy in the Middle East]] * [[Muslim Brotherhood in post-Mubarak electoral politics of Egypt]] * [[Mohamed Mahmoud graffiti]] * [[Freedom in the World]] * [[List of freedom indices]] * [[List of modern conflicts in the {{distinguish|Holon (physics)}}
[[Image:Electron-hole.svg|thumb|When an electron leaves a [[helium]] atom, it leaves an electron hole in its place. This causes the helium atom to become positively charged.]]
In [[physics]], [[chemistry]], and [[electronic engineering]], an '''electron hole''' (often simply called a '''hole''') is the lack of an electron at a position where one could exist in an [[atom]] or [[crystal structure|atomic lattice]]. Since in a normal atom or crystal lattice the negative charge of the electrons is balanced by the positive charge of the [[atomic nucleus|atomic nuclei]], the absence of an electron leaves a net positive charge at the hole's location. Holes are not actually [[elementary particle|particles]], but rather [[quasiparticle]]s; they are different from the [[positron]], which is the [[antiparticle]] of the electron. (See also [[Dirac Sea]].) [[Werner Heisenberg]] developed the concept of a hole in 1931.
Holes in a metal<ref name="ashcroftandmermin">{{cite book|last1=Ashcroft and Mermin|title=Solid State Physics|date=1976|publisher=Holt, Reinhart, and Winston|isbn=0030839939|pages=299–302|edition=1st|accessdate=}}</ref> or [[semiconductor]] [[crystal lattice]] can move through the lattice as electrons can, and act similarly to [[electric charge|positively-charged]] particles. They play an important role in the operation of [[semiconductor device]]s such as [[transistor]]s, [[diode]]s and [[integrated circuit]]s. If an electron is excited into a higher state it leaves a hole in its old state. This meaning is used in [[Auger electron spectroscopy]] (and other [[x-ray]] techniques), in [[computational chemistry]], and to explain the low electron-electron scattering-rate in crystals ([[metal]]s, semiconductors).
In [[crystal]]s, [[electronic band structure]] calculations lead to an [[effective mass (solid-state physics)|effective mass]] for the electrons, which is typically negative at the top of a band. The [[negative mass]] is an unintuitive concept,<ref>For these negative mass electrons, [[crystal momentum|momentum]] is opposite to [[group velocity|velocity]], so forces acting on these electrons cause their velocity to change in the 'wrong' direction. As these electrons gain energy (moving towards the top of the band), they slow down.</ref> and in these situations a more familiar picture is found by considering a positive charge with a positive mass.
== Solid-state physics ==
In [[solid-state physics]], an '''electron hole''' (usually referred to simply as a '''hole''') is the absence of an electron from a full [[valence band]]. A hole is essentially a way to conceptualize the interactions of the electrons within a nearly ''full'' valence band of a crystal lattice, which is ''missing'' just a few electrons. In some ways, the behavior of a hole within a semiconductor [[Crystal structure|crystal lattice]] is comparable to that of the bubble in a full bottle of water.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Weller|first=Paul F.|date=1967|title=An analogy for elementary band theory concepts in solids|journal=J. Chem. Educ.|volume=44|issue=7|pages=391|url=http://pubs.acs.org/doi/abs/10.1021/ed044p391|doi=10.1021/ed044p391|bibcode = 1967JChEd..44..391W }}</ref>
=== Simplified analogy: Empty seat in an auditorium === [[File:15-puzzle-02.jpg|thumb|A children's puzzle which illustrates the mobility of holes in an atomic lattice. The tiles are analogous to electrons, while the missing tile ''(lower right corner)'' is analogous to a hole. Just as the position of the missing tile can be moved to different locations by moving the tiles, a hole in a crystal lattice can move to different positions in the lattice by the motion of the surrounding electrons.]]
Hole conduction in a [[valence band]] can be explained by the following analogy. Imagine a row of people seated in an auditorium, where there are no spare chairs. Someone in the middle of the row wants to leave, so he jumps over the back of the seat into an empty row, and walks out. The empty row is analogous to the [[conduction band]], and the person walking out is analogous to a free electron.
Now imagine someone else comes along and wants to sit down. The empty row has a poor view; so he does not want to sit there. Instead, a person in the crowded row moves into the empty seat the first person left behind. The empty seat moves one spot closer to the edge and the person waiting to sit down. The next person follows, and the next, et cetera. One could say that the empty seat moves towards the edge of the row. Once the empty seat reaches the edge, the new person can sit down.
In the process everyone in the row has moved along. If those people were negatively charged (like electrons), this movement would constitute [[Electrical resistivity and conductivity|conduction]]. If the seats themselves were positively charged, then only the vacant seat would be positive. This is a very simple model of how hole conduction works.
Instead of analyzing the movement of an empty state in the valence band as the movement of many separate electrons, a single equivalent imaginary particle called a "hole" is considered. In an applied [[electric field]], the electrons move in one direction, corresponding to the hole moving in the other. If a hole associates itself with a neutral atom, that atom loses an electron and becomes positive. Therefore, the hole is taken to have positive [[electric charge|charge]] of +e, precisely the opposite of the electron charge.
In reality, due to the [[uncertainty principle]] of [[quantum mechanics]], combined with the [[Bloch wave|energy levels available in the crystal]], the hole is not localizable to a single position as described in the previous example. Rather, the positive charge which represents the hole spans an area in the crystal lattice covering many hundreds of [[crystal structure|unit cells]]. This is equivalent to being unable to tell which broken bond corresponds to the "missing" electron. Conduction band electrons are similarly delocalized.
=== Detailed picture: A hole is the absence of a negative-mass electron === [[File:BandDiagram-Semiconductors-E.PNG|thumb|right|A semiconductor [[electronic band structure]] (right) includes the dispersion relation of each band, i.e. the energy of an electron ''E'' as a function of the electron's [[Wave vector|wavevector]] ''k''. The "unfilled band" is the semiconductor's [[conduction band]]; it curves upward indicating positive [[effective mass (solid-state physics)|effective mass]]. The "filled band" is the semiconductor's [[valence band]]; it curves downward indicating negative effective mass.]] The analogy above is quite simplified, and cannot explain why holes create an opposite effect to electrons in the [[Hall effect]] and [[Thermoelectric effect#Seebeck effect|Seebeck effect]]. A more precise and detailed explanation follows.<ref name=Kittel>Kittel, ''Introduction to Solid State Physics'', 8th edition, pp. 194–196.</ref>
* ''The [[dispersion relation]] determines how electrons respond to forces (via the concept of [[Effective mass (solid-state physics)|effective mass]]).''<ref name=Kittel />
A dispersion relation is the relationship between [[Wave vector|wavevector]] (k-vector) and energy in a band, part of the [[electronic band structure]]. In quantum mechanics, the electrons are waves, and energy is the wave frequency. A localized electron is a [[Wave packet|wavepacket]], and the motion of an electron is given by the formula for the [[group velocity|group velocity of a wave]]. An electric field affects an electron by gradually shifting all the wavevectors in the wavepacket, and the electron moves because its wave group velocity changes. Therefore, again, the way an electron responds to forces is entirely determined by its dispersion relation. An electron floating in space has the dispersion relation ''E''=ℏ<sup>2</sup>''k''<sup>2</sup>/(2''m''), where ''m'' is the (real) [[Electron rest mass|electron mass]] and ℏ is [[Planck constant|reduced Planck constant]]. Near the bottom of the [[conduction band]] of a semiconductor, the dispersion relation is instead ''E''=ℏ<sup>2</sup>''k''<sup>2</sup>/(2''m''<sup>*</sup>) (''m''<sup>*</sup> is the ''[[Effective mass (solid-state physics)|effective mass]]''), so a conduction-band electron responds to forces ''as if'' it had the mass ''m''<sup>*</sup>.
* ''Electrons near the top of the [[valence band]] behave as if they have [[negative mass]].''<ref name=Kittel />
The dispersion relation near the top of the valence band is ''E''=ℏ<sup>2</sup>k<sup>2</sup>/(2''m''<sup>*</sup>) with ''negative'' effective mass. So electrons near the top of the valence band behave like they have [[negative mass]]. When a force pulls the electrons to the right, these electrons actually move left. This is solely due to the shape of the valence band, and is unrelated to whether the band is full or empty. If you could somehow empty out the valence band and just put one electron near the valence band maximum (an unstable situation), this electron would move the "wrong way" in response to forces.
* ''Positively-charged holes as a shortcut for calculating the total current of an almost-full band.''<ref name=Kittel />
A perfectly full band always has zero current. One way to think about this fact is that the electron states near the top of the band have negative effective mass, and those near the bottom of the band have positive effective mass, so the net motion is exactly zero. If an otherwise-almost-full valence band has a state ''without'' an electron in it, we say that this state is occupied by a hole. There is a mathematical shortcut for calculating the current due to every electron in the whole valence band: Start with zero current (the total if the band were full), and ''subtract'' the current due to the electrons that ''would'' be in each hole state if it wasn't a hole. Since ''subtracting'' the current caused by a ''negative'' charge in motion is the same as ''adding'' the current caused by a ''positive'' charge moving on the same path, the mathematical shortcut is to pretend that each hole state is carrying a positive charge, while ignoring every other electron state in the valence band.
* ''A hole near the top of the valence band moves the same way as an electron near the top of the valence band '''would''' move''<ref name=Kittel /> (which is in the opposite direction compared to conduction-band electrons experiencing the same force.)
This fact follows from the discussion and definition above. This is an example where the auditorium analogy above is misleading. When a person moves left in a full auditorium, an empty seat moves right. But in this section we are imagining how electrons move through k-space, not real space, and the effect of a force is to move all the electrons through k-space in the same direction at the same time. In this context, a better analogy is a bubble underwater in a river: The bubble moves the same direction as the water, not opposite.
Since force = mass × acceleration, a negative-effective-mass electron near the top of the valence band would move the opposite direction as a positive-effective-mass electron near the bottom of the conduction band, in response to a given electric or magnetic force. Therefore, a hole moves this way as well.
* ''Conclusion: Hole is a positive-charge, positive-mass [[quasiparticle]]''.
From the above, a hole (1) carries a positive charge, and (2) responds to electric and magnetic fields as if it had a positive charge and positive mass. (The latter is because a particle with positive charge and positive mass responds to electric and magnetic fields in the same way as a particle with negative charge and negative mass.) That explains why holes can be treated in all situations as ordinary positively charged [[quasiparticles]].
=== Role in semiconductor technology ===
In some semiconductors, such as silicon, the hole's effective mass is dependent on direction ([[Anisotropy|anisotropic]]), however a value averaged over all directions can be used for some macroscopic calculations.
In most semiconductors, the effective mass of a hole is much larger than that of an [[electron]]. This results in lower [[Electron mobility|mobility]] for holes under the influence of an [[electric field]] and this may slow down the speed of the electronic device made of that semiconductor. This is one major reason for adopting electrons as the primary charge carriers, whenever possible in semiconductor devices, rather than holes. Also, why [[NMOS logic]] is faster than [[PMOS logic]].
However, in many semiconductor devices, both electrons ''and'' holes play an essential role. Examples include [[p–n diode]]s, [[Bipolar junction transistor|bipolar transistors]], and [[CMOS logic]].
== Holes in quantum chemistry == An alternate meaning for the term '''electron hole''' is used in [[computational chemistry]]. In [[coupled cluster]] methods, the ground (or lowest energy) state of a molecule is interpreted as the "vacuum state"—conceptually, in this state there are no electrons. In this scheme, the absence of an electron from a normally filled state is called a "hole" and is treated as a particle, and the presence of an electron in a normally empty state is simply called an "electron". This terminology is almost identical to that used in solid-state physics.
== See also == * [[Band gap]] * [[Carrier generation and recombination]] * [[Effective mass (solid-state physics)|Effective mass]] * [[Electrical resistivity and conductivity]] * [[Hole formalism]]

{{More footnotes|date=March 2015}}
{{Infobox person | name = Emma Livry | image = Emma Livry -Sylphide 1.JPG | alt = | caption = Emma Livry in the title role of the [[Filippo Taglioni|Taglioni]]/[[Jean Schneitzhoeffer|Schneitzhoeffer]] ''[[La Sylphide]]''. Paris, 1862 | birth_name = Jeanne Emma Emarot or Emma Marie Emarot (disputed) | birth_date = {{birth date|1842|09|24|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[France]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1863|07|26|1842|09|24|df=yes}} | death_place = [[Neuilly-sur-Seine]], [[France]] | known_for = ''[[La Sylphide]]'', other romantic ballets | occupation = [[Ballerina|danseuse]] | years_active = 1858–1863 | current_group = [[Paris Opera Ballet]] | nationality = French | parents = Célestine Emarot and Baron [[Charles de Chassiron]]}}
'''Emma Livry''' (born as '''Jeanne Emma Emarot''' or '''Emma Marie Emarot'''; 24 September 1842 – 26 July 1863) was one of the last [[ballerina]]s of the [[Romantic ballet]] era and a protégée of [[Marie Taglioni]]. She died from complications after burn injuries sustained when her costume caught fire during a rehearsal.
==Biography== Livry was the illegitimate daughter of Célestine Emarot, a ballet dancer, and Baron [[Charles de Chassiron]], which prompted the following rhyming verse:
:Can so skinny a ''[[Corps de ballet|rat]]'' :Be the daughter of so round a cat?<ref>{{cite book|title=The Ballet Annual & Year Book|first=Ivor|last=Guest|page=55|isbn=}}</ref>
===Career=== She studied dancing under Madame Dominique and attended the Paris Opera School. Her career was promoted by her mother's lover at the time, Vicomte Ferdinand de Montguyon. On 19 October 1858,<ref name=williams/> at the age of sixteen, she made her debut with the [[Paris Opera Ballet]] at the [[Salle Le Peletier]] as the [[sylph]] in ''[[La Sylphide]]''. Her talent brought her fame and she became a widely respected ballerina.<ref name=williams/>
Montguyon prevailed upon the director of the Opera to change the programme so that [[Marie Taglioni]] (who originated the role) would see Livry in ''La Sylphide'' when she visited. Taglioni decided to stay on in Paris to teach the girl, who reminded her of herself as a young woman. She choreographed for Livry the title-role of Farfalla (Butterfly) in ''[[Le Papillon (ballet)|Le Papillon]]'', the only full-length ballet composed by [[Jacques Offenbach]]. The sculptor [[Jean-Auguste Barre]] created a figurine of Livry in this role in bronze and [[Bisque (pottery)|bisque]] versions.
Paul Smith wrote in ''[[:fr:Revue et gazette musicale de Paris|Revue et gazette musicale de Paris]]'':{{cquote|She was so ethereal, and diaphanous, an intangible artist imperative, an artist with ''ballon'' .... Mlle. Livry had a ''[[ballon (ballet)|ballon]]'' which has never been equalled – she bounds and leaps as no one else could do. She skims over the ground, the water and the flowers, apparently without touching them. Shims like feather and falls like a snowflake.}}
===Accidental death=== On 15 November 1862, Livry was rehearsing the title role of Fenella, a [[mime]] part and the title role in [[Daniel Auber|Auber's]] opera ''[[La muette de Portici]]''. Making her second-act entrance, she shook out her skirts, which caught fire on a gaslight. The accident was avoidable: a method of fire-proofing costumes was available in this period, but Livry and most female performers of the period were opposed to it because it discolored and stiffened fabrics.<ref name=williams>Roger L. Williams, ''Gaslight and Shadow: The World of Napoleon III'' (NY: Macmillan, 1957), 106. Fire-proofing was required by an imperial decree of 27 November 1859. In 1860 a dancer's costume had caught fire during rehearsals for Offenbach's ''Le Papillon'' which starred Livry.</ref>
In flames, she ran across the stage three times before she was caught and the fire extinguished with the help of firemen and other dancers. Her burns were more extensive than deep. She had clasped the burning fabric to her torso out of modesty. Her face and breasts were undamaged. According to the doctor in attendance, her thighs, waist, back, shoulders and arms were burned, and her stays were burned on. She tried to pray. Taglioni, who was watching the rehearsal, rubbed make-up grease into her wounds in the mistaken belief that it would act as ointment. She suffered for months, yet remained opposed to fire-proofed skirts: "Yes, they are, as you say, less dangerous, but should I ever return to the stage, I would never think of wearing them – they are so ugly."<ref name="ivorguest">{{cite book|title=The Ballet Annual & Year Book|first=Ivor|last=Guest|page=59|isbn=|accessdate=26 March 2015}}</ref>
In 1863, she was moved from her home in Paris to Neuilly-sur-Seine. However, her wounds re-opened and she succumbed to [[sepsis|septicæmia]]. Montguyon was with her when she died. She was only 20 years old. After a funeral at Notre Dame de Lorette in Paris, she was buried in the [[Montmartre Cemetery|Cimetière de Montmartre]]. The surviving scraps of her costume can be seen in the [[Bibliothèque-Musée de l'Opéra National de Paris|Musée de l'Opéra]] in Paris.<ref name="ivorguest"/>
==References==
===Notes=== {{Reflist}}
===Sources and further reading=== *M. Quatrelles L'Epine, "Une danseuse française au XIXe siècle: Emma Livry", ''Bulletin de la Société de l'Histoire du Théâtre'' (Paris, November 1908 – January 1909), pp. 7–47. *Guest, Ivor, ''The Ballet of the Second Empire'' (London, 1955) *[https://archive.org/stream/balletannualandy007628mbp#page/n57/mode/2up Guest, Ivor, "Centenary: Emma Livry, 1842–1863", in ''The Ballet Annual & Year Book'', Mary Clarke & Arnold Haskell, eds., (New York & London, 1963), pp. 54–60]
==External links== {{Commons category}} *[http://www.paperblog.fr/305846/emma-livry-une-histoire-tragique-a-l-opera Bernard Vassor: Emma Livry, une histoire tragique à l'opéra] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060223220149/http://michaelminn.net/andros/biographies/livry_emma.htm Andros on Ballet] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20081003040949/http://www.dancer.com/livry.php Christina Towle: Emma Livry]
{{Authority control}}
